content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												Star Trek Online is by far one of the best MMOs that I have played.Personally, I'll try out an MMO for a couple hours, maybe play here and there later, and then uninstall because I've lost interest. But not this.Cryptic has done a great job in developing this game. There are a few bugs here and there, but nothing too game-breaking. The story is very well done and is the part that keeps my attention. The leveling is also stellar, in most MMOs you'll sit there for hours and hours grinding to get to the next level. Or it sets you on a quest and the area is for level 20+ and you're level 10, you'll have to grind for days just to get to progress the story. Not with STO.Each mission in STO does require you to be a certain level, BUT each mission also levels you up just enough to get to the next. And with the DOFF system (which is very easy to get the hang of) is an easy way of getting XP. I've known a few players who have gotten some of their characters to max level and not even leaving their faction's homeworld by using the DOFFs. The story is also interesting to say the least, it wasn't so good that I couldn't keep it off my mind, but it was good enough to keep coming back.TL:DR The story is great, the developers are cool, and the leveling is stellar.9/10

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												Don't let the low play time irritate you guys. I played this game almost from release and only a week before I finally quit it (Dec 2014) for good I added it to steam so I don't have to Alt-Tab every time someone texts me.It used to be the best game ever in the entire universe. Everybody who played during the first couple seasons will agree with that.Then PWE took over and thrashed it.From what I hear there is no end to this agony, so I decided to stick the boot right in and write a review myself. Not being a man of many words, there is not much else to add. People who played and especially PVPed in this game exactly know why I and many many other started quitting the game after PWE took over.If you never played STO before, then there is only one advice I can give you: run, run as fast and as far as you possibly can away from this game.Its business model is following: everything is for free and you can obtain literally every single item in this game without spending a single Dollar, Euro, Pound, Banana or whichever is your country's currency. Sounds great, right? It is in fact great if you have a lifetime to wait for crafting and reputation missoins while you endlessly grind for dilithium. Of course you can accelerate this process by shoving your real world money up PWE's rear exit. We are not talking 2 Dollar microtransactions, no my friends, we are talking big money here.If you even dream of being something remotely close to competitive in this game then you already play it for at least 2 years and know exactly what you're doing, or you have thousands of Dollars, Euros etc ready to be thrown at PWE.To people who love and enjoy at least decent PVP matches: According to PWE's PR person "The PVP community consists of 14 year olds living in their mum's basement". And that's also pretty much how PWE treats PVP in this game. The Queues may pop but what you find there is P2W spam deluxe.Final verdict: Would not even force my special friend Geko to play it, that's how bad it is now.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												Don't mind the almost 500 hour game time. I have WAY more hours logged on this game, it's just that I had been using the non-steam game and launcher for a LONG time until I finally figured out it was also on steam. meh. Okay ladies and gentlemen, I've gotta put first things first. This game is NOT, I repeat, NOT, pay to win. Now keep reading.Anyway, let me get straight to the point. If you've never seen Start Trek before you'll be confused at first, because of the fact that you don't know $#!T about anything going on, and you won't understand almost anything in the game. However, the game does an excellent job of introducing all of the storylines and basically everything in the Star Trek universive to you, so basically, if you play this game long enough, you'll become a Trekkie, without even having watched any of the shows.STO also has great missions, which are very immersive and interactive. Once you're done with one storyline, there'll always be many more to complete, as the STO team uploads new ones almost every 2-3 months. (Don't quote me.) This game is absolutely free to play, which is of course, awesome. Every single weapon and ship can be aquired through a great system. Time and effort. Of course, it'll take much less time to aquire certain ships by purchasing them with Zen Points (Currency that is bought with real money), but it all depends on how you'd like to approach the game. I personally have not made a single ship purchase with Zen Points, and I still have a very strong ship that is capable of taking on any foe. The game also has two im-game currency systems, Energy Credits and Dilithium. You'll be using these two currencies to buy most of your ships and equipment. Both of these currencies are easy to earn and the prices for items are never too high. It has a great ranking-up and skill-tree system, and also has great PvP missions and PvE missions as well. And in PvP, your'e paired up with people of the same level, so you won't get obliterated by people who are much higher ranked than you.There are many many things that I haven't mentioned in this review. The devs have put a great amount of time and effort into this amazing game and I think that they deserve praise for it.       But to sum it all up, you get to run around, shoot lasers at people, shoot bigger lasers at ships, get in game credits, buy really cool things, shoot at people more, and play Dabo. Yes, dabo. This game has gambling. What more do you want? Now download the dang game.

number of helpful: 30 of 53 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												Here's the short version; An MMO set in the Star Trek universe that does not really feel like true Star Trek much at all.Allow me to explain in the long version. This review is aimed at hardcore Trek fans that enjoy proper immersion.You go through a rank system; you get given command of your first ship at the first true rank; ensign. There's mistake number one! No one becomes captain of a ship at ensign!The game is 95% combat. No exploration or discovery and a there's a mere smidgen of diplomacy. They removed the exploration features in the game some time ago. If you're into Trek as much as I am, it would be nice to have a ratio of at least 60% combat, 40 exploration and diplomacy. Part of Star Trek as we all know, was about exploring strange new worlds, seeking out new life and new civilisations and boldly going where no one has gone before. You can play some player made Foundry missions which feature exploration, but nothing from the devs themselves.There are no real decisions to make in your actions and through dialogue. Every mission ends up the same way no matter what option in the dialogue menu there is. If anyone reading this has played Star Trek: Tactical Assault, you know that picking dialogue options actually affected situation outcomes and whether you got a gold or silver rating by playing how a real captain should. That key part of being a captain of a starship has been removed.Also, it seems that your bridge officers appear to be much more qualified to be captain than you are. In every mission they practically determine what you have to do or you've picked up some gear that must be used to succeed. There is virtually no decision making that comes from your own mind on how to approach a situation and act accordingly. All you do is basically shoot first and ask pointless questions interspersed that don't change anything.Severe damage to a ship seems reparable in a minute with no penalty to how your ship performs. This allows people to just stroll in and absorb all the fire with no concern to how or how much the ship is damaged. I'm sure the crew of your ship would be ready to abandon you over letting them die needlessly. I would prefer it if crew were reimplemented but became a much more integral part of gameplay such as if lose half your crew, you won't be so efficient. But they also removed crew back in the season ten update. I would prefer it if your damage carried through until the end of a mission. Also, if damage affected systems like EPS conduits and weapons banks and the like, throwing you into a state of heightened panic of your ship being blown to smithereens.Another thing I dislike is the ability to push your ship far beyond its designed specifications through the use of abilities that can instantly repair hull or rapidly regenerate shields. I don't dislike all abilities, some of them definitely make sense and are acceptable, but there are a few which one bridge officer could not pull off.Apparently you can just change out parts of your ship no worries without spending months in spacedock. Warp reactor not up to your standards, just remove and replace, simple as that. Ships are designed and constructed with certain components, some of those can't be removed easily. I would prefer it if you were assigned a ship and forced to stay with the default layout. It just helps with the immersion that you're not a revered captain but instead, just there to do your job.And now, this brings me to my final point. Your ship's weapons and shields are always charged and ready to be put to use. Way to go trying to avoid a hostile situation with all your weapons armed and pointing at the other ship. There are also no alert statuses so you can't select between green, yellow and red alerts; which is undoubtedly one of the integral parts of Star Trek's combat. Yelling red alert and 'charge weapons, energise defense fields' was something I was looking forward to, but alas, doesn't exist.So that ends the long version of my review. If you like to be immersed in a game full of Star Trek, go and play Star Trek Tactical Assault or something else, not Star Trek Online. The feel of Star Trek is squandered by the limitations and playstyle of an MMO.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												Reviewing Star Trek Online is an interesting experience, because it's a little hard to put my finger on why I play it sometimes.Let's start with the basics: it's an MMORPG.  In a lot of ways, it's a very conventional RPG; a levelling system, more grind than a flour mill, regular bug-filled updates (which, to be fair, get fixed pretty quickly - the big, noticeable ones, at least).  It's also got two and a half factions which don't like each other, and since it's F2P, it's loaded with microtransactions.It marks itself out with having both space and ground mechanics, being almost entirely instanced, and through being Star Trek.  Let's face it, if you're here, you're almost certainly a Trekkie to begin with.The cons:1. 'Micro'transactions.  This game is not cheap.  I've played over 400 hours and not bought anything from the C-store, and I don't feel particularly helpless, but endgame ships will set you back around $40.  Admittedly that's a one-off payment, and any future characters can use that ship without restriction, but it's still a fairly large investment.2. Endgame balance is horrible.  The Special Task Force missions (read: raids) have almost dead public queues due to horrific imbalance in capability between a newly minted Lvl 60 player and an experienced and well-equipped endgame player; we're talking not a difference of 25% or so, but in the order of 1000% or more.  This has a few nasty side-effects for obtaining important gear; not insurmountable, but certainly frustrating.3. Complexity curve.  The game itself is relatively simple, but there are a lot of behind-the-scenes mechanics that are not even slightly self-evident.  These aren't a big obstacle to gameplay until lvl 50 or so, but it can make the experience feel sluggish and frustrating.  Browsing of the STO reddit is highly recommended if you want to stick with the game.4. Ground combat is subpar.  I personally don't think it's as bad as some people make out, but it's not nearly as fun as space stuff.  There are a few exceptions (personal cloaking devices combined with plasma flamethrowers are immensely entertaining) but it just doesn't feel as polished and developed.  Fortunately it's also a lot more forgiving in general.With that in mind, let's get to the reason why I keep coming back to this thing.1. Space combat is excellent.  Once you get used to the interface (I know some people find it awkward) it's very fluid.  As a long-time Eve Online player, I can honestly say that I prefer the STO mechanics; managing flight controls, a wide variety of offensive and defensive powers, and wrestling with keeping the enemy lined up with your weapons while keeping your shields boosted is a wonderful challenge.  It's also pretty as sin and really feels like Star Trek.  Diving at a Borg cube as the Defiant with all cannons blazing or seeing phaser fire bloom off your Galaxy as you maneuver at a stately pace around a hostile D'deridex is a great feeling.  Some of the powers also really give a suitably epic feel.  Using Torpedo Spread engulfs entire enemy squadrons in fields of photon torpedoes, while Fire At Will will make every beam you have fire at every enemy in range.2. Flexibility.  When making a character, you pick faction (Federation, Klingon or Romulan) and a 'class'; Tactical, Science or Engineering.  In World of Warcraft, that would be it: you'd have just picked your playstyle for the rest of the game.  Not so here; your class only governs a set of basic powers you have, and what powers you can use in ground combat.  You still have the full range of ships, weapons, secondary powers and equipment available.  Just because you picked an Engineering 'tanky' character doesn't stop you from flying glass cannon Defiants, and a high-damage Tactical can use the resilient, sluggish Galaxy.3. Events.  This is the one saving grace for all the high-cost real-money ships; on a regular basis, you'll be able to grind for special limited event ships.  These are high-end and very effective; one of the recent ships is considered by some to be one of the tankiest ships in the game.4. The story is actually pretty good.  MMO storylines tend to turn me off; they're clunky and ignorable.  While that certainly applies to a fair amount of STO, there are some excellently crafted set-pieces and missions.  Being kidnapped and brainwashed, seeing friends massacred after a peace conference goes wrong - and let's not forget the Romulan tutorial, where everyone you know is killed or kidnapped as you barely escape in a rusting hulk of a warbird.  Mass Effect it ain't, but I've been pleasantly surprised.5. Speaking of which, you can tell that it's written by real Star Trek nerds.  Despite an incredible range of enemies, locations and concepts, just about everything can be tied into one of the episodes or movies.  Two of the endgame enemies are spun off from a couple of stand-alone episodes of Voyager, but they feel in-character and match up with what we saw of them in the series.  The Elachi, a recurring enemy for Romulan players, were designed from a single episode of Enterprise where we barely saw them, but the elaboration works perfectly.  Creepy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.  You'll also hear some very familiar voices - Worf, Sela, Harry Kim, Tuvok, Spock (RIP) and a fair number of minor characters from the series have lent their voice talents.6. Levelling is fairly painless.  I remember attempting to get through WoW and giving up around Lvl 40 (Lich King era).  By comparison, STO has far fewer missions, and you can get a character to Lvl 50 in a week's casual play.  50-60 is a lot more tedious, but it's a lot less noticeable; you've unlocked all the important things, and it would be fair to say that the game really starts at 50.  Everything prior has been a warm-up tutorial.7.  Endgame gear.  Many games require endless farming of a given boss in the hopes of a drop.  STO completely drops this idea; endgame gear is all obtained from Fleet (guild) equipment or the Reputation system.  Endgame content merely provides the means to afford this equipment.  It's entirely predictable, and I personally would prefer to know that I need ten runs to get what I want, rather than roll the dice of potentially getting it first time, but likely needing to run fifty times.  I get enough RNG nonsense from Warframe.In conclusion... STO is by no means a perfect game.  That said, I would be comfortable in saying that it's one of the better offerings on the market.  Give it a week, and you'll be pleasantly surprised - or at least, you won't be bemoaning your lost time.

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												I wanted a new MMO experience, and as a hardcore trek fan, I immediately leapt to this game thinking that it would satisfy the itch. While undoubtedly more loyal to its source material than any other star trek game I've ever played, this game really does count on its franchise name, rather than the actual merits of the game, to draw players in and create the experience. One of the very first enemies the starting missions will have you fight are the borg, which I and the NPC ship that was joining me for the quest defeated easily. The game constant throughs the most terrifying and iconic aliens of the Star Trek franchise at you (such as the borg, species 8472, the klingons, ect.), as if to remind you that this is in fact a star trek game, and you merciliously gun them all down. Part of what made those enemies so terrifying on the show was just how out-matched the federation ships were against them. When you see a borg cube one your screen, you should be weeping and just as scared as Picard was when he faced off against them, not happily blow one up after another with two other ships. The appearance of these enemies strikes me as fanservice--and bad fanservice at that, which there is plenty of throughout the game (did I mention that the captain you work under in the starting zone constaly refers to you as his Number 1?) If they had spent even half the time they spent thinking up stupid references trying to balance the combat and making the multiplayer exciting (which, by the way, you'll either be curb-stomping your way through or getting curb-stombed, there is no in between or concept of "fair fights" or "evenly matched" opponents, but no one really does PvP anyway) they'd have a great game one their hands. In trying to make the game as "iconic" as possible, and not spending more time working on how to make the game as diverse, challenging, and as balanced as possible, the devs really delivered a watered-down Star Trek experience here. TL;DR?Beam me up, Scotty! There's no Star Trek game down here worth playing!

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												Vast and complex universe, lots of playstyles supported, most content optional, buggy.There's a ton of content to play without paying a dime, but PVP and the highest-end PVE has a "pay or grind to win" element.Vast open universe (which lost significant content in the form of ground and space nebula missions that were evidently too hard to maintain) with various regions - be aware the regions do have difficulty levels. The "season" story missions scale with your level but do so unevenly, and rewards do not always scale. Fleet membership offers potential huge bonuses but requires a lot of resources.The ships are amazing (some of them), many of the story missions are too, a few are insanely irritating. You can skip many story missions. There is a "reputation" system that is pretty grindy but offers a lot of rewards.There are bugs in this game that have gone unfixed for *years* and impact play, rarely is there a response to a trouble ticket, dev does not put enough resources into maintenance.Game works remarkably well on low-spec hardware (played on a T2390 laptop with X3100 graphics and a Turion 64 1.8 with ATI X300) this is largely because of the ability to turn graphics down to where they look like a mid-90s game!The low spec capability and huge amount of story keep this game a recommend, the bugs almost doomed it.

number of helpful: 12 of 19 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												I've played this game so much I need to justify my time with a review before people start looking at my play time and believe I somehow enjoy this game enough to endorse it and encourage others to play it.To make this clear - no, I do not think you or anyone else should play this game no matter how much time I spent and possibly continue spending in this game.This is a subpar MMO and doesn't even get good marks on the sci-fi MMO scene with several other examples being higher in quality and time investment.  The game's mechanics are at this point extremely dated and were dated when the game was released.  At this point, the developers have no idea which direction to take the game or what sort of players to encourage, satisfied with keeping things in the status quo.As far as value goes, the game is free to play and free to patch.  However, a lot of things in the game require a bit of investment from actual money out of your actual wallet.  Current ships and equipment with current mechancics require you to either pay for them or to grind the real money currency with in-game activities.  This grind will take an extremely long time as there is a currency cap which makes you either buy more character slots or wait a long, long time to buy a current ship.  This extends to everything out of the cash shop - which you need to go to for end-game ships, you either need real money, a lot of time grinding the time gated currency, or a lot of time spent grinding the in-game currency.  If you're smart you'll be able to do it, you'll also understand the way you're being gamed by the system and may feel disinterested in continuing.The combat and mechanics are a little dated, the graphics are servicable enough but there are some crash problems on modern systems, and older systems, and systems where you don't set the graphical options properly.  Ground combat is hilariously imbalanced, and space combat is ok, if a bit clunky.  Other space sims have much better and fluid mechanics, but this is a combat transitioned to an MMO and ok is a passable requirement.The endgame in this game is a repitition of the same short instanced encounters and a lengthy reputation grind to get better and better gear with the future promising more grinds and rep tracks.  You can also grind currency or spend time goofing off with friends.  As far as the choices go, goofing off with friends and nerding out about star trek is probably the preferable activity.The game is not without its positives.  The missions, while set up with pre-planned and cut-and paste mechanics are very well written and enough care has been put in the story to entertain and keep any fan of star trek playing.  In my opinion the writing in the Romulan storyline is one of the best written things you'll find in sci-fi gaming.The other thing I enjoyed or found surprisingly enjoyable was the mission editor.  This is one of the few MMOs with a mission editor and user-created content.  Some of the content is terrible but some of the content is very well done and well written by the community.  Playing around in the mission editor can be something rewarding for anyone with the patience required to develop interesting work.In all, this is a very poor MMO which I don't think anyone should play.  Much of the gameplay is pulled from and copied from other MMO's and replicated in an inferior form.  The Star Trek content can have some interest for fans, but it will lack the staying power to keep you involved.  The only reason it has its hooks in me is because its one of the few Star Trek games you can find.  Even if you are interested in it for the star trek content, you should still just play the missions for the story and forget about the rest of the game when you run out of story content.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												STO has had it's problems. On release it was buggy with poor controls and balancing. I'm pleased to say that the issues are mostly in the past, and the transition to free to play has been handled very well. I've put a huge amount of time into this one, and have greatly enjoyed my experience both alone and with friends (although being an MMO, friends are recommended). There is an entertaining mix of ground and space combat, and branching dialogues with plenty of customisation options for your character, ship and play style. Due to the numerous and ongoing updates there is now a pretty large amount of content to play through and keep you entertained.To date I've never felt like I HAD to buy anything using real cash. From the starting levels through to the endgame, everything can be completed without paying a dime. There are a fairly large selection of ships, outfits and other customisation options which do require you to shell out some cash, however there is never the feeling of "pay to win". Should you be willing to spend a little, Cryptic have catered well and there are some items which you may enjoy. All in all, a solid free to play game. Worth a look - and for free, why not?

Posted: April 2, 2015
												Star Trek Online has made a lot of improvments over the last five years.  What started out as a clunky mess full of good ideas and half formed systems has been refined, remade and polished into one of the most fun Free to Play MMOs out there.  Space and Ground combat has been redesigned to be fun and challenging rather than plodding and tedious and the rate of expansions and new Episodes (story missions) means that there is always somethign new to try.That's not even taking into account the wealth of player created content in the Foundry missions (some of which are excellent) and the option to make missions yourself!  The game offers a lot of options and different activities with enough to meet the desires of almost every player type, Crafting, PVP, RP, PVE and even raiders.  Give it a download and have some Trek fun!Live Long and Prosper

content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												 Can I just say, if you really love Star Trek, and you really love  MMORPGs, you will love this game. I am a huge fan of anything science fiction. When i discovered this game and found out that you can captain your own ship, I nearly exploded from excitment. The game did not disapoint. In the following paragraphs I will state things I enjoy about this game, and the very few cons that I have.          Pros- This game lets you captain a starship and fight any enemy the federation has ever faced. You fight Klingons, Romulans, Borg, Gorn, Cardassians, and even more! The stories do an extremely good job of putting you in the shoes of a captain and the space combat is fantastic. This game is extremely customizable and hundreds of different abilities for space comabt, and ground combat are available making each players build unique! Some people complain that once you reach level 60, the game is a cash grab. For people that aren't patient, yes it is. They complain that in order to receive tier 6 ships, you need to spend money. This is not entirely true becasue every year there are two or three events that give you the opportunity to win t6 starships. Sure, its a long process to win them but in the long run it's worth it! Or, if you've been a veteran for a decent amount of time, you may receive a free t6 ship from arc games thanking you for playing their game. Thats how I got mine! Also, going back to the campaign, the Iconian War story is fanominal! Also you can captain Klingon and Romulan ships. Nuff said.           Cons- I don't have many issues with this game except for a couple small issues. I think the ground combat could be a little better improved. Unless you're extremely duked out in shields and weapons at level 60, you will die alot. That being said, I do agree with some of the issues that many people have about the game being a cash grab. Yes, you can get free t6 ships, but if you want a t6 ship without waiting, it will cost 30$ of real money. Thats way too much to spend for just a decent ship in an MMO. For people that may not be as patient, this game is such a cash grab.          Overall, I have enjoyed this game alot. There is so much to do in it and its space combat is extremely engaging and addictive. If you aren't the most patient person out there, this game could potentially become a cash grab but if you have the patience at level 60, you will receive a t6 ship in time. All in all, get this game. Its so much fun!

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Pretty neat MMORPG.WHAT I LIKENo mindless, repetitive grinding required. There are LOTS of missions to go around and they are fine to level you up to the highest levels. Once you reach those levels, there are STILL more missions to go around. Lol.Ground AND space combat. <3Lots of customization options for character and starship appearance and equipment.All the customization options yield a variety of different playstyles, so there are lots of things to try.Co-op play is actually beneficial, and there are events in missions that only specific classes (tactical, engineering, or science) can do. If you have a buddy who plays a different class, then you can take advantage of more events than you would playing alone.WHAT I DISLIKEPaying into the game definitely yields an advantage, especially in PvP. However, for the most part, it SEEMS that free players can still acquire the fancy combat equipment and what not by putting more time and effort into the game. There are aesthetic elements that can be acquired only with Zen (the currency you get by buying with real monies), but they don't really affect the outcome of battles; they're just for looks.PvP can get really annoying with hardcore players who have MUCH better equipment than newer players, and who will not relent, thereby spoiling the experience for others.After a while, it can get repetitive. The vast majority of missions involve space combat, ground combat, then space combat, travel to a different system, and have more space combat.Overall, I like it, but wouldn't pay for it.

content:
Posted: February 7
												STO has had a rocky history in the sense that their main source of income now seems to lie within these things called "lockboxes", which are essentially online gambling machines. There are a number of prizes one can get from opening a lockbox and of course a top prize but the trick is that in order to open one you need to spend real world cash to get keys. They are reasonably priced, but the chances to get the top prize in a lockbox are nearly a thousand to one. For most people, you're either extremely lucky or rich enough to keep throwing money at the game for more keys to get the prize you want.My biggest issue is not with the concept of lock boxes, but rather that the devs development of the lockboxes has seemingly overriden development of normal cash shop items, like ships and other items you can just buy instead of gambling on.Otherwise the game is fantastic, my steam profile only shows something like 153 hours on record but I assure you I've been playing since beta before they had even moved to steam. Space combat is solid and fun, ground combat's a little less polished but still quite amusing. The story arcs are well written and especially some of the more recent content, even touching. You may see people complaining about this or that within the game, but for many of us if we didn't think the game was worth it, we wouldn't bother complaining. All in all, if you even vaguely like Star Trek the game is worth your consideration.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												So, I decided to finally write up a review for this game. I figure that around 370 hours of play is enough to be able to know what I'm writing about.So, the first question you have to ask of Star Trek Online: Does it feel like Star Trek? The short answer is kind of. The long answer is yes and no. Whilst it has familiar staples of the franchise, it is also lacking in some elements. For example, more exploration that DIDN'T invariably lead into combat encounters wouldn't go amiss. I won't say it doesn't feel like Star Trek, but it feels almost exclusively like seasons six and seven of DS9 and season three of Enterprise. It has some Trek aspects, but it feels more like a Trek skin for a generic Space MMO and action based MMO. It does, however, have some nice fan service in appearances by existing characters, with several, including Spock, Worf, Sela, Tom Paris, Harry Kim, Seven of Nine, Neelix, the Doctor and Miral Paris, being voiced by their actors from the shows. An opening narration by Leonard Nimoy and an EMH voiced by Zachary Quinto are also both nice touches.What's worth considering on the lack of Trek feel to this game, is that it is somewhat remedied by the foundry; the user generated content is, in my experience, of great quality more often than not. In fact, there have been occassions where I've felt the foundry content had come out better than the content released by Cryptic / Perfect World / Whatever they want to call themselves now. A prime example is the Breen missions; whilst a fun little arc, some of the missions involved in it can be awkward to play. That's not to say all user created content is amazing and infinitely better than the stuff the studio puts out, just that it often has a more Star Trek feel to it.My next point is in regards to the playable classes. At the start of the game, you pick one of three factions, between Federation, Klingons and Romulans. It's worth noting that, while playing as a Romulan, you play as a member of the new Romulan Republic faction, NOT a member of the Romulan Star Empire, so if you're hoping to be the bad guy, your bubble's burst, I'm sorry. Each of these factions have their own stories, with the Federation being my favourite, the Romulans proving suitably intriguing but the Klingon story feels somewhat closer to how they have been portrayed in Trek before, so I find myself with a bias towards them over the Romulans.Once you've chosen your faction, we then get into the actual classes, broken up into the three basic areas of Starfleet; Tactical (i.e. Worf, Tuvok, Reed), Operations (i.e. Scotty, Data, O'Brien) or Science (i.e. Spock, Jadzia Dax, T'pol), with each filling their own role not quite typical of MMO's; Tactical tends to work best with the smaller, faster ships with run and gun tactics, Operations works with the big cruisers and dreadnoughts, and Science works with a sort of intermediary with more buffs. That's not to say you can't play a Tactical character in a Dreadnought (I do!) or a Science character in a light escort, it's just their abilities are more geared towards the ship types mentioned before.My one gripe with this game is the micro transactions; they aren't micro at all! Zen works out as almost 1p per 1 Zen, so when you see a ship for 3000 Zen, you're looking at about £30.00! Of course, Zen can be farmed via Dilithium mining. However, at the moment, it is 260 odd Dilithium per Zen, with an 8000 per character per day cap on amount you can refine; that translates to a lot of grinding for Dilithium. It doesn't help that the Z-store ships are noticably better than those found in the ship store that you get a free ship from as you go through. Wit hthe introduction of the new T6 ships, this is more noticable than ever, and I hope to see some real F2P T6 ships implemented soon!Overall, it's a good enough game. It's not a great Star Trek game, but it does pay fan service in the right places at least. My final opinion is; I'd reccomend this, but Trekkies, be patient with it, it'll take roughly as much patience as the Trek reboots do, so if you enjoy them, you'll enjoy this, if you don't, maybe give this one a miss.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3
=IntroductionStar Trek Online, a game I have been playing since around 2012 I believe and not a bad one at that, STO has made significant improvements to the graphics, functionality and overall gameplay, I enjoy this MMO and play it to chill out with friends or just to waste a few hours pew pew some Iconians.ContentStar Trek Online has a plethora of content which has been added over the years, with more missions, campaigns and the ability for a user to create their own missions that the community at large can play, this is known as the foundry. There are countless quests on which you can undertake as well as different characters at your disposal, for example you can play as a Federation, Klingon, Romulon (Fed aligned or Klingon aligned) and 23rd Century Federation. This gives you enormous amounts of things to do within the game with missions alone, however there's more, for instance you can PvE queue which is STOs equivalent to a raid in some respects allowing you to group up with others and complete the queues objectives for loot and other rewards. With a plethora of missions to complete as well as guild gameplay and other satisfying content there is plenty to do in STO. One thing that lets the game down is its ground section, although ok it is not the best but has improved over the last few years, thanks to the developers continued support for the game, as well as this the game recently underwent a graphical overhaul.PvE Queues and the ExchangePvE queues are the main way of getting yourself nice loot as well as marks, marks form a part of a reputation system that you grind out to get set items (think World of Warcraft) it involves set missions that you queue for with others and complete for marks which you put towards getting more XP within the reputation system which in turn grants you more unlocks, I like this raid like system and have a lot of fun with it however a downside is that until you hit LVL 55 in game you only have access to a small portion of the queues, post 60 you have access to Elite queues which require META builds and coordination to complete. The exchange is the player market allowing you to sell and buy items and ships for EC or energy credits, it is a simple system much like a hub trader in other MMOs.Ships, Weapons and CraftingSTO offers a huge selection of ships from the Star Trek universe, with Sovereign Class ships like Enterprise E to Shinzons Scimitar Warbird there is plenty to choose from, however aquiring Tier 6 ships (at the time of review the highest tier or ship) a lot of work and time is required, or alternatively you can buy yourself a ship, as for me and the group we play with we nought ourselves tier 6 ships, for £20 it is worth it and it is just like buying the game itself at that point also, however this can also be a negative as it means that newer players that have progressed to LVL 55 will have to do quite some work to access these ships with the Dilithium market etc. I'll explain more in another section.Weapons in STO are tiered, from I to XVI, with loot quality from Common to Epic like many other MMOs, weapons will have different attributes and abilities which improve the higher the tier they are and also how good the quality is, this brings me to crafting, an extensive system within the game and quite fun, you level up your crafting in the R&D panel which allows you to craft every ship and ground module you need in the game, levelling up these can be done by crafting items and also researching, which grants you a decent amount of XP, more crafting slots unlock when you reach specific points within the crafting screen, such as having three separate specialties at level 10 for example, crafting requires good Officers however, BOFFS and DOFFS within STO play a huge role, these are Bridge Officers (they give you your abilities in space and ground combat) as well as Deck Officers (these give you bonuses to specific crafting etc) having goof DOFFS allows you to craft better items which have good stats. Crafting within the game is fun and rewarding as long as you stick at it, much like Eve in some respects you can queue a crafting project and come back later to collect it.Guilds/FleetsFleets in STO are clans or guilds, a fleet can construct a Starbase which grants benefits such as access to fleet ships, enhanced versions on their ordinary counterparts, however starting a fleet is not easy as you require people to be actively putting things into the Starbase upgrades and keeping everything topped up, being a fleet leader requires effort and commitment to the game if you want to succeed. Being in a fleet as an ordinary player can have benefits such as a community of people to group with or access to fleet ships, DoFFS and BoFFS as well as other benefits, the fleet system is expansive and engaging if somewhat grindy.SummarySTO is a solid MMO that you can have a lot of fun with as an average player, there is plenty of content to keep you interested and coming back for more. With a fun PVE queue selection as well as missions it can keep you busy, on top of crafting and trading on the player market. Pros and ConsPROS1. Fun space combat that feels satisfying and looks great2. Great crafting system, plenty to do3. Graphics are not too bad at allCONS1. Can be grindy2. Ground combat pretty poor3. Can be hard to get late tier ships without paying for itAll in all I recommend that you give it a go, after all it is Free!

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												This game (whilst with its flaws) is what i can honestly say to be one of my all time favorite MMO games to date. I have yet to find an MMO with the atmosphere of satisfaction and wonder this one does. It is a true follow on to the overall Star Trek franchise and can be said as one of the most cannon Star Trek workings to keep ticking on with the true feeling and fantasy sci-fi kept within.At a performance standar the game is prety easy and fun to control leaving the payer with the option tho change his/her controls if the have an significant problrms with it.The gameplay is pretty fun too. It is always improving with the game itself allowing the constant expansion of the franchise's own universe involving the timeline (25th Century) so that you can't simply say that youve already seen it or that its all been done before. Another thing i like is that the nature of the game features seasonal events than will constantly bring in new gameplay and all new missions and storyline to enjoy.However, there are some issues i have with it. Mainly being that in order to advance thouroughly through the ranks and continue with certain missions and aspects, you are almost required to have 4 other consecuative friends to join you just so that you can make a fleet. Now i know thats just what MMORPG's tend to do but this slight detail means that I have to a)Continue the game with that ship I have owned for around 2 months or b)I simply join some other random clan in which would require me to talk to other people. I know shocking but considering that i dont have enough time to participate in the constant flow of events they would be asking me to join i would rather not.Regardless, over all an enjoyable fun game that i can always rely upon for some relaxation and enjoyment if requiredPersonal Rating: 9/10

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												STO was a great game at one point.  It's a fairly mediocre game as of late.Many bad/questionable choices have caused major imbalances in the game, frustrated long time players, and shown that PWE/Cryptic is trying to heavily monitize the game at the expense of the players.However, that being said, there is much good to be said about STO as well.1) Decent storylines that pick up where the TV episodes and movies left off.  Cryptic has done a great job of revisiting many of the lesser known races in the STO universe, and bringing many unfinished story lines to a close.2) Ships, ships, and more ships.  All the amazing ships we know and love as well as quite a few retrofits/refits that bring our favoties up to par with the 25th century.  I love taking out my 23rd century Excelcisior class cruiser and wiping the floor with the Borg or even other players.  Nothing is more embarassing then a 200 year old ship tearing your brand new top of the line cruiser to shreds.3) Decent player base.  Social interaction is recommended, but not required.  You can go a long ways without ever having to say hello to another player.  However, joining a fleet should be one of the first things that you do, so that you can get further, get better gear, etc.4) Decent selection of real world money ships, costumes, etc.  Some of them are obvious money grabs, but some of them are just plain awesome too.5) Seasonal events like the Summer event at Risa and Q's Winter Wonderland help break the slowness in 'seasons' (aka expansions).6) Ground combat is 'okay'.  Its not up to par with the space combat, but it is certainly playable and how you best explore the main story lines.All in all, if you like Star Trek, then you'd probably like STO.  If you've never played an MMO before, or don't have much experience in the Star Trek universe, you can try this game, but be prepared for a learning curve.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												I'm not going to sit here and write out all the pros and cons of this game as plenty of other reviews have done that for you. I will however state with all the hours I've put into this game, it's one I simply keep playing. However, it's not consistent like most MMO's. It's one of those games you can walk away from, come back when a new line of content episodes comes out, event goes on, etc, and jump right back in and enjoy what's new. Star Trek Online is by far not the best Star Trek experiences, but it's certainly not the worst. It does lack the other facets we generally see in the main shows. However, it does put you in direct control of your favorite ships, most of which you can get without paying a dime. There isn't a single ounce of content within the game you can't unlock without playing the game and putting forth a bit of effort and time. That being said, all the story content is always unlocked and free to play and enjoy. Wether you just poking in from time to time to enjoy the new episodes the go live (often featuring voice actors from the shows and movies themselves), or committ the long haul and build up a fleet, build a starbase, and other assets and grow a mass armada. Star Trek Online can provide a nice enviroment to jump into and enjoy wether you're a trek fan in the slightest or not.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												I had played this for seval hundred hours a few years ago, got bored, and left.  I decided to come back to see if things had gotten more interesting.  What I found is, if you're a new player, it is nearly impossible to do much of anything in this game anymore.You will spend hours waiting for a pve que to fill up to get currency for a grindy reputation system that everyone who plays already has finished.  The EC exchange currency has been devalued to a point where anything useful is unobtainable without saving for months, or possibly years, due to the lack of ability to collect valuable loot because no one does pve ques.  The crafting system will take years to complete without any money invested, or you could throw money at the game and it will still take a year and a couple thousand dollars, just to allowed to have the random chance at something that may or may not be useful.  Many more examples exist, but to sum up the problems:  Lack of players makes a grindy game an impossible grind.  If you've never played before, don't waste your time.  If you haven't played in a while, it's more waiting for the same thing you've done already.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												My first review on here.I played this game since an old friend introduced me to it when it went free to play years ago. Even bought a lifetime supscription for the hell of it. It was on and off. It reintroduced me to Star Trek, and it can be fun to play even with some of the big problems it hasI'm going to revise this review and make it shorter and less bias. It does have some of the original cast members from the shows providing their voices of the original characters like Worf, Nog, Tuvok, etc. And Morn is played by well...Morn. It has an active but small role playing community where one could feel like a real character in the Trek universe. The guild or fleet system is pretty robust with many benefits to fleet members like access to ships and gear that only fleet members can get. The game's crew does regularly add new content almost monthly. And there is plenty to do here like random events, play adventure zones, fight in battlezones(yet few of these are pvp zones), practice your character's crafting or R&D, and play STFs and other more team-based instances with firends or complete strangers.To top it all off, it is ALL FREE! Almost anything can be bought without using any real money whatsoever. You will have to prioritize what you want if you want to play to earn, but one can just get whatever they want in the game just by grinding it. I wish I discovered this before I bought the lifetime supscription. Biggest DOH moment in my life. LOL!XD. But I still payed some money here and there to support it anyway.Now for the negatives. This game does get vary buggy. So buggy even old bugs will come back from time to time. Many of these bugs are funny, but some are game breaking like a broken mail system. And there are bugs and borderline exploiting bugs that have never been fixed for years. The community can get a bit too negative or toxic in places. And the gameplay can get unbalanced as its  seems to be about damage and not much else.Even though I give this game a thumbs down for all those cons, this game can still be vary fun. And this game is vary generous for an MMO as its vary possible to get whatever one wants without paying for it at all if one knows how to budget and set in-game financial priorities. For that sense, I recommend this game 100%. But a fair warning, it will have some serious rough edges that can hurt your experience.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												Star Trek Online is for trekkies seeking to captain their own ships. As a hardcore player/trekkie this game does that but the problem is it takes a lot of its time on space battles and on hostility against other races. Sadly, it's an MMO and we can't avoid combat as one of the main parts of the game. It would be great to explore other options such us being medical officer to being a captain of a medical ship. Having a science vessel and focus a lot on scientific journeys. Grab a battlecruiser and go head to head with the Klingons on PvP (spoilers: sadly because of the new seasons it will decreasr the number of it anymore). However, in my opnion, the story is great and explores the events and ideas which CBS decides to ignore in the television and movies, the events after Voyager. Despite the limitations of its engine, STO still provides good storylines and dialouges during your journey on become an admiral. The endgame content is also great which will make you busy and have fun. Unfortunately, if you hate doing everything over and over again, it's a grind system you'll hate. You have to grind a lot of things just to get decent stuffs especially in reputation system which kinda annoying. But for me it's still great how they put everything you want in game for free you just have to grind for it (both in good and bad circumstances). The gameplay is good and understandable. If you are a new player it provides you with enough knowledge on how the game works through tutorial story arcs (I find the Romulan tutorial arc the best intro to the game since it tells a good story while teaching you how things are done). I find a lot of complains in graphics and cash grabbing. In my opnion the graphics are optimized for low-end devices (i compared the holodeck and tribble server graphics which holodeck did lowered some graphical standards which is really helpful for players with no luxury of higher-end stuff). On the note of cash grabbing i can say that it's totally based on the person on how he plays. Before the new dawn season i was♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off because how bad my toon having crap ship and equipment. Turns out it was my fault for not being careful on making a skill build. After new dawn, which made a new skill system, it really improved my toon a lot. I had more skills more skill bonuses and such. Even with non-epic weapons i can still do pretty huge impacts on pves and pvps. Last but not the least, yoy can pretty much get everything for free (on the bright side you can have all the ships in the game in  the tribble server if you want to).Overall this game is 8/10 for me

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												MMOs are tricky things, and what they do more than anything else is excel in one area and totally crash and burn in another. Star Trek Online is, in this regard, a quintessential MMO. When you are piloting your ship, its an engaging, albeit repetitive experience that is well executed, beautifully rendered and full of promise. When you walk around on your own two feet, you have to wonder why the developers even bothered. Recent reworking of many portions of this game have improved the overall experience, but the planet-bound experience is pretty miserable. The graphics for the 3rd person experience are shockingly bad, the movement is relatively humorous, but not necessarily in a good way, the animation is weak and the combat while better than you might imagine, the AI of your "crew mates" is disappointing. In contrast, the space-faring portion of the game is, if you pardon the pun, stellar. Certainly flying in circles during drawn out battles can be boring, but there is enough going on, with the strategic choices, the balancing of shields, positioning in 3 dimensional space to best use your speed, or lack there of, weapons and special tactics can make even the more tedious battles at least moderately interesting. The space map is less pretty than it should be, but it's certainly not terrible and transwarp travel can get you around quickly at least in one direction. there is some charm to having access to some of the known "landmarks" such as DS9 as well. Other aspects of the game are generally typical affair - items are colour coded, a la everquest and world of warcraft, and as a free-to-play, most the desirables are available, for a price. For free, the game is worth it for the space alone. For a full fledged, MMO experience which will capture your imagination and keep you coming back for more? Go elsewhere. Even for free, there are better choices.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
												Star Trek Online has been consistently high quality. I am a lifetime subscriber with no regrets. Expansions in this game are gratis. The new ships are not. If you treat the game like Pokemon, you can by the Legacy of Romulus or Delta Rising packs to get access to everything (and some exlusive perks), but you need not do this. Almost everything you want can be earned in game.Lets be clear about the busines model though. You want F2P and refuse to pay anything? You will be punished by an endless grind for Dilithium to sell for Zen to buy the ship you want. Dilithum is capped at 8,000 refined per day. The average going rate has been around 160 Dil per Zen lately. At this rate, if you wanted a Zen ship worth 2500 Zen, you need to sell 400,000 Dil, or spend 50 days to earn it. Now you have your ship! Keep grinding that Dil so you can get the really good gear on it! Everything that is important costs Dil.On the other side are Zen sellers. People who put $5 on their account and buy 80,000 Dil on demand. These are Cryptic's customers. I have seen a lot of complaints about this, or claims that is is Buy2Win. It's not a competition, and without a revenue stream there would be no game to play. Remeber that when you sell Dil, you are requesting other people subsidize your play time and the economy that controls this is regulated to Cryptics benefit.One of the negatives of this game is the parent company. CBS has a strong hold on certain aspects of the game. Want to fly the NCC-1701 at endgame? Sorry, it's a 1st tier gesture that costs 500 Zen. Romulan T'liss Warbird? Same deal, no dice. You get this wonderful ship to start, but you have to use the T'varo from Enterprise, which is technically and "older" model. Want to play an android like Data? Flat no, the reason given is that Star Trek is about the human experience. The current Enterprise (NCC-1701-F) is actually captained by an Andorian these days...So the big positive, if you chose to embrace it, is that STO is a "popcorn" type game. There are loads of content, but most of it has no impetus. Jump into a PvE queue and go. Jump into a system and do an away mission. It all earns you experience, energy credts, various faction marks, and of course Dilthium. Play one mission or play all night. There is no requirement for heavy investment of time like other MMOs.Overall, I recommend the game. There are nits that you will see as well, but they grow over time. Many quality of life changes are in flux with each update, so the game is actually improving. If there is something that could be done right now to make it better, it would be to create daily seed missions that drive and reward people for the content they are currently missing by waiting for it to be spoon fed.

												This is a game I played with the intent to dislike it. I mean, a franchise I did not care for, a MMO, sci fi setting..Guess what- it didn't happen as the world was well presented, immersive, and I was given total freedom to set up my character, own my own ship, and even configure that one to my likings generously. You can play it entirely free, the added bonuses of subscribing and/or buying cash store items tend to be rather marginal, I ended up paying mainly to support the developers, but at its core it is still a nice looking RPG-style thing with variety between character-ground combat, or exciting ship to ship fights, and no need to do boring grind quests as you can level up with an interesting storyline mission. There is still ongoing support for this, too. watch out though, you might learn a bit more about the series than you wanted..

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												I cannot recommend this game enough to all lovers of Star Trek, outer space, spaceship simulators, MMOs, RPGs, and futuristic battles! It's even pretty good for people who like single players--for the most part, people will ignore you in group places like Earth Spacedock, unless you talk in instance chat or interact with them in some way, and the rest of the time you can go off into your own mission instances.The game is free to play with optional purchases, and is actually fun even without them. Dedicated players can earn some of the paid items by grinding the Energy Credits and buying stuff from other players on the exchange, so there's a lot of flexibility. It's a lot of fun to play with friends, with whom you can form a fleet and gain other benefits, like fleet credits to purchase things from your fleet store--But the biggest benefit of playing with friends is buddying up to run enjoyable missions together and have a blast, or maybe have an impromtu party in Club 47 in Earth Spacedock. (no kidding!) Other fun things are pets that follow you around, and breeding tribbles (yes!) by keeping a tribble in your inventory and adding a food item. If you add one tribble and one food, you can control which tribble eats which food and what they breed. There are charts showing what tribbles breed what offspring for what foods, for the dedicated breeders--but if you just want to casually breed them, just throw one in your inventory or bank with a load of food and watch them breed--like tribbles! lol Petting tribbles gives you (and your bridge officers) buffs that last for about an hour, long enough to run a mission. The buffs can be extra damage output, damage resistance, or health regen--or even a combination of the above! (Klingons can't get these buffs, sadly, since they and tribbles have a mutual dislike). For the fashion-minded, there are many uniforms (from all the TV series and movies!) and off duty uniforms that you can get/buy and mix and match! And after you've got the perfect outfit, visit the arms dealer or weapons master to get upgrades and armor--or jaunt over to Vulcan, Andoria, and/or Risa for some fun exploring and a vacation! You can investigate logic on Vulcan, engage in Andorian hand-to-hand combat and see their parks, or play on the beach at Risa! While you're doing all that, if you're not using the new in-game voice chat to talk to all your awesome buddies, you can tune in to one of the star trek radio stations to hear some great music and humorous trek related "commercials"! Lovers of crafting will find a cool crafting system based from Memory Alpha. Captains scan systems to find "anomalies" of different types from which crafting is done, and when they find some, they get to play a mini-game of matching a wave frequency in a limited time to gain more of whatever they've found.For those who look for the rare and limited, there's some rare items, ships, officers, and equipment gained from particpating in various events, doing some harder missions, or higher level crafting, or lock boxes from the store.You start out as an ensign at Starfleet Academy on Earth (if you play Federation--if you play Klingon you start on Q'ronos and you can now play Romulan too) and gradually make your way up the ranks, getting better and better ships, gear, and bridge officers. There are two modes to the game--a spaceship simulator type space mode, and an RPG/FPS type ground mode. Everyone plays both at different times in missions, just like the TV series' and movies. Definitely give this game a try--it's got a lot to it and you might like it for its game qualities even if you don't really like Star Trek--buf if you DO, you won't want to miss this. :)

content:
Posted: November 10, 2013
												Star Trek Online has been consistently high quality. I am a lifetime subscriber with no regrets. Expansions in this game are gratis. The new ships are not. If you treat the game like Pokemon, you can by the Legacy of Romulus or Delta Rising packs to get access to everything (and some exlusive perks), but you need not do this. Almost everything you want can be earned in game.Lets be clear about the busines model though. You want F2P and refuse to pay anything? You will be punished by an endless grind for Dilithium to sell for Zen to buy the ship you want. Dilithum is capped at 8,000 refined per day. The average going rate has been around 160 Dil per Zen lately. At this rate, if you wanted a Zen ship worth 2500 Zen, you need to sell 400,000 Dil, or spend 50 days to earn it. Now you have your ship! Keep grinding that Dil so you can get the really good gear on it! Everything that is important costs Dil.On the other side are Zen sellers. People who put $5 on their account and buy 80,000 Dil on demand. These are Cryptic's customers. I have seen a lot of complaints about this, or claims that is is Buy2Win. It's not a competition, and without a revenue stream there would be no game to play. Remeber that when you sell Dil, you are requesting other people subsidize your play time and the economy that controls this is regulated to Cryptics benefit.One of the negatives of this game is the parent company. CBS has a strong hold on certain aspects of the game. Want to fly the NCC-1701 at endgame? Sorry, it's a 1st tier gesture that costs 500 Zen. Romulan T'liss Warbird? Same deal, no dice. You get this wonderful ship to start, but you have to use the T'varo from Enterprise, which is technically and "older" model. Want to play an android like Data? Flat no, the reason given is that Star Trek is about the human experience. The current Enterprise (NCC-1701-F) is actually captained by an Andorian these days...So the big positive, if you chose to embrace it, is that STO is a "popcorn" type game. There are loads of content, but most of it has no impetus. Jump into a PvE queue and go. Jump into a system and do an away mission. It all earns you experience, energy credts, various faction marks, and of course Dilthium. Play one mission or play all night. There is no requirement for heavy investment of time like other MMOs.Overall, I recommend the game. There are nits that you will see as well, but they grow over time. Many quality of life changes are in flux with each update, so the game is actually improving. If there is something that could be done right now to make it better, it would be to create daily seed missions that drive and reward people for the content they are currently missing by waiting for it to be spoon fed.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2012
												Star Trek Online is the first MMO I've ever given a really fair shake to. Generally, the MMO formula doesn't appeal to me, but after reading several positive reviews, I gave this one a try.The game itself is very attractive, especially with the graphical settings turned all the way up. This is definitely a Star Trek universe, with lots of visual cues  from the TV shows.This game delivers lots of solo content, which is what piqued my interest. And it's true, this MMO is mostly a solo venture. You'll see other ships flying around, and other people at stardock, but you rarely interact with them. It's like 1,000 people playing solitare together.Star Trek Online has a compelling space-combat system. You can really trick up your ship, too, if you care to. But this doesn't save the game from it's very repetitive missions, and very complicated economy. End result: I lost interest. Total time invested, about 10 hours.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												UPDATED 11/20/15:  Several new changes to the game have been made, and so far, they seem to be positive ones.- Separate personal space and ground traits.  FINALLY!  No more switching traits during a story mission!- Armadas.  These are in essence "metafleets" of up to 13 different fleets each.  One is an Alpha that can invite three Beta fleets, and each Beta can invite three Gamma fleets.  Each fleet can donate toward other armada members' projects.  This feature has potential but I don't believe it's been fully realized just yet.  It does come in handy for using fleet marks when your home fleet is already at max level on all projects.- Dry Dock.  Allows you to free up active ship slots for use.  Only complaint I have with this is that the equipment on a ship being dry docked doesn't stay with the ship but returns to your inventory.  Use of the loadout feature can mitigate this, but loadouts are still a bit buggy for some players.- Admiralty.  Basically, this is a duty officer (DOFF) system using ships instead of people.  Each ship in your inventory generates a card for the Admiralty system with fixed engineering, tactical, and science specs.  Missions show the required total amount of each spec, and you can slot up to three ships on each mission.  It has a pretty good XP return on some missions, so it takes some of the drudge out of leveling from 50 to 60.As of late, it does feel like the devs are listening more to the players and making useful changes instead of just cosmetic ones.  The storyline is maturing well, though it does seem that exploration is again taking second place to combat, even though Cryptic indicated this season would be more about exploration.  I'll withhold judgement on that until the season has progressed further.Dilithium prices for ZEN have skyrocketed since my original review.  On average, they're running in the 220-240 dil / 1 ZEN range.ORIGINAL REVIEW (12/27/2014)For those who eat, drink, sleep, breathe, and live Trek, Star Trek Online is as close as you can get to being a part of the universe, short of time travel.  This isn't to say that the game doesn't have flaws, but overall it works quite well.PROSYou get to fly and even (somewhat) modify canon starships, plus some pretty cool designs not seen in films or on TV.The game is rich with content...in fact, it's a bit staggering just how much you can actually do in game.  Colonization?  Yep.  Ground fighting?  Got it.  Space battles?  You bet.  Exploration?  It's in there.  I strongly recommend that you read and bookmark the Star Trek Online wiki.Customization of both ships and characters is possible, though more extensive customization will cost you eventually (either money or lots of grinding).  Still, the amount you can do in F2P is good.The story arcs are interesting for the most part, and mesh well with canon Star Trek.  Finding out what happened in the Delta Quadrant after Voyager had been there is a good example...you'll also get to find out what happened to the Jenolan Dyson Sphere after Starfleet sent two science vessels to study it, how some of your favorite characters turned out and what they're doing circa 2410, the name given to Species 8472, and other tidbits along the way.Some of the special events are fun and funny, especially the Winter Wonderland event in progress as of this writing (12/27/2014), and offer decent rewards.CONSIf you don't like grinding, don't expect to get too far too fast.  There's plenty of it.  For example, you can collect all the dilithium ore you want, but you can only refine 8,000 per day plus a few small bonuses here and there.  As you unlock reputation levels, refined dilithium is required to purchase the stronger and better items...some require 15K, some require 32K, and so on.  That means you're going to be doing lots of minding...er...grining...er...GRINDING.To really customize ships and characters, you'll be spending ZEN (Cryptic's currency) which costs either real money or LOTS of dilithium.  Typical cost as of this writing is 165 dilithium to 1 ZEN.  Considering that most of the best items for purchase run anywhere from 500-2500 ZEN, I'll let you do the math.There are a couple of long-standing bugs in the game (read the wiki and the game site for more info) that can be either a minor nuisance or a major pain, depending on your tolerance level.PET PEEVEI thought dilithium could be recrystallized as early as in Star Trek IV, which was confirmed in TNG.  So why do I have to keep mining dilithium for everything?  Can't I just reuse a small amount?  :POVERALLRecommended.

												Loved this game. I've been playing since 2012 and this is literally one of the best free MMOs around. The ground combat mechanics are not exactly my taste as a I prefer FPS, but space combat is amazing. My only complaint about space combat is that it is set on a 2-D plane (as in you can't do barrel rolls with your ship or fly around upside down and what not). The story arcs are also great and I'm glad that they have revamped the older stories to make them more interesting. I do not like the fact that you have to basically pay to win in PvP and kind of ruins the fun.  All in all, STO is great in general. Many people favor ship to ship combat over ground combat, others like the latter, and really it's all up to you.

												I am a Star Trek Beta player with a lifetime edition and stopped playing at some point. If you start reading my review you might think "why is he not recommending the game after listing all the cool features?" Continue reading and you might discover the sad truth behind the wall of content.Back in the days I played Klingon fighting proudly for my faction. The crafting system is fun and also the Officer missions. You can send your crew to get recources for you or even different currencies you can spend for equipment. The stories are really cool and I can recommend the Missions which take you back in time to experience old star trek episodes. I recently joined again to see what changed. They implemented a lot of new features, quests and events so a PvE player might be very satisfied BUT if you are looking for PvP you should look elsewhere. The entire game changed from different fighting factions to a bunch of excel sheet reading damage maximizing grannys in pink pyjamas. They only maximize their gear to get better gear and to sit in their space stations dreaming of big fights which will never happen as nobody ever plays any PvP. So if you look for a complex game with seasonal events and story you are at the right place but you will never use your gear in player combat ever again. So even if I have a lifetime abbonement I will not bother downloading the game again. The Peace corp took over the game which is sad and destroyed the game at least for me.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												If you're a Star Trek fan, then you'll want to play this. Obviously, PW makes their money by having microtransactions. However, despite this, it's still equitable for the F2P player. As the game description says, it's like being inside the show. Sector narration is done by Leonard Nimoy, Michael Dorn reprises his role as Worf and there are other familiar characters. If you're a Star Trek fanboy like me, then you'll see this game as a time suck. It's not the most visually stunning game out there but it's a lot of fun.Edit 1: Recently, Tim Russ reprised his role as Tuvok during a Dyson Sphere event. Edit 2: Now that I have more time on record, I can add a few things. My view about the game above is still the same. However, I will take the time to add a few things. As I said before, it helps if you're a Star Trek fan to begin with. You get to play with the ship types you saw in the different series and you get to visit the places you could only see on TV. I will caution you that the story takes place some 30 years after the events of the last Star Trek movie (no, not the new ones...I mean Nemesis). If you take that into consideration, you'll realize that it's a whole new take on the franchise. Edit 3: I mentioned before that there are microtransactions. Really, the best ships are there and it wouldn't hurt to drop some money on Zen to get a few of them. That being said, you seriously don't have to. What you're really paying for are the consoles that come with them that give you some neat abilities. When you hit max level, you can get all kinds of equipment by running PvE/PvP queues that evens the playing field. So, you don't need to buy anything at all. Edit 4: With the Legacy of Romulus update they did, the current mechanics seem to favor the Romulans since you can choose a side. Their ships seems to have the advantage in fights and function in multiple capacities. That being said, the disparity isn't actually there. Each race has their strong suit and each race is deficient somwhere.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												It's free so give it a try, but don't give them your money.I had an issue recently where an in-game item that I had paid money towards was accidentally deleted because of a bug. The support department refused to return it, didn't have the decency to tell me why they wouldn't/couldn't and even threatened to ban my account if I pressed the matter.The developers of the game openly have contempt for their players calling them morons, exploiters, whiners, you name it. There seems to be a real toxic attitude behind the scenes at certain levels of this company.For a review of the game...I'm a life-long Star Trek fan. I came here looking for a fix after not being impressed by the new movies and I found it for a while. There is plenty to explore and the ships are done well and can be fun to fly.Then you start to realise that every mission is essentially the same. Warp in, kill a few waves of bad guys and warp out. Starfleet don't do diplomacy or exploration anymore, they just kill everything. No questions asked.The endgame is the same. Repeating the same few missions over and over to gain slightly better equipment to do the same few missions over and over but slightly quicker. Everything is a pointless grind. The only real reason to stay is the friends you make along the way.To summarise, it's a moderately ok space shooter that plays upon your nostalgia and love of a tv show with skins, music and a bit of voice acting. Everything is a grind and hidden behind timegates and endless grind/paywalls. To make any real progress you either need a fat wallet or to play the game like a full-time job.There are far better gaming experiences out there.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												Star Trek Online used to be better before Delta Rising. The main offenses after the new expansion lie in the realms of balance. Release after release, there seems to be very little deliberation about releasing new items and mechanics. They are, for the most part, terribly broken. PvP is utterly a joke, and even PvE now suffers the consequences, as the empty queues can tell.Many other systems are equally aggravating. Crafting and upgrading, both tied behind time gates and random number generators. When you craft or upgrade an item, you cannot choose the mods - they're random. Which may turn your crafted item into vendor trash, and your resources spent for nothing. Not to mention the terrible long time gates -- 20 hours to craft a single endgame item. I haven't seen any of this in the other good MMOs I used to play.To not be completely negative about this, certain areas of the game get proper attention and listen to player feedback. They're mostly related to art: costumes, ship models, and environment. The new Club 47, released a couple weeks prior to the date of this post, is truly awesome. But you can only go so far dancing all night long in this game, if anywhere.As a fan of the game genre (flying a starship, having a crew), it is sad to see this game being destroyed by poor development decisions. If you are a fan of Star Trek (I am not really), you may find the stories interesting.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												I'm a long time player and have only seen this game improve. There have been a few hiccups here and there but ultimately the game only gets better. They have a great free-to-play model. If you have the time, anything in the game can be had without spending a dime. The best  end-game gear is earned in game, not by purchasing it in the cash shop. So, no...this game isn't 'pay-to-win'. Cash shop ships, costumes, personnel, etc... can be purchased as a free-to-play player without spending a cent. You just have to earn in game currency known as Dilithium, and then trade it in the dilithium exchange market for Zen (which is the cash bought currency used in the cash shop). There are a few exceptions to this. There are a few rewards for subscribers and lifetime account holders that can only be had by purchasing or subscribing, but none of these rewards are game breaking, nor do they effect game play.
