number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Star Trek online is a game which follows in the footsteps of the franchise T.v shows in that the story and characters are always respectful of the lore but like the new movies alot of the plot revolves around time-travel and dimensional travel but so what, it seems the new season is focused on previously untold and unexplored concepts around Millenia-dormant threats from numerous ancient races which push the boundaries of the  lore. I think many of the story mission sagas would actually make good comics or novels but most players lament not having conversation choices impact the story in a significant way, even though there are many opportunities to play as evil or good. The lengthy Rep system and new Research schools and specialization trees cretainly breathed life into the game for dedicated players, as well as new ships available to all players who complete events during winter and summer. "No player need be left behind" in terms of ships and equipment, if you trade longer playtime for an outright buy. Important here to note is the store in this game has exorbitant prices, a ship can cost you $30 dollars only to be outclassed later and there are many "packs" that range in the hundreds of dollars, "WTH"? right? but believe me, I've played a long time and any player can earn and buy any ship the free way and it won't take THAT long maybe like a saving a month in-game at the most for a good ship. Lock box ships can also be purchased on the exchange I know many people who get them this way. All in all, what with events and discounts and giveaway's and dedication, I don't feel leftout as a non-subscriber and over the years I can say the game earned what I spent, at least I wasn't dumb enough to get into Lockbox keys but If you want to gamble 100's of dollars you deserve a good ship! crazy. Anyway, Graphics are good with many story options, some actually stunning enviroments like summer Risa, hours of fun for Trek fans or sci-fi ship combat fans, although ship combat is some of the best I've played, its done in a third person view with a more stategic take in that the skills and manouvering you use in combat are all important since all  combat is auto-aimed. Same with ground combat strategy is all important and headshots non-existant but for a skill tree which gives a crit bonus for aimed shots.  Anyhow, I would say check it out, I don't offer many criticisims because the game is quite open ended and everyone finds a different nche of activities they like, Over-all it's impressive work but I would say suffers like all MMO's because they also incorporate alot of "mindless" grindiness into into it, if you know what I mean, something like being presented with a mountain of dull paperwork to do to get some rewards but again it's up to the player if they "feel" like it or not.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Ah~ STO. I've played STO on and off over the course of it's lifetime and still find it fun to play.Star Trek Online is an MMORPG set in the Star Trek universe. In STO you have two types of gameplay: Ground and Space. In ground missions you and your Away Team beam down to planets, derelict ships and stations and asteroid bases and clear them of hostiles all while receiving nice little spoonfuls of lore, story and EXP/Loot. Space combat pits your ship against other ships for similar rewards. It has all the staples that you would come to expect from a modern MMO. >Group Finder>"Guilds" called Fleets>Party system>Auction House>Huge amounts of cosmetics for your character>Extensive crafting system>Fleet Bases (Guild Halls) that you can upgrade.>Hundreds of ships (Each with customizable looks)The only downside is the dated graphics and game engine. The gameplay, however, is fantastic and quite fun. Explore anywhere at any time. All in all, it's one of those games that if you enjoy it, you'll find yourself coming back for more.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Fun game (mostly - apart from elements influenced by the cash shop) but by far the worst customer service you'll find.All up I would have spent a bit over $300 on the lifetime sub and various ships. But when my main character became really badly bugged, affecting something I had spent money on in the cash shop - and it was affecting other players too - could I get them to fix it?No.I bugrepped it. Months went by. Nothing. I bugrepped it again. Waited again. Nothing. So I lodged a ticket with customer service. After jumping through hoops (taking screenshots etc.) to prove there was a problem they told me they couldn't fix it and I should bugrep it. Which I'd done. They also specifically told me never to contact CS again about this problem or any like it.Email records from CS were produced.So nearly a year later I lodge a complaint with BBB. PWE's initial response was dishonest - saying I should have contacted CS, as if I hadn't. They then ignored BBB's attempts to follow up with them for several months until they gave up and advised me to lodge a complaint with the US Federal Trade Commission.Meanwhile in their forums, their head of community relations took to slagging me off and perfectly innocent posts of mine were being moderated away. And their developers tried to make me out to be unco-operative, when I had been anything but.Eventually in the thread about this bug I told them about BBB's advice to complain to the US FTC. Voila! The bug was fixed fixed. That's all it takes to get bugs fixed in this game. A year of bug reporting, CS tickets, complaints to consumer groups and threatening them with an FTC complaint.I had played and enjoyed the game for a very long time (outside Steam), and spent a lot of money on it, but when a company behaves like this - well no game is worth that. Plus given how aggressive and dishonest they were in relation to the BBB complaint and in their forum, I could never trust that they wouldn't mess with my characters.Steer clear.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												I know I don't really have the hours recorded on steam but I played this game for a year or two before the Romulan expansion, the community was great, including the resident troll named Butts :) (I have to admit, his trolling was kind of endearing and I kind of miss the way they trolled it had a semblance of respect for people who weren't butt hurt about it LOL).Also, I've played twoother PWI games, Forsaken World and Perfect World and yes, in some of these games you CAN earn currency to buy what the P2W players buy BUT it's going to take you forever and a year to actually get the currency all the while P2Ws are kicking your♥♥♥♥♥everywhere in PvP, superior gems and the like.My very first review, here we go:The Good:- The Community was great- Very friendly even if I wasn't a Trekkie.- The ship fighting was great, I loved every minute of it. (Buff, buff, buff, Guns to lower shields. projectile to destroy the hull, cloak, rinse and repeat)- The character customization had a lot of options. (What I thought was tanned was actually kind of Orange LOL)- The missions were also pretty great, just the right amount of challenge.- The inside of the ships were magnificent.- Pet Varens in one of the ships.- Space and ship graphics were good.- And holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ your guild house is a massive space ship/station, that is all.The Bad:- The non-ship combat was clunky. (Clunky drop kick was my favorite thing.)- The grinding was just... Mind numbing.- Character graphics looked weirdly like rubber.- The physics for out of ship combat was weird.The Ugly:- PWI's Free-to-play but pay-to-win scheme.Would I recommend this game? The honest answer is yes, it's a good game and if you have money to spare or parents who can spot for your game cards then why not buy a few account upgrades or IRL cash ships. If you're into the long term grinding experience then you can eventually buy ships that are decent with in-game currency. Yes, you can complete the game without shelling out cash except for buying the DLCs.Do I hate the PWI experience? A little bit, yes.Will I not recommend this game simply because it's a PWI game? No, the game deserves it's praise and it's time, Cryptic made this game, not PWI. PWI is simply milking the game for all it's worth because they're a business and that's how they choose to run things.

Product received for free
												I've been playing this game casually for quite a while now. I've had nothing but good experiences with this game. The depth, and scale is amazing, and the player-made "Foundry" missions provide an extra layer of depth to the already story-rich gameplay. Playing Dabo on Deep Space 9, flying around the Risa Summer Resort with my floater rental, and generally exploring the galaxy are a few of my favorite things in this game.I chose to disregard the negative reviews I saw before trying STO out, and I'm glad I did. This game is fun for Trekkies, AND everyone else that loves a content-rich MMO.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												Played a tonne of this just after it went F2P and before it went on Steam.Really enjoyable space combat game combined with a pretty lackluster ground combat portion. The story missions are pretty enjoyable compared to most MMO's, and make you feel involved in the plot rather than just as a witness to it. Also unlike other MMOs you aren't stuck doing gathering/kill quests to advance, but instead you are doing stuff to advance storylines. It was refreshing to play through an MMO that felt more like a proper story-based game.At times it feels like a strange fanfic of what happens next in the original universe, but it's still Star Trek. Sure the DS9 and Voyager continuations can make little sense, but it's still a fun time to see those characters return.If you're a Star Trek fan there is more than enough in here to delight you for a good long while.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												Star Trek Online: Agents of Yesterday - What a steaming pile of crap. I've been enjoying the STO universe now since it's release (even pre-ordered it). It's the only place where I can still immerse myself in the Star Trek universe I've come to love. And while it's not a AAA title, or even a B title, it has always done a fairly good job at remaining true to the universe and being an enjoyable little game. Unfortunately, Agents of Yesterday, in my opinion, is their first complete failure to produce anything good. For starters, I've never held any interest in the TOS universe. If someone made a TOS game, I'd most certainly completely ignore it. So right off the bat, this expansion has already failed me.Add in the excruiatingly bad lag that this expansion introduced to all the instances, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Star Trek reboot movie ships, and the most ridiculous explanation for making them equivilant to 24th century technology and we're already off to a terrible start.Not only this, but in order to take advantage of all the new story and content, you cannot continue with your pre-existing character. Oh sure, 24th century characters get to run a couple of missions for Daniels and access to three new instances, but we practically get left out of any content for the 'season'.This is one embarassingly pathetic expansion.Edit: Corrected spelling mistakes.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												Space, the final frontier. These are the voyages of you, your crew, and your starship. Your ongoing mission; to explore strange new worlds. To seek out new life, and new civilizations. TO BOLDLY GO WHERE NO ONE HAS GONE BEFORE!This mmo set several years after the events of the amazing TV series puts you into the Star Trek universe, where you create your captain, pick your crew and pilot your own starship across the cosmos as a member of Starfleet, the Klingon Defense Force, or the Romulan Empire. Explore new systems, sign treaties and decimate your enemies while piloting your favorite ships from series and customizing them to your own accord. The gameplay starts off a little slow, sense you start off with the worst ship in the game and then end up fighting the strongest enemy in the Star Trek universe just in the tutorial alone (in the Starfleet storyline anyway) but as you level up, grab some upgrades, comission new bridge officers and then acquire better starships it gets REALLY REALLY FUN. Plus, the PvE is also the absolute best of any mmo I've ever played.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												I haven't played Star Trek Online since it launched back in February of 2010. I can say without a doubt that I was excited for this game when I first pre-ordered it. And then I played it. It wasn't the worst MMO I had ever played but it definitely didn't live up to my expectations. The ground combat was clunky, the early story and missions were boring and there was little to no voice acting. About the only thing I did like was the ship to ship combat. But that couldn't save it for me. I just couldn't bring myself to buy the full version. Now, 4 years later, I find myself picking it up again after hearing about how many changes have been made. It piqued my curiosity so I began to play last week. Trust me when I say, this isn't the same game that I decided against buying 4 years ago. Pretty much everything has been revamped. The game is now in it's 8th major update since launch, so there's quite a bit of new content. Starting out, the first thing I noticed that the whole intro has been scrapped and is now completely different. Instead of finding yourself in the middle of a Borg attack, you are now an Ensign at Starfleet Academy, who has just graduated and been given his (or her) first assignment. You have been chosen to be the First Officer aboard a not-so-new Miranda Class ship. Your first mission is to go out and collect some data samples with your cadet crew. Then things go wrong.The story is engrossing from the very first moments. It's a major step up from what used to be. Then there's the C-Store. Currently, the game is Free To Play, which is good for someone like me, who's on a budget. Usually I hate the Free to Play options in games because I feel like my version is severely diminished. That's not the case in Star Trek Online. As a matter of fact, aside from some nifty cosmetic stuff and things like different styles of ships, I haven't really seen anything different between the Free to Play stuff and Paid subscribers. There are a few things, such as more costume slots or extra Duty Officers, which are nice but not necessarily hindering you if you don't have them. What really impresses me about the C-Store is the ability to buy Zen (the currency used in the Cash Shop) with in-game Dilithium. Admittedly, it's at a pretty steep cost. About 125 Dilithium per 1 Zen. That means that if you want to buy the cheapest item in the C-Store, you'll need about 31,000 Dilithium saved up. Which is going to take you quite a bit of grinding. But still. The option is there and that's more than most other games will give you. Overall, I have been having a blast. Currently I've only made it to Level 20 (Commander) and I have yet to join a Fleet but that hasn't stopped the fun from rolling in. The only thing I could really ask for is some good PVP or better PVE Instance queues. But that's not to say I wont keep playing. At the moment, I am going to give it a 7 out of 10. I've seen some bugs but those are nothing that can't be fixed in later patches.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												STO is a very well executed space MMORPG. The story is relatively engaging for an MMO, and the graphics are nice. If you are even a little bit of a trekkie, there is a great deal of fun to be had here.That said, like most MMOs, it gets samey rather fast. It takes longer than most, which is something I really have to give the developers a great deal of kudos for, but eventually, you're going to feel like you're doing the same thing over and over again. Something that helps combat this is that it has the concept of user-created missions. You can actually get on a special account type and create missions for others to play. These range from the awesome to the "meh", and is another unique feature to STO.The fact that this is free to play, and the paid addons are reasonable, makes it definitely one of the better MMO's out there. If you liked Earth and Beyond back in the day, you'll probably like this. Recommended!

content:

												Surprisingly good. I have not tried PvP, but throughout the PvE/story missions, I have never felt pressured to spend any money on the game. You unlock a new ship every 10 levels, and new ships are occasionally available for free during event missions. Every ingame thing you might need (gear, bridge officers, deck officers) is available from (relatively easily) obtainable resources in game as well as money.  The endgame isn't lacking in PvE, as of this writing there is a battlegrounds area for ground combat, and plenty of task force missions for space combat.In summary, the game is worth taking a shot at, even if you aren't a diehard trek fan.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2012
												If you're a Trek fan, there's a lot to love.  You'll recognize people, places, things, and plots from across Trek's 50 year history, you can even play a TOS-era character as an alternate start method.  Gameplay is very combat heavy, but this *is* an MMO. The F2P model is very fair (if you're not trying to PVP at a high level, anyway), and you can finish the game without spending a single dime if you wish.  Zen (the store currency) can be bought with in-game resources, but even not counting that you can use entirely free ships and weapons to finish the story and dive into the endgame, it's just a bit harder.  The endgame grind can, admittedly, be a slog.  Mostly in time, not in repetiveness if you plan it right, but it's still there.  That grind is only as important as you want it to be though.STO is not without its problems, but that's not uncommon with MMOs.  Yes, there's bugs, yes, it can be laggy, but for most people it's not so bad as to hurt the experience.  If you want a fun romp full of Trek nostalgia, STO is worth a look.

												If you like Star Trek then this is game is a must play... you may really fall for it and want to keep playing. I played this several years back and I must say it has come a long way in how the game unfolds and is presented. You really feel like part of Star Trek universe with the music, voice work, and the types of missions you get. I still don't have a lot of time in but because it is totally free to start playing it is easy to recommend.  The ship battles are pretty cool and have rather simple but still rewarding strategies even at the beginning. It isn't complex but again if you like Star Trek it gives you that feel like you are having those battles in space with a star ship. I'm hoping as you level and continue to explore there will be more depth.  The ground combat is pretty weak. Presentation is better and the integration of all the parts is so much better than a few years ago it is comendable. Still it's a shame the quality isn't even up to where Star Wars online's work is and not nearly as fullfilling as a Rift, WoW or Guild Wars 2 scheme.  I like that despite some of the weaker pieces the game still has that Star Trek flavor that makes it worth playing for those who like the movies and TV shows.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 6
												This was the game that got me back into gaming back in 2011 after a long hiatus from games. In 2017, the game engine and play mechanics has aged pretty badly (they weren't astounding even in 2011). However, if you enjoy pretending you are in Star Fleet flying your ships around, it's fun to collect all the ships and play dress-up with your captain and crew. It might be a different experience after Free2Play launched, which makes the experience feel "less pure" because a lot of things are now unlocks that used to be part of the core subscription experience, but it is not as bad as Free2Play Star Wars: The Old Republic (ugh). I'm rating it a YES because I have fond memories of it and enjoyed it as a game that is a scaffold for my own storytelling in the Star Trek universe. It has a very flexible, if dated, character editor and you can create your own missions in "The Foundry". It won't cost you anything to try it as it is F2P. If you are looking for a polished game with more rewarding action gameplay mechanisms, however, I would not recommend it. It is probably the most polished and complete Star Trek game out there now, but there is little competition. MASS EFFECT this is not.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2012
												STO has been my game of choice since participating in the closed beta. Though it suffered from a difficult start and bumps along the way, the game has continued to evolve and grow. The PvE aspect of the game has become expansive and can seem a bit overwhelming at times for new players. With so many systems integrated over the years from Duty officer missions and abilities, Reputations systems, countless gearsets/combinations, greatly improved crafting system finally in place, and of course the missions both official and player created, the game feels mostly complete and whole finally. Like any MMO it will continue to evolve and not always in a direction everyone will be happy with. That said the Development team generally gets it right. The free to play aspect is among the best I have encountered in all my thirty years as a gamer and the last ten or so with my encounters with free to play models. There are items a player would need to purchase for endgame such as ship upgrade tokens, fleet modules, and a removal of the energy credit cap. All items mentioned can be purchased with either cashy money or in game dillithium converted to game currency through the dillithium exchange. Now for the bad. The PvP is woefully lacking in improvement and attention since launch. While it can be entertaining the public qeues are so one sided and have been since a few months after launch. Abilities are often unblanaced to a fault. Often you are stuck with either the cookie cutter flavor of the month builds, abilites, Duty officer combinations. Even if you have a great build you can expect to lose unless you have a mostly coordinated team all geared and built to provide the DPS and support needed to win. I would not recommend PvP to any new player without first consulting with a PvP group in game sadly. As for the bad part of the PvE side, The Special task Force missions and Advanced Qeues have become a DPS race. You need to participate in advanced Qeues to get items needed for reputation gear. Often if you need reputation gear you are not in a position to contribute much to the team. another. Another issues is the complete lack of need for the Enginner and Science professions in game. In space missions and PvP they are vastly less valuable than a Tactical captain because they cannot produce the same kind of DPS. Having had thirty eight Max level characters before Delta Rising and Six after fully geared and tested to a minimum of 15k DPS and some to as high as 35k (Good but far from great measured by the Infected Space Advanced Standard) and often coordinating for PvP and having written a few of the build guides over the years I feel qualified to say this. It is just the nature of the game for now and may change with balancing as time goes on. On a final note for the PvE is a lack of attention to some bugs, though not game breaking, they can be irritating.All that said if you are still here I completely recommend this game. The good vastly outweighs the bad and I will continue to play so long as this is true. See you out there.

												Yes you can probably see that I've played this game... a lot. The writers keep coming out with new content and events to keep you interested long after the standard missions have dried up.Character customisation allows you to redesign your character again and again and with new costume options available to everyone fairly soon after you dive in you can keep tweaking that look to match your characters' personality.The best experience however is to play in a team as this will bring greater rewards and teach you a thing or two. If teamwork is your thing then join up with an established fleet or take the plunge yourself and create a fleet just for your friends. Fleet management is, I will warn you, a time consuming and stressful at times vocation but it can and does bring its' own rewards.So many dimenions to the economies of the various currencies out there to mention here but a shrewd investor can actually make Zen (PWE's in-game currency) from the dilithium market.Overall, I'd recommend this to my friends as you have the option of playing for free and if you like it, you can always spend a bit of pocket money on improvements or even a new ship.7.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2013
												-As of November 21st of 2015, this review is woefully outdated. Be aware-Actually one of the more decent MMOs I've played. Strangely compelling.Even so, there basically is no endgame. Well, actually, there is, but the endgame really is just there for the sake of itself. You grind missions to get better gear to grind missions faster to get even better gear to grind the missions even faster, ad nauseum.Levelling up to endgame is fun but fast, and is really only there for the sake of getting you used to endgame, which the game still doesn't do extremely well. Skills in particular can be confusing to level.All in all it's a solid game with solid mechanics though, most of the powergaming bits can be ignored for the sake of its core gameplay, which is blowing the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of everything in a spectacular fashion. Not very up and coming of a Starfleet officer, I think, but as a Klingon or Romulan is definitely fitting.As for the IP, STO uses the Star Trek universe to its advantage and makes fans of the series feel right at home, while not alienating people who've never watched an episode of Trek in their lives. Even so, the aforementioned tonal contrast between the Starfleet of the shows and movies and the more Imperium of Man-style gung-ho militaristic Starfleet of this game can be jarring but still doesn't ruin the experience (for me at least).As for the Pay2Win question, Star Trek Online is one of the better examples I have seen of the F2P monetization model. Everything the game gives you for free is more than viable for every single PVE confrontation in the game. Even so, getting the very good stuff is still free. Explaining STO's currencies and economy takes a while, but basically it goes like this: -Energy Credits are the GP of Star Trek Online. They're gained mainly from selling random loot you don't end up needing. They can be used at NPC vendors and the player exchange, which sells everything from high quality equipment to rare ships usually only acquirable from Lock Boxes or the Lobi Crystal Consortium (more on those later)-There's this stuff called Dilithium. It takes dedicated effort to grind for the unusable version, which is then converted to the usable version at a rate of 8000 daily. Dilithium is used to do pretty much everything endgame.-Zen is the paid currency. You buy it for $1.00/100 Zen. You buy advanced ships and other helpful sundries with it.-You can exchange Dilithium for Zen. Players buy Zen and want your Dilithium because they don't want to grind it themselves. You want their Zen because you don't want to buy it. You put your Dilithium up and offer it for Zen, and someone grabs it. Or vice versa. The economy of Dilithium/Zen exchange rates are dictated by supply and demand.-Lock Boxes (basically Mann Co. Supply Crates) can be opened with Master Keys, giving you a random goodie (sometimes an extremely good ship) and some Lobi Crystals. Lobi Crystals are bound to your account, but can be used to buy things on the Lobi Crystal Consortium, things like desirable equipment, advanced consumables, and even good ships. Master Keys are bought from the cash shop, which you can get the currency for by exchanging the grindable currency.Again, everything in the game can be gotten for free. If you have enough time you can have the best equipment in the entire game without ever paying a cent.All in all, Star Trek Online is one of the better examples I've seen of an MMO doing things right. It had a rocky start, but has grown into a great game. I definitely recommend trying it, even if you don't really like Star Trek.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2012
												Star Trek has always been a dream MMO for me to play and when I first saw this I knew I had found my one home on the internet.I installed it and created my account and I was truly amazed by just the amount of immersion they have built into the game. Ypou start by creating your character, You can choose between Federation, Klingon Empire or Romulan Empire... I picked Starfleet of course!Upon creating your character I was expecting your normal 6 races that were peoples most favs but I soon learned that you could go as far as being Andorian and even a Trill(Joined or not) BUT it does not stop there, They have also included the tools to create your own Alien Race complete with special abilities custom looks and the lot. Imagine Spore Creature Creator in an MMO! The Tutorial began and I was celebrating graduation from starfleet Academy which for me was a real shame because I would liked to have spent some more time and perhaps even my first 10 levels just learning about the game and the Star Trek Universe. I mean would you take up the chance to do a class on Warp Engineering?This is where the excittment stopped for me, There is ground combat but I refuse to even Awknowledge that part of the game as its severly lacking in every possible way. (I remember one time I was being chased around a tree by a Klingon... all my friends just stood and laughed at me) Space battles are extremely intense and provide a great bit of stress relief though I felt there could have been a little more.SUGGESTION: Not something I can really complaoin about but I'm going to rant and suggest it here... this is Star Trek and there is no ability to command your ship from the captains chair... I want to be able to walk around my ship issuing commands to my crew, not steering and fighting in 3rd person from outside the ship!Now that is all I can say but would like to also note it is a Theme Park MMO and I find these rather boring so this is not one I have played a lot of but it is one that has earnt itself a spot on my shelf and it will remain there defiantly.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												It certainly has it's weak points; repetetive missions, occasional bugs and some poor gameplay, although that's confined to ground missions. On the plus side, this is easily the best looking, most expansive and most realistic Star Trek game ever, that offers the best way to expericne the Star Trek universe yourself. Team games are also a lot of fun, especially death macthes. On top of that, it's easy to learn, highly customisable, and doesn't require you to throw money at it. Sure, you can pay your way up to bigger ships, but you loose the sense of achievement of ranking up. You're more likely to like it if you're more into the ships than anything else, but overall it's an authentic and enjoyable game.7/10

												One of the things that has always bugged me about MMOs is the long distance running to turn in quests. First they send you on a stupid quest to exact some justice on some lame fool who did something bad (insert short mission story line here), and when you finally get the guy and retrieve the spoils of battle from his cold dead corpse you have to run for days back to the quest giver to turn the mission in. So, for over an hour of gameplay you actually only played the game for maybe 5 minutes.  Not the case with Star Trek Online.In this space faring MMO you are the captain of your ship. You get to go out and have adventures and all that of a regular MMO with the flare of Star Trek. Along the way you can meet some characters from the shows. All that is to be expected. What was surprising was they way can get your quests. Like most MMOs you can walk up to a quest-giver and talk to them and they will give you the quest. In Star Trek Online you have the option of Calling them from your ship and selecting the mission from the list of available missions. It's almost as if the creators knew that you'd be a long, long way out in the middle of nowhere and wouldn't want to continually run back to to them just to turn in a quest. It is Star Trek, after all, why not just put them up on the main screen, Number One, and we can get on with our mission?Overall the graphics are basic for what systems can pull these days, and the voice acting in ok. The gameplay is a MMO game so you quest a lot. If you are a fan of Star Trek like me then you can forgive the game a lot and play for fun. At the sweet price of free, you don't even really need to be a fan to try it and see if space adventuring is right for you. Just keep in mind, if you are looking for the next blockbuster MMO to scale the mountain and dares all to knock them off of it, you're looking in the wrong place. This game is made for fun not necessarily to dazzle or impress you.

												The game has a lot of nice custimizable features for your character and crew. As long as you keep getting new equptment it's actually pretty good at keeping your quests to not being too hard for your level and having a lot of activities to do. content:
Posted: April 1, 2013
												This game is free, so that should pretty much set  your standards low enough to like this MMO. I'll say straight off the bat that the ground combat is absolutely crap in this game, you might like it... It's 3rd person (can kind of have a 1st person view if you press enough buttons) and the AI is about as smart as ReplyGirls on youtube. But the SPACE COMBAT is amazing. It looks brilliant, it feels rather solid and you'll have a blast with it.It's set many years after the events of The Next Generation (Picard, Sisko, Janeway if you have any idea about Star Trek).The uniforms in this era look like Latex crap, but you can wear late uniforms from First Contact and customise how you look.Also this game/MMO absolutely craps all over Star Trek and everything it stands for. Just enjoy it as a game, don't ever consider it canon.I put many hours into this game because I loved the ship battles, that's it. Give it a try. It's free for crying out loud! ;)

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												Very fun game with good story lines and lots of stuff to explore and enjoy. There are a lot of things you can buy with real money (aka zen) but you can aquire zen by selling in game currency (dilithium) If you have multiple characters, you can farm dilithium much faster since the base rate you can refine a day is 8k per character and a little more later if you are in a fleet and or a vetern lifetime player. So basically you can buy anything in the game that costs real money, without ever spending any real money. It involves a little grinding but nothing you cant do easily once you have a lvl 45+ character. Cap is 60 now. I have over 1200 hours in the game since it has gone to steam and I played it pretty much since open when you had to pay a monthly fee to play. They are always adding new stuff though there are times in the past they were a little slow on end game stuff but it looks like they are picking up the pace again. Its free to play so you cant go wrong for trying it out. You have ground missions and your bridge officers that go with you to help you on them and you have space missons. Both are a lot of fun. You can also increase the difficulty of missions if you feel that they are too easy. Up it some and they definantly wont be too easy. Plus if you do, and you die, you take damage and you have to repair it, though it doesnt hinder you too much until you start dying a lot, which i have done before back when I was new to the game and didnt realize that I accidently turned it up to max. I got destoryed..... and a ton of damage debuffs... basically shooting blanks at that point and so were my officers. Anyways, its a great game and a lot to do. Try it out and if you need help, just hit me up @dacra is my handle for my characters. Good luck :)

												Simply put, Star Trek Online is a wonderful game.  You are given a high level of customization over your characters, crew, uniforms, weapons, and ships.  While you can spend money on items, simple Dilithium mining, grinding, and ship-to-ship combat can provide most of the currency needed to buy items.  Larger battles can provide all manner of weapons and ship upgrades you can sell, equip, or trade.  Story writing is excellent and puts you in several famous locations throughout the galaxy.  If you are a Star Trek fan open to playing in MMORPG, this is the game for you!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Over all enjoy this game. Unlike other MMORPG's there is a special feature in this game where players can create their own custom content. This is in the form of maps and missions. With in these there are missions or goals, tho the rewards for these games are standardised by STO (star trek online). If your a fan of star trek online then you'll more than likely enjoy the game for a long time. For even beginers (F2P Free 2 play), there is enough slots open to play 1 character from each faction. With in the game you have choices of engineering, tactical, and science captain. There are similar ships to choose from with appropreate abilities. If you want a little compairison, think of tactical like a fighter, engineer like support/aid/tank (not as high dps as tactical), and science to be along the lines of support ability wizard/cleric (offencive/defencive) Most of the game is available to play for free. In fact you can level up to the maximum level and pilot some top end ships. However special or eliet type ships are much mroe time consuming to get. There are story lines for federation, klingon, and romulan factions (playable). Then as you level up there are chapters about older star trek oddities like tribbles. Missions with the actual Warf as a voice actor. Borg missions, species 8572, volcan, and much more. My personal favoret is to visit deep space 9, Earth space dock, and to fly around where ever I want. I think this game as at least compairable to most other mmorpgs with pets, quests, items, character customization is far supperior than most. There is a lot of content that is available to those willing to spend the money to get it. Rather than monthly subscriptions there are free to play accounts, Monthly subscribers, and life time memberships.  The Life time member enjoy certain rewards and perks continuesly while other perks become available immediately on purchase.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												**REVIEW POST UPDATE 7/20/2014 6:46 PM (PDT)**A few months have passed, and so many new things came to the STO Universe. Such as more inventory space for free, and bank space. We are currently in Season 9.5 A New Accord. The .5 generally brings some modifications to game performance and what not. We should expect some new things, in Season 10. For now however, I have been exploring the STO Universe, making new friends, discovering new things, and more! I still do greatly recommend the game, for newcomers to STO, you guys get an updated Tutorial :3, but have fun, and never give up!*REVIEW POST UPDATE 4/6/2014 1:12 PM (PST)*The game has greatly improved over the past year that I had been playing it. Although, the Dyson Sphere can use some work, as there is a huge bug where the ground below you spazzes out, but other than that, a very great game. You might see other people that are Vice Admiral(Level 50 [Max Player Level]) and might make fun of you or something related, just ignore them. There are very few Vice Admirals' out there that would help newcomers into the STO Universe. I became one of these people and help any newcomer that I see that is in trouble, when it comes to a mission, friendly stroll in Sector Space, or some casual talk. I think every newcomer into the STO Universe, should remember one thing, Never give up. What you see there, was something I learned when ranking up within STO. If you need any help, low level or not, you can always message me In-Game(If online), or send me a Friend Request through Steam, message me and I will get back to you ASAP. I really care to help out newcomers into the STO Universe, it's a really fun and addicting game. So just download the game, and come on and join us!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												STO is a very well executed space MMORPG. The story is relatively engaging for an MMO, and the graphics are nice. If you are even a little bit of a trekkie, there is a great deal of fun to be had here.That said, like most MMOs, it gets samey rather fast. It takes longer than most, which is something I really have to give the developers a great deal of kudos for, but eventually, you're going to feel like you're doing the same thing over and over again. Something that helps combat this is that it has the concept of user-created missions. You can actually get on a special account type and create missions for others to play. These range from the awesome to the "meh", and is another unique feature to STO.The fact that this is free to play, and the paid addons are reasonable, makes it definitely one of the better MMO's out there. If you liked Earth and Beyond back in the day, you'll probably like this. Recommended!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Yes you can probably see that I've played this game... a lot. The writers keep coming out with new content and events to keep you interested long after the standard missions have dried up.Character customisation allows you to redesign your character again and again and with new costume options available to everyone fairly soon after you dive in you can keep tweaking that look to match your characters' personality.The best experience however is to play in a team as this will bring greater rewards and teach you a thing or two. If teamwork is your thing then join up with an established fleet or take the plunge yourself and create a fleet just for your friends. Fleet management is, I will warn you, a time consuming and stressful at times vocation but it can and does bring its' own rewards.So many dimenions to the economies of the various currencies out there to mention here but a shrewd investor can actually make Zen (PWE's in-game currency) from the dilithium market.Overall, I'd recommend this to my friends as you have the option of playing for free and if you like it, you can always spend a bit of pocket money on improvements or even a new ship.7.5/10

Posted: November 22, 2015
												I came to this game back on the free to play launch.  I for the most part played nightly up until a year to two ago.  While the game is a great game one of the biggest down sides that caused me to stop playing the game is the constant grind to level up just so you can play the next story driven mission.  Sure it is easy to level up but it just gets old doing the same thing over and over again just to get to some new content.  The game when I came to it wasnt too bad but with the release of the fleet bases the game became a very huge dilithium sink which is now starting to level off some as dilithium values have dropped as majority of people have already finished their bases.I do recommend this game because you can put many hours in it but be warned you will have to do a grind to get to some stories as the story missions do not provide enough XP to level up from one story to the next.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Surprisingly good. I have not tried PvP, but throughout the PvE/story missions, I have never felt pressured to spend any money on the game. You unlock a new ship every 10 levels, and new ships are occasionally available for free during event missions. Every ingame thing you might need (gear, bridge officers, deck officers) is available from (relatively easily) obtainable resources in game as well as money.  The endgame isn't lacking in PvE, as of this writing there is a battlegrounds area for ground combat, and plenty of task force missions for space combat.In summary, the game is worth taking a shot at, even if you aren't a diehard trek fan.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Personal Rating: 6/10I've yet to play more of this game and I'm definately looking forward to it. While it is missing some essential characters such as Kirk or Spock, the impeccable voice acting and character emotion is amazing. Naturally, like all MMORPG's there is a lot of collecting x amount of y monster. But it doesn't feel overdone or underdone in this game. I'm not a Star Trek fan but I'm enjoying it! The combat is fluent and the dialogue is near-perfect.However, there are only two things wrong, small things, but non the less they are essential. The frist point being my character has no voice and for such a star studded audio presentation it deterierates into laughable situations where it's a very serious moment, everybody panicing and there's me, stood there, emotionless and voiceless.My second and final complaint it the ship. I hate controlling the ship, it just feels clunky and I can never get it to the right speed.But other than that it's a thoroughly enjoyable game (so far) and I'm looking forward to playing more of it. Unfortunate lack of Simon Pegg though.

content:
Posted: March 6
												This was the game that got me back into gaming back in 2011 after a long hiatus from games. In 2017, the game engine and play mechanics has aged pretty badly (they weren't astounding even in 2011). However, if you enjoy pretending you are in Star Fleet flying your ships around, it's fun to collect all the ships and play dress-up with your captain and crew. It might be a different experience after Free2Play launched, which makes the experience feel "less pure" because a lot of things are now unlocks that used to be part of the core subscription experience, but it is not as bad as Free2Play Star Wars: The Old Republic (ugh). I'm rating it a YES because I have fond memories of it and enjoyed it as a game that is a scaffold for my own storytelling in the Star Trek universe. It has a very flexible, if dated, character editor and you can create your own missions in "The Foundry". It won't cost you anything to try it as it is F2P. If you are looking for a polished game with more rewarding action gameplay mechanisms, however, I would not recommend it. It is probably the most polished and complete Star Trek game out there now, but there is little competition. MASS EFFECT this is not.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												If you like Star Trek then this is game is a must play... you may really fall for it and want to keep playing. I played this several years back and I must say it has come a long way in how the game unfolds and is presented. You really feel like part of Star Trek universe with the music, voice work, and the types of missions you get. I still don't have a lot of time in but because it is totally free to start playing it is easy to recommend.  The ship battles are pretty cool and have rather simple but still rewarding strategies even at the beginning. It isn't complex but again if you like Star Trek it gives you that feel like you are having those battles in space with a star ship. I'm hoping as you level and continue to explore there will be more depth.  The ground combat is pretty weak. Presentation is better and the integration of all the parts is so much better than a few years ago it is comendable. Still it's a shame the quality isn't even up to where Star Wars online's work is and not nearly as fullfilling as a Rift, WoW or Guild Wars 2 scheme.  I like that despite some of the weaker pieces the game still has that Star Trek flavor that makes it worth playing for those who like the movies and TV shows.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2012
												STO has been my game of choice since participating in the closed beta. Though it suffered from a difficult start and bumps along the way, the game has continued to evolve and grow. The PvE aspect of the game has become expansive and can seem a bit overwhelming at times for new players. With so many systems integrated over the years from Duty officer missions and abilities, Reputations systems, countless gearsets/combinations, greatly improved crafting system finally in place, and of course the missions both official and player created, the game feels mostly complete and whole finally. Like any MMO it will continue to evolve and not always in a direction everyone will be happy with. That said the Development team generally gets it right. The free to play aspect is among the best I have encountered in all my thirty years as a gamer and the last ten or so with my encounters with free to play models. There are items a player would need to purchase for endgame such as ship upgrade tokens, fleet modules, and a removal of the energy credit cap. All items mentioned can be purchased with either cashy money or in game dillithium converted to game currency through the dillithium exchange. Now for the bad. The PvP is woefully lacking in improvement and attention since launch. While it can be entertaining the public qeues are so one sided and have been since a few months after launch. Abilities are often unblanaced to a fault. Often you are stuck with either the cookie cutter flavor of the month builds, abilites, Duty officer combinations. Even if you have a great build you can expect to lose unless you have a mostly coordinated team all geared and built to provide the DPS and support needed to win. I would not recommend PvP to any new player without first consulting with a PvP group in game sadly. As for the bad part of the PvE side, The Special task Force missions and Advanced Qeues have become a DPS race. You need to participate in advanced Qeues to get items needed for reputation gear. Often if you need reputation gear you are not in a position to contribute much to the team. another. Another issues is the complete lack of need for the Enginner and Science professions in game. In space missions and PvP they are vastly less valuable than a Tactical captain because they cannot produce the same kind of DPS. Having had thirty eight Max level characters before Delta Rising and Six after fully geared and tested to a minimum of 15k DPS and some to as high as 35k (Good but far from great measured by the Infected Space Advanced Standard) and often coordinating for PvP and having written a few of the build guides over the years I feel qualified to say this. It is just the nature of the game for now and may change with balancing as time goes on. On a final note for the PvE is a lack of attention to some bugs, though not game breaking, they can be irritating.All that said if you are still here I completely recommend this game. The good vastly outweighs the bad and I will continue to play so long as this is true. See you out there.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4
												I bought the game back in 2010 during the initial launch and wasn't very impressed with the game and quit shortly after. After putting the game out of my mind for almost 7 years I decided to jump back in to it and give the game another shot. I had heard from some close friends that the game was actually good now.I really enjoy the game. The story arcs are pretty good, the gameplay is very enjoyable with good space combat(the ground combat is mediocre, but it offers a nice break from the space combat) The F2P model is very fair and you can buy anything from the premium store(named the C-Store) with the use of in-game currency. They have pretty regular promotions(couple of times a year) where they give away free ships, just recently during the 7th anniversary they gave away a batch of Tier 5 ships(1 Klingon ship, Romulan ship and Federation ship) worth about $20 each for free and during special events they give away new, unique Tier 6 ships for free.The game is also very alt friendly(they actually encourage you to make several characters) Any ship you unlock through the premium store(with either real or in-game currency) are unlocked account wide.The game isn't without flaws though. Like most games, Star Trek Online has a loot box system which you can gamble to get unique ships only available from boxes. I'm personally indifferent to loot boxes in games, but I know a lot of people despise them. But you can also buy these ships from other players(through the Exchange, which is the games Auction House system) for in-game currency. These gambling ships are on the same power level as the ones bought through the premium store, but they are different in that they are not unlocked account wide.This is honestly one of the best F2P games on the market right now, and if you're a fan of Star Trek looking for a new MMORPG, I'd highly recommend it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												I like this game.  I played it before Perfect World, when it was only Cryptic, too.  It's changed a lot.  There isn't 3 hr mandatory quest chain completion issues that nobody except me seemed to complain about.  Way back then, if you got an hour and half into certain quest chains and you had to log out, you had to restart the quest chain all over again.  I didn't like that.  At some point, I had enough crew members to do quests and there were quests to do.  It was quite joyous, because I never needed to risk some multi-hour chain quest as if I was in a dungeon crawler.  However, I'm a complete loner in the game, and at lvl 56 I just play to level up.  Statistically, I'll make friends at some point in the game of course.  The fact that I can essentially be an invisible man at lvl 56 does speak a bit to the depth and detail of the game.Unlike WoW, I don't play auction, and I literally have maybe three captains.  I don't even use the bank.  You can see by the hours I've played that I've been somehow more efficient than most in the game, but I don't invest in gear or anything like that.  In fact, I haven't even placed my 'talents' since the last update that reset the talents.  The newer Admiral quests add something to questing, so the crew quests didn't get boring.  However, the newer Admiral quests really, really, really like a lot of very nice expensive ships.  Either that's a lot of grinding or that's a lot of cash, and I don't feel like doing either, so they get done much slower.The only thing I really want to do is try to have to ships that have higher crew maximums so I can have more crew for quests and options.  However, 400 crew to me is pretty good because I don't really want to grind for the much higher crew maximum options.  In this crew maximum sense, a single $20 can go amazingly far, but then you'll be taunted in the sense that you want to fill the maximum just as quickly as you raised the crew maximum.  Slow and steady with a dose of efficiency works just fine.  I do think the game is fun, I really do.  This game has a lot of places to run around and look at things when you find yourself bored.  It's quite nice.  There's also a safe mode that's windowed that will work on little 11inch screen 2 in 1s.

												There's a lot of stuff to say about STO.First of all, it's absolutely huge, the story alone lasts for many hours already, and the content is constantly being expanded, partially even with things like player created missions. I like Star Trek a little in general but I never was a big fan of the series or anything like that.The graphics in the game are generally pretty good in my opinion, and some of the systems (like the fluidic space) are actually eye candy. The character customisation is pretty cool, but it's restrictedin unnecessary way.Also, expect bugs. Many bugs. Most will be to your disadvantage but every so often the game might glitch out in your favor.True to a really big MMO there are a lot of places with a lot of things you can do, and it'll take a hundred hours or so just to try everything out.I'll save myself listing Pros and Cons, as enough reviews have already done that.Also, beware of the Gorn jokes.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												I have never gotten to max level in an MMO before I played this, but this game suffers from some serious flaws. The end game content is very grindy, especially compared to the experience of leveling up a character, your UI WILL be filled with way too many windows, and ground combat is subpar to space combat. That said the episodic quests are outstanding and really make up for a lot of the game's flaws for me, and the free-to-play model is the best in the MMO business. A solid but unoutstanding MMO with plenty of fan service and a very good atmosphere, along with Cryptic's outstanding character customization.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												This game is clearly pay to win.  While you can play through the game without spending anything purchased ships and items have clear advantages over the ships you aquire  through regular means.  Ground combat is hidiously designed and clunky as hell.  You'll find there are significant delays between ordering an attack and executing it.  The game offers a choice between "RPG mode" which does all the aiming for you and "FPS" mode which allows more action oriented combat, but there's almost never a reason to leave the aimbot mode.Locations are generally uninteresting, and the game often doesn't reward exploration of any kind.  Puzzles in the game are often too easy to be considered interesting, and too long to be considered anything other than extremely annoying.  In fact, so much about away missions is annoying that you'll find yourself skipping as much text and dialog as possible just to get back in to space quicker.The redeeming feature of this game is the space combat which is well executed and visually pleasing.  It's possibly the only interesting part of the entire game.Like many other people, I figured this game would have a strong PvP element.  I chose to play as a klingon because the idea of engaging ships in raw comabt was appealing.  However as it turns out PvP queues are almost always empty and the likelihood you'll get to try PvP is almost nil.  I asked around about why PvP was so dead and .. SURPRISE: it's because the game balance is broken, and every experienced player knows it so they only play PvE.Missions are mostly wooden and uninteresting.  Sometimes you spend a lot of time annoyingly running between two points.  90% of the items sold in the game require currency that you either have to pay for, or is difficult to figure out how to acquire.  The currency you get the most of (energy credits) is mostly worthless for anything other than buying items which won't be better than the drops you get or speeding up travel which can be very slow over long distances.This game had the potential to be something special, particularly with the space combat which will suck you in - at least at first.  However it drops the ball in so many ways you'll wonder why you bothered to waste time with this dud.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												If you are a Star Trek fan, you owe it to yourself to give this game a try... for free. It tends to lose itself in the background noise of every other MMO around. It does nothing really special, but it is fun to try to design your own ship and uniforms, and pick your own crew. The only real criticism of this game is the same that I have of every MMO: you are not unique. You have the same gear, access to the same missions, and are captain of a starship just like every other player. Areas around planets and space stations are clogged with dozens of starships, all captained by players. I feel this is evidence of a systemic assumption in MMO design, that players don't want to work for anything. I feel it would have been far more compelling if they required you to work up to being a captian with your own ship.From a technical standpoint, I have constant issues with the servers being down. I often get significant lag followed by the termination of my connection and (when I try to log back on) the server is down. This is not an occasional thing. Just about every time I sit down to play. I'm pretty positive this is not an issue on my end, as I don't encounter this problem anywhere else. As a result, I've not been able to play this game as much as I'd like.Over all, I think it has some value in the idea that you get to see a lot of cool Star Trek stuff. And, if played for free, this can be worth while (and the reason for my recommendation). But I wouldn't pay for a rather bland game with so many server issues.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												I am forced to decide between recommending the game or not, so I'll say yes, however, it is a huge "Yes, but"You will need a lot of tolerance for grinding. Or dump a lot of real money into the game which I don't recommend, stuff is not cheap.The main problem for me is the 8.000 Dilithium cap a day (that's not much at all). It is clearly designed to slow down your progression in order to annoy you, wear you down and make you spend real money. This is a disgusting business practice, a bigger joke on the player than horse armor. Technically you can get everything in-game, but it will deliberately take forever. I can understand for some players this to be a game breaker.Also, you will need patience or the ability to have fun figuring stuff out. The economy, the UI, several features are kinda hard to grasp for new players.I personally mostly have enjoyed the game during the 3 months I have played the game, since I have played Wow for a long time I have a huge tolerance for grinding. The Space battles as well as story and parts of the customization are cool. And I will continue shooting a beam rainbow, even if it is not optimal damagewise.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												I like this game.  I played it before Perfect World, when it was only Cryptic, too.  It's changed a lot.  There isn't 3 hr mandatory quest chain completion issues that nobody except me seemed to complain about.  Way back then, if you got an hour and half into certain quest chains and you had to log out, you had to restart the quest chain all over again.  I didn't like that.  At some point, I had enough crew members to do quests and there were quests to do.  It was quite joyous, because I never needed to risk some multi-hour chain quest as if I was in a dungeon crawler.  However, I'm a complete loner in the game, and at lvl 56 I just play to level up.  Statistically, I'll make friends at some point in the game of course.  The fact that I can essentially be an invisible man at lvl 56 does speak a bit to the depth and detail of the game.Unlike WoW, I don't play auction, and I literally have maybe three captains.  I don't even use the bank.  You can see by the hours I've played that I've been somehow more efficient than most in the game, but I don't invest in gear or anything like that.  In fact, I haven't even placed my 'talents' since the last update that reset the talents.  The newer Admiral quests add something to questing, so the crew quests didn't get boring.  However, the newer Admiral quests really, really, really like a lot of very nice expensive ships.  Either that's a lot of grinding or that's a lot of cash, and I don't feel like doing either, so they get done much slower.The only thing I really want to do is try to have to ships that have higher crew maximums so I can have more crew for quests and options.  However, 400 crew to me is pretty good because I don't really want to grind for the much higher crew maximum options.  In this crew maximum sense, a single $20 can go amazingly far, but then you'll be taunted in the sense that you want to fill the maximum just as quickly as you raised the crew maximum.  Slow and steady with a dose of efficiency works just fine.  I do think the game is fun, I really do.  This game has a lot of places to run around and look at things when you find yourself bored.  It's quite nice.  There's also a safe mode that's windowed that will work on little 11inch screen 2 in 1s.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Star Trek Online, or STO, is a game set in the space age with giant ships, a whole selection of races (Not Racing) and a vast galaxy to explore! I will recomend this to people who like Star Trek and to people who don't really know anything about it as through the story telling you will get to grips with basics of Star Trek knowledge. This game is still being updated regulary and has seasonal and daily events that add hours of gameplay added onto the 100+ hours of storyline, side quests and PvP. As this is a Cryptic game the customization is superb from the ships you fly to the crew who fly it. Now this game plays in two ways, one way is with your ship and the other is on the ground. As this is a mmorpg you can get together and play with your friends and play through the missions together or you can play on your own. This game is completely different to other popular mmorpg's as this brings another aspect to the gameplay as it's not just a grind fest on the ground but in space with a whole galaxy to explore meeting different races and player along the way. Now when you start the game you can pick from 3 main races, Starfleet, Klingon and Romulan all having different quests, ships, planets, weapons, armors and gameplay styles so they all offer a different way to play. Now as this game is made by Cryptic it does have some Pay to Win ascpects or in this case pay to unlock before unlocking as about 60% of the items and ships you can get from the 2 non payed currency, zen being the payed one. I am going to give this game a 8/10 as it has 100's of hours of gameplay, regular updates and a vast community; but let down by its small glitches.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												My opinion? I would say about 7/10.First, as a Trek fan I enjoy that it continues the story of the Prime universe, and that there are tons of call backs, references, and even cameos.Now, when I started, I admittedly felt like the controls were a tad awkward, but once I got used to them. I've found that that's all I really needed: to get used to them.The space combat is highly reminicent of what's seen in the shows/movies, even including attacks/abilities that can be traced to commands given by the various captains across the generations.The ground combat/missions could be better, but I personally find them tolerable.The graphics are good, but not fantastic, and it tells a good story overall.Also, if you love the ability to customize virtually everything(no, that's not an exageration), you'll get a kick out of this game. You can customize your outfits, your ships(with some restrictions based ship's class/type etc), alter your bridge officers, and even create your own species.The crafting system is a bit tedious, and materials are hard to come by, but it's not horrible.Now, if I had to name my biggest issue with this game, its the same as most MMOs: the microtransactions. By using real money to by 'Zen'(100 Zen = $1), you can unlock a lot of stuff, but some of it is kinda petty and/or overpriced. For example if you want to get a new ship past level 50(that's appropriate to your level), you better be willing to pay out $25 PER SHIP. Granted,, there are other ways to secure new level appropriate ships, but most are geared for LV 50, and require grinding for special currencies to aquire.Also, I have to say I've notice the community tends to be a bit juvenile.  Even though there do appear to be some more mature people among the community, by and large I would recommend just soloing unless you really need help.So, overall the gameplay is enjoyable and good for Trek fans, plus it also has some good storytelling and decent graphics. But, the petty money stuff and largely immature community are a bit offputting. If you are a Trek fan, or just love MMOs with lots of customization and decent story, check it out, and enjoy some nostalgia.If you aren't a Trek fan, can't stand stupid players, or hate microtransactions...feel free to give it a try, but it may not be for you.

Posted: August 27, 2014
												Oh God.OH GAWD!!!!PLEASEPLEEEEEEAAAAAASE send this game to that horrible circle of hell reserved for the ♥♥♥♥♥iest of MMO'S!!!!!!!Let me see...LAGL...A...G...And my system SHOULD blow this game out of the water...Auto-combat. Click on they enemy and watch them die. Or... attempt to click on them before watching them die because you're running at 5 fps and the enemy AI is having a seizure... TERRRIBLE (and I mean terrible) voice acting. Wierd Camera. Really Generic Quests: "here, go kill this three of these Giant Beetle Things and report back to me..." I'm sorry, did you mean "click on these giant beetle things and watch them SLOWLY (and I mean slowly) die while you frantically search a miniscule bar 0' equitment and attributes for some non-existant secondary weapon that will speed up the process a little!?" No? CUZ THAT'S WHAT I'VE BEEN DOING FOR THE PAST TWO HOURS!!!!!!!!Point n' click flying +Really Bad Lag don't mix. AT ALL... Overall, avoid at all costs, even if its free. There's some "pay-to-win" crap in there too, by the way, I just didn't encounter much of it because of my limited time playing the game...Yeah... its not just boring, or a ripoff (of time, that is), or bug-ridden, like normal bad games are, its PAINFUL to play. Like rubbing a cheesgrater against your forhead and staring at a wall of LED lights for hours on end.

content:
Posted: February 26
												Star Trek Online is a great game. The gameplay is fun and the missions are very diverse and innovative, and one of my favorite mechanics is the foundry mode where you can create and upload your own custom missions which are super fun to play. Although some very annoying things happen with the game itself like frequent crashes/freezing, there's this little bug that makes it where your mouse arrow is in the wrong position so you cant click on thin gs because the arrow isnt where it looks like it is, but otherwise the game is great and although some of the MMO mechanics need working on (I'm looking at you Red Alerts) the game is very innovative and fun and rarley seems repetitive

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26
												I've been playing this game for at least 5 years by now, but not on Steam so my "hours played" are no where near reflective of my actual time in game. STO is a good game and offers lots of stuff to do, lots of ships and gear to aquire, instances to run, etc. The "ground mission" graphics and gameplay aren't amazing, but the space battles are where this games strength lies. the community is impressively civil, and people actively try to help each other, which is rare in most MMO's. The publisher- Cryptic isn't especially great and doesn't respond to tickets or emails, or seem to really care what players think. There is definately a p2w dynamic at play, becasue grinding certain ships would literally take you years. All that said, I still recommend this game if you are a Star Trek fan. If you aren't, then this probably isn't the game for you.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												I just wanted to re edit this review as I have spent a lot more time in game and think it deserves a bit more time.Firstly I think this is the best mmo out there and its free! It is so in depth, I have put 70 hours into the game and im still finding stuff out. It is highly customisable from yourself to your ship to your ship crew.  The stories are excellent if your a fan of Star Trek which I am, theres loads of reference to all the franchises with episodes of time travel to get your origianl series fill.The ship battles are my favourite. This isn't Dota you have a full array of abilities to chose from, my Naga gets a lot of use. I am really enjoying the Science vessel it is my kind of play style and feels like a character in itself. There are hundred of different ways you can play the ships. Having a science vessel but then having a tactical team or a mix of all. You even chose the different officers on your ship which then opens up different abilities which you can choose from.You get duty officers alos which you can send on mission and this can level you, get skill points and dilithium.I havent finished learning the game, there seems like there is much more and they are always improving it and adding new seasons.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												With nearly 515 hours of gameplay this is my review - 2 max lvl 60 Fleet Admirals. I am also a Fleet ambassador( Armada delegate)Pro's- Large waste world with company and player driven missionsCan get lost for hours completing MissionsGood online community - hardly any trollsPVE content is decentI love the space battles and some ground missions are fun13 Fleets(guilds) form an ArmadaCons- lag more often then mostTeam based- you can solo but it so boring doing it that wayAll Fleets(Guilds) require Massive ingame currency which can slow down your progression to help with guild leveling and projectsnot many fleets actually do things togetherIts kind of a "every gamer for themselves" gameKinda of Biased on factions. Federation has more ships options then the klingons, and Romulans have very crappy selectionHEAVY GRIND FEST OR LOADS OF REAL CASH FOR ENDGAME ITEMS,SHIPS ETCPVP DeadIm split down the middle with this game. I like the game just certain things bother me with this game.. the amount of time it takes to farm certain currency is truly time consuming. Nearly all items are CASH shop based. The ingame currency used to buy items and upgrades has an 8k daily limit. which is like a penny a day when you see the price of some items. The game is design for you to make ALTS and FARM/GRIND to increase your currency intake.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Only online style games ive played are Defiance, LOTRo, WoW all three are worthy, good games. But there was something about STO that i just love, the fact you can basically play the entire game without spending a penny [and this doesnt mean you have to spend hours and hours grinding on mulitple characters] As i am a fairly new player to a game thats been out for over 2-3 years it meant i could jion a fleet that had experience, helpful players. I love the game, by far one of my favourites, since getting i got the 1 month Gold sub, as this unlocks many things but then most stay open if you go back to silver [f2p] ive bought some of the ZEN [which is paid with real world money] as i fancied a new ship and as i enjoyed the game so much without spending a penny i thought £20 to have a 1 month GOLD account and then enough ZEN to buy a special ship was worht it. Theres so much to do, and it gets updated regularly, and at certain times of the year they have events where you can get free ships, costumes etc.
