number of helpful: 11 of 21 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												Star Trek Online is a very interesting game, to say the least, but has loads of issues. First of all there is immersion-breaking pop in with characters, entities, special effects, and entire scenes. What I'm talking about here is when the screen transitions from one scene into another it doesn't allow all of the entities to load before coming in from black. So you're frequently left watching strange pop-in with stuff. There are also numerous control-specific things that just feel... off... like clicking over and over to attack, instead of being able to just hold down the button, to give one example. It is a great looking game, and worth the price of admision (it is free after all) but I wouldn't really recommend it as something worth spending any significant amount of time playing.

number of helpful: 11 of 21 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24
												"Fleet Admiral and 6-year long loyal Veteran's Log - Stardate 94754.01 (Earthdate 24 Feb 2017)This will be my final uninstall of the game.Star Trek Online, over the past few years, has had some major issues, graphically. No matter how compatible and powerful my laptop and my PC are to run Star Trek Online, the game still has crashes, infinite loads or graphical issues in game. My laptop is fully capable of running DirectX 9, and DirectX 11. However I can only run DirectX 9 due to an infinite loading screen whenever I try to switch out the DirectX version to 11. (It will freeze after the 'Cryptic' load, where the title of the current Season is displayed, with 0-1fps appearing and disappearing constantly).Furthermore, updates and patches are tempremental with my settings. Some patches, maybe most, are harmless to them, and I can get back in game and not have an issue. But many, well, they break my install or my setup. Safe mode is the only way it runs, and that's not something I signed up as Veteran for. So for the past few years (on my laptop - we'll get to my PC later) I've remained on DX9 because it's been the most reliable. Although, even with this, I've had to at numerous times re-install everything to get it to run again without any issue. It is frustrating but being that I've been on this game for so long, casually, I've always tried again. Oh, and, reader, spare me the obvious fixes like verifying and such, I've tried everything I could find out and one way, shape or form it still will never work like it should.The latest patch though is the final patch I will ever let Star Trek Online install. Still running the old and retiring DirectX9 for this game, I get into the game fine as usual. However, another major issue has cropped up - the entirety of missing textures. All ships are invisible minus decals and effects, as well as the legs and face and hands of all my characters (just a floating torso and arms uniform, with a floating wig to boot). I tried to experiment with the settings. I tried switching to Dx11 and Dx9 experimental, and as is always the case, this causes the crash at the Current Season title/loading screen. Of course, Safe Mode works, however I don't see why I have to run that every time I want to play the game from here on in.As for my PC - I gave up long ago. The case was the opposite in terms of DirectX versions - it would only run DirectX11 despite full compatibility should I want to downgrade to a lower DirectX version (though with a PC as high-end as mine I'd have no need usually). Just as with my laptop, patches would be tempremental, with the same types of crashes and infinite loads. Exactly the same. Everything! Minus the opposite DirectX versions I use. I gave up on it long ago. I have better next-gen games to play anyway so I didn't have much patience to have to re install all the time.So I bid Star Trek Online, and the crew of my ships, a final farewell. The errors and crashes and general temprementality of it all is... well, I wouldn't say not worth it. The game is Free To Play. But as a One-Time subscription purchaser, and having put a good bit extra of my real money into the game to show my appreciation despite it's issues, I can tell you, reader, that it is Free To Play for good reason now. Don't even put a dime into it. If you can get into the game of course."I'm not reviewing the content of the game here quite frankly. If that bothers anyone, then feel free to read the rest of the comments and countless reviews online that describe the content itself to make your own decision.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
												The game is a neverending pile of garbage. Wonky gameplay that gets repetitive pretty soon, uninspired missions that become grindier as you progress through the game (yes, they add kill X enemies mid game and not in the beginning, it's like they ran out of ideas and went "oh, ♥♥♥♥ it").AI is terrible too, with friendly officers getting stuck annoyingly often. Quests also suffer from constant bugs one way or another, sometimes even progress stopping bugs.Graphics wise it's outdated, which is not entirely a bad thing, but is paired with terrible acting and direction in cinematics, giving it some below amateur feeling that you can't wash off.And last but not least, the user interface is more of a bother than a help. Things like huge symbols in minimap that simply wont let you see what you are suposed to see, to everything looking pretty much the same and thus making it harder to even understand them, or weird design choices like not giving a more direct approach to equiping kit abilities, having to realize on your own that you are suposed to try random keys until you get P and see a selection of avaliable skills.Basically, if you can skip this entirely you won't regret it, it doesn't get any better as you progress, it only gets worse.

												Here is the pro to the game:- Leonard Nimoy narrates and is the voice in the datalogThat is all.If you know nothing about Star Trek and are looking for a space RPG combat game, this still is a poor choice but not the worst.  However, for a game based on a franchise that were resolved around conflict resolution, problem solving and ingenuity, this game took out all three and decided to make a space combat game.  The characters are unimaginative and the missions consist of Space Ship combat - ground combat - Space Ship Combat, lather-rinse-repeat.  It's not about exploration, it's about being the Federation's enforcement.  Not worth it.

Play Klingon Academy if you're a Trekker. (The only reason I don't instead, is that I've already played it to death.) Play this game if you're a console gaming Trekkie. (The only reason I do is that I'm a Trekker starving for good Trek games. This will do, for now.)

number of helpful: 17 of 33 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												What I liked about STO (Star Trek Online) is impossible to say. After all, I never got that far because tech support was unable to answer a simple query concerning which domains to whitelist (other than perfectworld.com) in order to get it running on a secure system. Let's start from the beginning:.My system is specially set up so that JavaScript, etc.,  runs correctly on my system only when served from a whitelisted domain. From any other domain it gets shut down - which is how I know that STO is served, in part, from unspecified domains other than perfectworld.com and these other domains are, consequently, not whitelisted by my security. .What takes the cake is that, when I asked tech support for the domain names which needed to be whitelisted for the game to work, they responded by stating that the game works for “millions” of other people - which dodged the question by employing an argument by irrelevance; a form of sophistry known as a fallacy. I have to wonder if these guys even bothered to read the support ticket I lodged (given their total failure to comprehend the problem I raised) and why they couldn't simply address my question (as opposed to addressing some purely imaginary complaint).  .Now, when support techs start engaging in sophistry, it can mean that they are more interested in griefing the customers than doing their job. Moreover, this reflects very poorly on management, for obvious reasons; principally because it demonstrates the attitude that they can do no wrong and it is always someone-else's fault which, ultimately, gives rise to a fundamental disrespect for the customer base..The bottom line is that I recommend strongly against STO and, moreover, I will not be reviewing this game again until I see some sort of evidence that key management changes have been made which facilitate policy implementation designed to ensure that customers are not systematically marginalised for the apparent crime of asking for some technical support.

number of helpful: 19 of 37 people (51%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 25
												Star Trek is... Action - Adventure - Science Fiction - Gene RoddenberryStar Trek Online is... nothing like Star Trek, now give us dat money! - Perfect World EntertainmentSadly, this game has barely anything to do with Roddenberrys Star Trek apart from some name dropping and voiceover works from the actors.It is heavily combat focused, to the point where almost every single mission will require you to shoot down hordes upon hordes of goons both in space and on the ground.The missions and tasks you perform in this game are linear. All of them. Avoiding combat, alternate solutions to the tasks at hand, using technobabble to get out of a tough situation are not here - You rarely even get fetch quests for most of the storyline as the game reduces you to "go there, kill everything".And to add insult to injury, the post-scarcity world of Star Trek has seemingly been taken over by the Ferengi. Not only is there a player economy based on "energy credits", but a multitude of currencies including ore you mine with a daily cap for refinement, premium currency Zen, Ferengi Lobi Crystals and many many more.Now all of this would be bad but okay if the game offered any kind of depth or fun gameplay, but instead it sadly can't even hold up to the lowest of Korean grinding MMO standards. Forget about playing a healer or a tank - DPS rules supreme. Ground combat is even more dumbed down.It is painful to say, but Star Trek Online which once set out to be the continuation of the original timeline of Star Trek has become little more than a skinner box of shallowness and pay to win mentality. Instead of boldly going where no one has gone before, this game chose to remain at home and stick crayons up its nose. And it asks for 20 Euros for a single starship.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												I've played this game for 700 hours, and have played this game to win. I've played this game to max out my level, achieve the highest score, get the most out of my characters. Before I explain why I dont like this game,I would recommend this game if you are looking to have a fun time, if you are a casual gamer and a star trek nerd, you should definately give this game a shot. You can play through the campaign and have fun with your friends easily without spending a dime. Anything beyond that, I am not so sure, unless you like grinding your organs to mush. So, if you are in it for fun, and not to win it, then absolutely go on and download this game, skip the rest of what I have to say. Now, if the above does not apply to you, I would not recommend this game if you are looking to do what I did in this game, play to win. Before I start my review of the game as a whole, which might turn into a rant, let me say one major turnoff to all non-casual gamers, and that is that this game is SUPER DUPER POOPER SCOOPER Pay 2 Win, it's really pay 2 win, and every update that the devs stick into the disgrace of a game that it is right now, make it more and more pay 2 win.Originally created in a sort of rock paper scissors manner where you needed different classes of ships and types of captains to win in pvp or pve, (which mainly become the game after the storyline, and becomes a repetitive grind anyhow), the developers are slowly getting rid of this concept. It is common knowledge among all veteran players of this game that all that matters if you really want to win, is DPS. The usefulness of players that run ships like cruisers and science ships is so miniscule compared to those of escorts (the tactical officers main ship), and high dps cruisers, a more recent addition, (disgusting imo), that at high levels, after long hours of grinding, you will find yourself obsolete as anything but an escort player or tactical officer. This problem is so large that you will find that when you enter PvP especially, that players will exploit the broken game mechanics enormously, pairing different equipments, bonuses, and abilities, (there are so damn many), in ways that they are not intended, but allowed by the developers, that they are impossible to beat. The exploitation of everything at high ranks, the balancing of statistics to get the most out of escorts and such, really retracts from the star trek atmosphere. There are so many flaws I can go on and on about in the game, and before I run out of breath talking about this one flaw, exploitation, ill just lay them all out for you:1. Players exploit the game at high levels2. The game is unbalanced for different playstyles at higher levels3. Most players are at max level so you cant do anything in pvp 4. After you finish a set of missions, you will find yourself grinding the same PvE events for countless hours for just a few pieces of borg tech for example, unless you deem yourself a wallet warrior. 5. The in-game economy is very limited and boring.6. The actual storyline is repetitive and sparse.7. Broken game mechanics brings little variety to ships (if they want to win and be useful)8. They are always adding new ways to spend money or grind your organs to mush, they add plenty of new ships, plenty of new equipment, and new missions to get equipment, they hardly work on REALLY fixing the game and polishing it's mechanics. Instead of revisiting problems, they will simply expand. For example, if cruisers are underpowered because tanking and drawing fire is useless in PvE, they simply increase the damage of cruisers) 9. Besides the main storyline, side missions or personal missions are just as boring and typical, almost 100% of them are just rinse and repeat. Go shoot some ships, shoot some people on the ground, and run around pressing F to do some scan sci-fi stuff.10. Did I mention scans and the F key? Yes, everything besides shooting♥♥♥♥♥♥up, (which is easy because your character and ship locks onto everything automatically, making every enemy encounter just repeated buttons to press over and over, even with autofire on you are simply using your simple and boring abilities over and over to kill your enemy, waiting for abilities to recharge, rinse and repeat, rinse and repeat, grind GRIND GRIND!!!!Sorry, went on a bit of a tangent. Anyway back to the F key. Anything besides shooting♥♥♥♥♥♥up is basically going around, pressing the F key, whether you are healing wounded patients or scanning asteroids, you simply press the F key and wait for the bar to reach 100% and yay thats all. This isn't completely true, there are a few things in the campaign and side missions and stuff in the game that require a bit of skill, but 90% of these tasks have the same mechanics, and the way they are set up (easy as hell and boring to tears), you can probably set up a couple of macros to solve them anyway if you really cared. There are only a few instances in the newer campaigns that aren't the same damn easy puzzle, repeated over and over. The only useful mini-game is the one that you use to go dilithium mining, and that one is... Ok. :)Back on course, I think the #1 problem is the broken mechanics at higher levels:You will encounter players using dyson ships (completely STO-unique ships), firing romulan weapons (disruptors), using only beam weapons, (because multi-weapon ships are useless besides the occasional special weapon, and torpedoes are largely useless too thank you game mechanics), using borg ship modules, while using tholian engines and shields. Now this above issue isn't just an isolated thing, like you will see one in a handful of people doing this. Absolutely not, unless you are a low level player that doesn't know what he is doing, when you achieve higher ranks of Admiral, which everyone does pretty quickly, you will find that everyone is forced to do completely uncharacteristic things. You will find starfleet ships using antiproton weapons, and only antiproton cannons, or only antiproton beams, because adding a torpedo to a weapons slot would be useless, as torpedoes are quite useless without wasting plenty of skill points on them anyway and you need those skill points for beam weapons becuase torpedoes do nothing against enemy shields. (I could go farther but that would probably bore you)The worst thing that ever happened to this game was Perfect World Entertainment acquiring it from the original creators, Cryptic Studios. From the stories told by my clan mates, who have played this game from the creation, the game was a lot better, focused a lot less on giveusmoneygiveusmoneygiveusmoneygiveusmoney with PWE.I quit it a bit ago after getting fed up with all of the♥♥♥♥♥♥updates that were just excuses for PWE to make more money.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Before I talk about STO, let me quickly give you an idea of where I stood on MMOs and Star Trek as a franchise before I started playing this game. MMOs:I have tried pretty much every free-to-play MMO under the sun, and tried a couple paid ones as well. I've tried WoW--didn't care for it. Tried every Perfect World game—none of them grabbed me. The only MMO I sunk any time into before STO was City of Heroes/Villains. I played that game off and on for years and put hundreds of hours into it, and it was a fantastic experience. Still think it's one of the best MMOs ever made, and may it now rest in peace (P.S. NCsoft can go suck a fat one for shutting it down). Star Trek:Besides catching half an episode of Next Generation on TV as a kid here and there, I had never watched Star Trek. I was mostly indifferent about the franchise as a whole, and my vague childhood memories of Next Generation painted it as somewhat boring and confusing show. How wrong I was. Around the same time I was thinking about giving STO a shot I decided to watch a specific episode of Star Trek: The Original Series on Netflix because it was listed as a prime example of a now common science fiction trope on tvtropes.org. I've fallen into a deep, dark hole. I'm almost done with the original series, I've watched the first few episodes of Next Gen, and I've bought a Star Trek history book about the first 150 years of the federation. I'm a full-on trekkie now, apparently. Star Trek Online: So, the question is, how good is the game? My opinion is that it's very, very good, but that if  you don't like the source material you might not like the game either. It is pretty standard MMO fair in a lot of ways. You click on things, you hit hotbar keys, you click on glowy interact-able objects, etc. However, it does enough to differentiate itself that it winds up being a pretty great game, though it may not be different enough if you have no love for the source material. It's not, for instance, breaking into the new action MMO as hard as, say, TERA, but it does have a third-person shooting mode where you can 'aim' at enemies that I think is rather fun, and you have a dodge-roll by default. The game is split up into two modes of combat—ground mode, and ship mode. This is something that takes a little getting used to. For a while I really disliked the ship combat and wished it was nothing but ground, but after getting used to it, and after unlocking better ships and  more ship abilities, I've come to enjoy them both equally. Just give it time. And once you're at the point where you enjoy them both hopping back and forth between the two adds a lot of variety to the gameplay compared to any other MMO I've played. It's like every hour you're switching to a different game. The progression system has a few more layers to it than most MMOs thanks to that split in the combat. When you level up you're putting points into your captain, your ship, and the four members of your 'away team' that you bring with you on ground missions, and which provide hot-bar abilites during spaceship combat. You're getting loot for yourself and all your away team members, but also for your ship. Just the basic ship that everyone gets at the start will have gear slots for: tactical console, science console, engineering console, shield, engine, two fore weapons, one aft weapon. It only gets crazier from there as you start aquiring ships that have more weapon slots and more engineering consoles, and even hangars where you can put little dog-fighting ships that will fly out of your main ship and star wrecking stuff. Now, let's talk about your away team for a second. Having a squad of A.I. with you at all times is pretty cool, and makes you feel like a captain from the show. You can train them in different skills, and they're basically how you choose what ship abilities you want. On the ground they're another phaser to help you kill stuff, and they have abilities related to their class. You outfit them with gear, just like you do for yourself, and by employing old-school JRPG trickle-down economics, getting one great new gun could mean your whole away team is in for a slight upgrade As far as classes go, there's three, and they only really determine two things—what hotbar abilities you can get, and what skills you can train crew-members in (although you can also train them by 'using up' a new crew-member, which can be bought or received as a quest reward). Any class can use any weapon. So...yeah, I like this game a lot. It has a lot of easy to understand systems that are layered on top of each other to create something with a lot of depth. I love that I have more than just my own, single character's progression to focus on. When I level up I have to consider if I've been having trouble recently in space or on the ground, and drop points accordingly. You have to keep your away team in mind. That new gun that dropped might not be as good as yours, but is it better than something one of your guys has? Some people will hate this aspect of the game and think it busywork, but I love it. The world feels big, while actually being rather small and instanced. The sector map design when you go to warp looks cool as hell. There are references and fanservice dripping from every pore of this thing. If you like Star Trek at all, and you actively want to try and get into an MMO, you HAVE to give this a try.

												Let me start out by saying I love this game. I read the reviews and decided to pick it up on Stream, as it was free to play, and I was a big Star Trek fan. And it was great... at first. You can level really quickly, though part of that was due to the Delta Rising promotion they had going on when i joined, and the ships were great. Then I got to level 50, and was given access to the Delta Quadrant and Dyson Sphere. All the sudden, the wonderful mission's I'd been completing turned into 5-6 part grinds spanning over different areas, in different systems, in different sectors.... and I had one that I spent almost 2 hours trying to complete because even though I have the best ship in the "free" fleet, it does not match up to these enemies. So, unless I feel like spending money of upgraded ships and weaponry, I've gone about as far as I can in the storyline. I still plan on playing from time to time, but these missions are gonna be left undone, and my faith for future "seasons" highly in doubt.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Big, lore-heavy (and Lore light), and goofy. It's not the subtle intergallactic diplomacy styling of the TV shows; Star Trek Online takes more after the movies with more action and more conflict.This isn't a bad thing, the space combat has become more and more satisfying over the years and the complexity of situations improve every mission.The ground combat has improved enough to be fine, but isn't the most enjoyable part of the game. This is where the crew you bring on missions are helpful; they balance a lot of the quirks out and allow for some customization. In reality, if you take ground combat partially seriously it's alright and there's no real penalty for wiping on mission so the problems are ignorable.Since the game has been around for a few years, the ships available are many and wonderful. If you wanted to fly ships from the Dominion War perfect! Want to play a period-specific Enterprise from earlier shows and movies? They have that too. Everything comes with balance considerations, but careful outfitting and a casual play style make many of them servicable or at least different.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												I just got a new computer so my hours played are shown as a little low. Before I played directly from the original game client that launched with the game. I've as since, downloaded the game through Steam. I've been playing STO since the very beginning, I've always been on and off(that's what she said), and I suppose having a lifetime membership has helped in that regard. After a number of updates, the ground combat, skill system, and crafting have went through a number of improvements, and I enjoy them how they are now. You can play ground combat like a shooter or traditional mmo, but feels good to mix and match now and then.Space combat is the real treat, and plays differently depending on how you equip your ship and what type of ship you use. Large scale battles can be a very nice spectacle to behold.The story of the game starts off about 30 years after the last original timeline movie(Star Trek Nemisis),  and the original timeline events spoke of in the 2009 movie, as such, Romulus has been destroyed. Each story sequence helps explore different aspects of each of the different show storylines. It's also been great to hear Star Trek Alumni reprise their roles.I'm still having fun in Star Trek Online, and will put hundreds more hours into it. You don't have to spend real money if you don't want to, but if you're spending time in the game, it might be nice to give something back every now and then. Star Trek online is a great game for fans of the franchise, unless they don't like space battles or the idea of ground combat. But keep in mind, there are also a few diplomatic missions as well and puzzle solving. That's it from me for now.-Live long and prosper.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												So right off the bat, I'm going to make the claim that if you're a Star Trek fan, you'll find something to love about this game.Whether it's the episodic campaign that draws heavily upon the series and films. Or the vast overworld that allows you to beam down to many of the iconic locations you've come to know and love, such as Deep Space Nine, Starfleet Academy, Earth Stardock, Risa, and, taken directly from the most beloved film of the series, Paradise City from ST V. (Kidding.) Or just being able to run around your own ship or shuttle, most of which are inspired by, or are of the same class as, the ones from the show/films, and pilot it around the galaxy. There's something in this game for everyone.Since most people here have already covered the big parts of the game, I'll point my own personal list of Pros and Cons:PROS:- Fantastic Campaign: The devs for STO are big time Trek fans, and you'll definitely discover this once you start making your way through the campaign of your choice: Starfleet, Romulan, or Klingon. Each episode is formatted like an episode of the show, most of which are heavily inspired by plotlines from the show and films. Some of the episodes even continue the stories of some ST characters. Some devolve into shoot-'em-ups, but most -- especially the recent ones -- are 100% Trek, on par with the show. There are also player-created missions available to play through by way of the Foundry, which is awesome and something I wish more MMOs would incorporate.- Frequent Updates: Cryptic update the game with major episodic content a few times a year, most of which have featured actors reprising their roles from the series, such as Michael Dorn (Worf), Tim Russ (Tuvok), and Denise Crosby (Tasha Yar). Leonard Nimoy also narrates many key parts of the game in-character as Spock. Each new episode has added new story content, dailies, and general updates -- and all of them have been free. We've had one full-fledged expansion, Legacy of Romulus, and another one on the way in October called Delta Rising.- The Star Trek Experience: A lot went into making the game feel like a genuine Trek experience. The general atmosphere, the scale of the overworld, the missions, the visuals, locations, and characters. You take command of your own ship, and you can pretty much roll up any character you can imagine: from the stock races, such as Human, Vulcan, Romulan, Klingon, Betazoid, Trill, Orion, etc., to a custom alien race that you can define. There are also a lot of RP opportunites: Dabo(!), asteroid mining, ship interiors, and seasonal events. Just a lot of great stuff.- F2P Model: If I had to make a list of the most ethical F2P MMOs on the market... it would be a short list, but STO would be near the top. All of the story, PvE, and PvP content is free, as are all the updates. Most of the things Cryptic are making money off of are cosmetic items (uniforms, ship interiors/exteriors), ships (but the free ships are just as competitive), and services like inventory space, character slots, bank space, etc. The two things that I would count against it are the lockboxes, which can be easily ignored, and the two races locked behind a paywall, though with nearly infinite races available to you, it doesn't make much of a difference in my opinion. With a model like this, I've been happy to support it since I started playing.KHANS:- Sector Space: Initially, it's no big deal, but after some time you start to realize how unintuitive Sector Space can be, sectioned off the way it is. Can you land here, orbit, or do nothing? Why are there invisible walls in space? There's an event here, but is anyone participating? What does the event even entail? Cryptic have stated in the past that they want to give Sector Space an overhaul, which would be awesome, but we still have it for now.- Instance Stagnation: There are a lot of PvE and PvP instances to queue up for. People play a select few, but most have stagnated -- not from lack of players, just lack of interest. I'd much rather them not be there if no one's going to play them, so that Cryptic would be able to put more focus on the ones people still enjoy.- Community: Do yourself a favor and find a good fleet that you can get along with, because the community in STO, at least the vocal part, might just drive you insane. This is nothing new to online games, but it seems abnormal in a Trek game. Part of the reason might be how fragmented chat is in STO, which makes moderation rather difficult. Making chat universal across individual sectors would make things better, I think, but for now reading ESD chat might just make you go blind.I think that about covers it! Like I said, if you're a Star Trek fan, you owe it to yourself to give this a try, especially now that we're on the verge of a new expansion.Live long and prosper!

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												Oddly enough, I'm not a Trekkie by any stretch of the word (Star Wars diehard here), but this game is actually very fun. I will give a bullet list of the pros as well as the cons and hopefully it will be beneficial to those interested in playing this game:The Good-Extensive graphical settings-Space and ground combat-Robust character creator & outfits-Foundry (player-created) missions-Massive ships to customize and exploreFor a game that is five years old, it's actually holding up quite well. It doesn't compare in visuals to a more recent MMO such as Elder Scrolls Online, but it scales quite nicely and you can make it look fairly good by MMO standards. What sets this game apart from most MMOs is the dual gameplay of space and ground combat. It keeps the experience fresh and interesting as you are constantly jumping back and forth between shooting enemies with phasers to blowing ships into oblivion with your cruiser.Without a doubt, this is by far the most in-depth character creator I've ever experienced. There are a decent amount of presets for faces, but where it truly shines are the sliders. There literally is a slider for everything. You have control to make your character look the way you want and this will literally keep you busy adjusting and changing for hours. The amount of outfits is also quite extensive, although much of it is behind the gameshop currency. I was informed, however, that everything is obtaining in-game if you work for it.The tutorial for Starfleet was actually quite enjoyable, even if it was essentially a rip-off of the recently rebooted films. I didn't enjoy the Klingon tutorial nearly as much. Too stereotypical "bad guy" in my opinion. That aside, where the best content is actually found are the missions created by players, not the developers. I'm still not that high of a level, but by far the most fun I've had were completing foundry missions. They seem to scale to your level and they offer a decent amount of experience. Some can be rather long, so make sure to check the estimated time for completion at the beginning before starting.The Foundry creator seems to allow players to create and build virtually anything they want, so it leads to infinite amounts of quality content created by the players. Very smart and cost-effective as the best content generally is that which is made by the players, not the developers. Last but not least are the ships! Depending on your class will determine what class of ship is appropriate for you. Everything a Trekkie would expect is available in the game as well as plenty more. The ships are also massive with a fully-explorable bridge, crew deck, and various other locations. You can also change the appearance of the bridge as well as the exterior design of the ship and its colors.The Bad-Simplistic gameplay-Slow progression-Relatively steep learning curveDue to the scale of the game with the dual gameplay, the depth in both is rather lacking. While the space game is actually quite fun, it really is nothing more than a button masher so far. The ground experience is very much the same way, although it does have an RPG mode and a FPS mode to change how you shoot enemies to make it more engaging. I would have liked a better integration between ground and space similar to JTL in SWG where exploration in your ship isn't a different instance and multiple players take on various positions in one ship, instead of everybody being a captain of their own ship.After you reach level 10, the developer-made quests seem to either come to a close or trigger much less often. This will lead to you having to explore on your own doing patrols, foundry missions, PvE queues, or deepspace encounters. So far it would seem patrols might actually provide the best amount of EXP, although foundry missions are by far the most entertaining. I highly recommend leveling with a friend if you have one to join you.While the tutorial tries to do a decent job of explaining the foundation of the game, there is just too much to cover. As is the case with most older MMOs, you'll need to ask a lot of questions to players who do know or try researching on your own. I wouldn't let that veer you away from this game, however. So far, I've enjoyed it quite a bit. I had absolutely zero expectations going in and found myself pleasantly surprised by what the game offers.Final thoughts:Again, I'm not a Trekkie, so this is merely the perspective of someone who has played a lot of MMOs and found the features in this game to be quite pleasing. It is F2P, although everything seems to be obtainable through hard work (besides Borg, you need to be a lifetime member for that). The game is definitely worth visiting if you are just looking to have an interesting and diverse experience with plenty of content to keep you busy.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Before I talk about STO, let me quickly give you an idea of where I stood on MMOs and Star Trek as a franchise before I started playing this game. MMOs:I have tried pretty much every free-to-play MMO under the sun, and tried a couple paid ones as well. I've tried WoW--didn't care for it. Tried every Perfect World game—none of them grabbed me. The only MMO I sunk any time into before STO was City of Heroes/Villains. I played that game off and on for years and put hundreds of hours into it, and it was a fantastic experience. Still think it's one of the best MMOs ever made, and may it now rest in peace (P.S. NCsoft can go suck a fat one for shutting it down). Star Trek:Besides catching half an episode of Next Generation on TV as a kid here and there, I had never watched Star Trek. I was mostly indifferent about the franchise as a whole, and my vague childhood memories of Next Generation painted it as somewhat boring and confusing show. How wrong I was. Around the same time I was thinking about giving STO a shot I decided to watch a specific episode of Star Trek: The Original Series on Netflix because it was listed as a prime example of a now common science fiction trope on tvtropes.org. I've fallen into a deep, dark hole. I'm almost done with the original series, I've watched the first few episodes of Next Gen, and I've bought a Star Trek history book about the first 150 years of the federation. I'm a full-on trekkie now, apparently. Star Trek Online: So, the question is, how good is the game? My opinion is that it's very, very good, but that if  you don't like the source material you might not like the game either. It is pretty standard MMO fair in a lot of ways. You click on things, you hit hotbar keys, you click on glowy interact-able objects, etc. However, it does enough to differentiate itself that it winds up being a pretty great game, though it may not be different enough if you have no love for the source material. It's not, for instance, breaking into the new action MMO as hard as, say, TERA, but it does have a third-person shooting mode where you can 'aim' at enemies that I think is rather fun, and you have a dodge-roll by default. The game is split up into two modes of combat—ground mode, and ship mode. This is something that takes a little getting used to. For a while I really disliked the ship combat and wished it was nothing but ground, but after getting used to it, and after unlocking better ships and  more ship abilities, I've come to enjoy them both equally. Just give it time. And once you're at the point where you enjoy them both hopping back and forth between the two adds a lot of variety to the gameplay compared to any other MMO I've played. It's like every hour you're switching to a different game. The progression system has a few more layers to it than most MMOs thanks to that split in the combat. When you level up you're putting points into your captain, your ship, and the four members of your 'away team' that you bring with you on ground missions, and which provide hot-bar abilites during spaceship combat. You're getting loot for yourself and all your away team members, but also for your ship. Just the basic ship that everyone gets at the start will have gear slots for: tactical console, science console, engineering console, shield, engine, two fore weapons, one aft weapon. It only gets crazier from there as you start aquiring ships that have more weapon slots and more engineering consoles, and even hangars where you can put little dog-fighting ships that will fly out of your main ship and star wrecking stuff. Now, let's talk about your away team for a second. Having a squad of A.I. with you at all times is pretty cool, and makes you feel like a captain from the show. You can train them in different skills, and they're basically how you choose what ship abilities you want. On the ground they're another phaser to help you kill stuff, and they have abilities related to their class. You outfit them with gear, just like you do for yourself, and by employing old-school JRPG trickle-down economics, getting one great new gun could mean your whole away team is in for a slight upgrade As far as classes go, there's three, and they only really determine two things—what hotbar abilities you can get, and what skills you can train crew-members in (although you can also train them by 'using up' a new crew-member, which can be bought or received as a quest reward). Any class can use any weapon. So...yeah, I like this game a lot. It has a lot of easy to understand systems that are layered on top of each other to create something with a lot of depth. I love that I have more than just my own, single character's progression to focus on. When I level up I have to consider if I've been having trouble recently in space or on the ground, and drop points accordingly. You have to keep your away team in mind. That new gun that dropped might not be as good as yours, but is it better than something one of your guys has? Some people will hate this aspect of the game and think it busywork, but I love it. The world feels big, while actually being rather small and instanced. The sector map design when you go to warp looks cool as hell. There are references and fanservice dripping from every pore of this thing. If you like Star Trek at all, and you actively want to try and get into an MMO, you HAVE to give this a try.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												This might be one of the most disappointing games I have ever played, comming from the standpoint of a gamer. It is one of the poorest quality games out there in terms of bugs, both minor and game breaking, it has the most basic endgame, and pvp has never been, and likely never will be balanced. The graphics are overly taxing for their quality, and lag issues plague a percentage of players constantly. The only good things that I can say about this game from the view of a gamer, is that the free to play system is tastefully done. One does not need to pay a single penny in order to play and enjoy the entire game, but it is worth it if you do wish to pay. You can acquire credits for the real money store by just playing the game, so even though some of the items offter a small advantage, they are obtainable for anyone willing to invest the time (most notably end game ships). The other thing I find great about this game is that it is always adding new content, while not super amazing it is enjoyable for a time, and features some great voice acting talent, who would be familiar to anyone who knows Trek.This game becomes better from the standpoint of a fan of Star Trek, and is very much worth it to play if you are one. Overall I recommend this game to anyone who just wants to have fun with Star Trek, or for a casual gamer who just wants to have fun in general and does not care so much about overall game quality. I do not recommend this for a pure gamer just looking for another game to try, or for a unique gaming experience, because you will not find that here.I do feel it is fair to note that the game has lately increased in quality, while it does not yet change my opinion of it, It might become better in the future.It is free to try, so, why not?

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												This game is very good, once you get used to the controls and play style. I give is around an 8.5 out of 10. Graphics could be better, yes, but this is an MMO, and for what it is, I think they've done quite well with it. I love the pre- and post-warp cutscenes and the transporter animations most, and some of the storyline talking cutscenes the least.The free to play part is a plus, too. It's a quality game, definitely, and doesn't simply lock you out of portions of the game just because you're free to play while others are premium, in fact, with enough effort, I'm sure you could accumulate enough dilithium to trade for substantial amounts of the premium in-game money (zen), which you can then use to buy the bigger, better, shinier, more premium things in the game.On a personal note, I'm happy with the game, and I'll be happy to continue playing. The best part is, once I tire of Federation quests (if I do), I can just make another character and experience Klingon or Romulan quests (you have more than enough character slots to make characters for each side). I think it's great that there isn't an entire side locked up for premium/paying users' use only, I think (though some races -- like the Joined Trill -- are locked up).Being free to play, I feel perfectly safe suggesting this game to anyone. If you don't like it, all you have to do is stop playing, because you didn't have to spend money on the game in the first place!

content:
Posted: March 31
												When screenshots of the planned "Star Trek Online" game were first teased almost a decade ago, it looked like a simulator for living in the Star Trek universe, much like the original Star Wars online game experience before it got ruined by patches and so on. A true sandbox for Star Trek-ness. However, it was taken over by another developer, one known for making comic-like games and generally actionning and arcade-ing things up to the max. My heart sank, because my favourite Star Trek games before then were games that simulated life on board your starship of choice.Bridge Commander for PC was one of those games, I'd go back and download all the old Star Trek games now and then and play them just to see if any were good, and some were excellent. Another was the Interactive Technical Manual/Captain's Chair set of games, which made it so that you could walk through little 360-degree photograph simulations of the ships and learn all sorts of things about everyone. Also one game that gets little to no cred is the Elite Force expansion for PC also, which took the Star Trek Voyager game and made it so that you could explore the ship, mess with the systems, play on the holodecks, and so forth. It took a good 3 hours to push every switch, which isn't long, but it's a good slice of life if you want to experience a walking simulator about ST:VOY. Also the new VR game looks to have some of that spirit - maybe.Star Trek Online is the antithesis to all of that. There's no classic roaming about and taking in the scenery, no smelling the roses, and for some reason the corridors are ridiculously huge - all the bridges and so on are blown up to the size of small soccer fields, even the one for the shuttlecraft looks like a basketball court you could do laps in. It's inulting to me as a veteran gamer, since I'm stuck wondering - "what, are they expecting so many casual players who have never tried to play an online game before, that they had to make it so they wouldn't be frustrated walking into walls all the time? is it literally made for mentally challenged people?!" I've never seen a game put so much freaking walking space everywhere. The transporter pads which are supposed to be somewhat uncomfortable to stand on with 5-6 people are suddenly these huge affairs the size of a moderately-priced living room. O_o; smhNo, you could say that STO tries to bring back the feeling of Original Series Star Trek, with Kirk facing a new escapade each episode and generally the ships and life and so forth falling into the background. I used to despise the Original Series for being too fast and loose with ... well, logic itself, frankly. Sometimes, most of the time in fact, the things the crew encounters and their reactions to it make a lot of sense. But now and then there was just no sense to what they were doing at all, and what my mom calls "60s values" were everywhere - people getting angry for absolutely no reason, being "chivalrous" (almost mocking) towards female crew members, and so on. I've recently watched TOS in its completeness and I have a much greater appreciation for it now, I found the fun in it as it were. But even Roddenberry seemed to back off from the feeling of the original, considering the way that the early Trek movies became almost pedantic affairs about Shakespeare and philosophy and politics. I like those best I think, out of all the Trek stuff that's been created, but this game seems to mostly if not entirely abandon those principles in favor of BANG! BANG! Space cowboys to the rescue!The thing is, it works. The Next Generation, Deep Space Nine, and Voyager all seemed to want to be saying something more fun and action-oriented than they actually did, esepcially in the episodes involving scary new species or little special events featuring warzones. It's like there was this anxious little boy hidden away inside the hearts of the producers, and every now and then he'd come out and for several episodes we'd just have a general romp around the galaxy, with torpedoes blasting around and so on. That's where Star Trek Online shines. It takes the time period from those series and tries to make it work as a series of TV-style episodes, which are crystallized into about a dozen quest chains (yes, that's all there is in the game for my faction, but they are relatively long - several hours at minimum each, more like 12-20 hours for some). Want to see Denise Crosby finally getting some serious attention in any Trek franchise? Well, here her performance as Empress Sela is charming and impeccable.The difference between STO and the actual TV shows is that while some of the best story arcs in the entire Star Trek universe - all the 29th century nonsense, the Year of Hell characters, the DS9 take on the Mirror Universe, and so on - were mostly ignored after their individual episodes and two-parters, the creators of Star Trek Online took the most interesting and audacious ideas and expanded them into significant things which affect everyone on a daily basis almost. More fun, more action, more romping around, more crazy conspiracies and interesting intrigue than the shows were usually willing to do. If the original shows were vanilla-flavored, this is artisinal chocolate with jalapeno sauce. The difference between fan theories and the actual material, especially when it comes to Star Trek fans, is that the fans come up with intellectual extensions that make it cool for nerds but are impossible to justify when you're marketing to a general audience who are just expecting to turn on their television sets and get a decent story. This does the fun nerdy "footnotes section at the Memory Alpha wiki" stuff that hopefully you've wanted to see (if you're a Trekkie).I tend to love and play (and review!) games which are kinda poopy when taken as a chance to fulfill one's hopes and dreams about what a person can do in a virtual world, but are immensely enjoyable when played on their own terms. This is a game which is best played on its own terms. It tries to take the pre-reboot storyline and tie it together with almost everything that's ever been created in Star Trek.. happening all at once, in a coherent storyline. For the most part, the writers (who are these gods?) manage to tie a whole bunch of ridiculously contrived continuities from the creators into something much more coherent than it originally was. It might slip past you if you don't care about the plot or aren't paying enough attention, but seriously, this game turns BAD (with a capital B!) episodes from the TV shows into something that makes sense and can actually form a long story that ties in with others. Play it for the episodes and very little else, and you'll find a fanfiction-style work that ties things together with amazing detail.My only real complaint is that literally nobody plays the PVP anymore, as far as I can tell. Want to use that amazing new ship you bought for more than your own personal masturbation in the latest quest line to be released? Well, tough. Apparently enough people ruined it early in the lifecycle of the game that you just can't find anyone to play with anymore. The PVE Queues the game has, where everyone defends against the Borg or whatnot, are full 24/7, and an excellent way to level (you can get 90% to the level cap within 12 hours if you just keep running them!). However, the PVP queues are at zero, zero, zero, zero, zero for every match type, all day and all night, with little to no flukes where there are suddenly more people in them. There's just nothing. I really wanted to try PVP even if it sucked, but I guess it's back to living through some pretty interesting Star Trek episodes for me. :) Which is both a blessing and a curse, as is most of this game.Accept STO as the flawed piece of semi-trash that it is, and you'll find plenty of treasures within, it just might be best to wait for enjoying them until you're in the mood to appreciate something that might not be perfect.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Big, lore-heavy (and Lore light), and goofy. It's not the subtle intergallactic diplomacy styling of the TV shows; Star Trek Online takes more after the movies with more action and more conflict.This isn't a bad thing, the space combat has become more and more satisfying over the years and the complexity of situations improve every mission.The ground combat has improved enough to be fine, but isn't the most enjoyable part of the game. This is where the crew you bring on missions are helpful; they balance a lot of the quirks out and allow for some customization. In reality, if you take ground combat partially seriously it's alright and there's no real penalty for wiping on mission so the problems are ignorable.Since the game has been around for a few years, the ships available are many and wonderful. If you wanted to fly ships from the Dominion War perfect! Want to play a period-specific Enterprise from earlier shows and movies? They have that too. Everything comes with balance considerations, but careful outfitting and a casual play style make many of them servicable or at least different.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												I had a lot of fun with this game, and I never paid anything but my time. If you are a Star Trek fan, you have nothing to lose, and you'll probably enjoy what they've done with the franchise and your personal story. I was tempted to buy cosmetic upgrades because I am a nerd ("Ooh they have Kirk's jacket from Wrath of Khan! I want it!"), but I never felt like I had to pay in order to win. You definitely CAN - you can pay real money to buy upgraded ships with special technology - but I never felt pressured to do so.I really like the crew management element of the game - essentially, the special abilities of your ship are determined by your bridge officers. Bridge officers can be requisitioned from Starfleet or acquired on missions, which I thought was a nice touch. You can customize your bridge officers appearances in a very satisfying way, from their appearance and uniform to their stance. I got a boring Trill medical officer and made him much more interesting by making him twitchy and neurotic. Once you've customized a uniform for yourself or an officer, it's easy to save the outfit and apply it to whoever you want.The rest of your crew - rank and file - are mostly just pegs you can shuffle around to complete timed tasks and projects, with a variety of little rewards. I enjoyed this 'Starfleet Spreadsheet Simulator' in kind of a perverse way, sending my little dudes to formulate warp bubble theories and whatnot, but it's mostly a time-waster.The main problem with the gameplay is this: the ship-to-ship combat is much more polished than the away missions, but away missions are where you will spend most of your time. The on-foot sections of the game have very awkward and inconsistent level design. If I could delegate those bits to my redshirts, I would mostly do it, and enjoy the game more.I put it down when I didn't feel like playing it anymore, and I haven't picked it up again since, but I enjoyed the time I spent playing it. It didn't feel addictive or manipulative.tl;dr : Try it if you like Star Trek. It's actually free and not fee-to-pay.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												If you want an honest detailed review on a game that has been around forever. Then here it is. Star Trek Online is a game that requires an Enigma!. It is begging for a STO2 reboot. Simple put it is a  game is set in the 25th century, 30 years after the events of Star Trek: Nemesis.[4] Star Trek Online is the first massively multiplayer online role-playing game within the Star Trek franchise that has some wonderful pros for free players and a lot of cons for players as well.A good mmo.PROSA: Space Oombat even today is wonderfully done and fun to watch. Fast paced and great effects for its time.B: Alot of small games meshed together, tactical, strategy, like Duty rosters with its own game, research with its own game and crafting. A lot to do, with so little time.C: Visually a gorgeous game for Star Trek fans, capturing the "Next Generation" colors, panels and sounds. D: Plenty of story mode straight through missions. You like choices you have them. Even a foundry to create your own misisons. However it is down for upgrading I am toldE: Solid game control, graphics and easily adaptable even by the older systems around.F; Custom character building with 3 playable factions and 100s of character designs, play as a ferengi, romulan or even a orion. Plenty of character choices to please even the loyal ST fan or novice player.G: Exploration, fun planets to discover, and wonderful bases and visuals. Fleet system to build on your own or join massive established guilds.CONS and there are plentyA: Game has alot of fragmented games and unfinished ideasB: grinding can be too annoying for you to stay withC: Bad decision initially to have your main character a mute, unlike lets say KOTOR which your character speaks and is central to the choices and actions of the storylines your involved in.D: Poor voice quality, however some classic voice acting, great to hear a Leonard Nimoy or the classic Mrs. Roddenberry's computer voice, Stars from the shows narating missions. So some good and bad there.E: Ways around all issues. Huge learning curve with the total gameplay, but easy to pick up after a weekF: Lousy promotion system in that it is way too quick to move up. Your an admiral in a day. You will learn that T6 ships rule and you will be screaming for a free one, Guess what join a fleet ask how to get big credits fast and you should have one in a week. That simple.G: PVP is terrible for a ST game amd you may get tired of the grinding. It is all Dill, dill is gold, so wasting it is an ugly option. However there are tricks to getting rich and getting dil, like all games if you ask.OVERALL: In my opnion, this is a game for Star Trek lovers, mmos have their pros and cons and if your already heavy in one another maybe too much. If you don't like Star Trek, then this one is not for you. I commend the years of effort to make this game. They deserve credit for such an accomplishment. However, the engine they chose to build on, just too many mistakes to overcome. Star Trek Online is dieing for a reboot like Guild Ways, but for FREE, not a bad game to try. See the workshop for gameplay videos to look before trying. The newer your system the easier it is to play, but even the old Vistas and older models handled the game just fine. Star Trek Online is a good game, with plenty to like and plenty not to like. Good enough for a thumbs up and free is never a bad thing.MY SCORE 2.5 out of 5

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												This might be one of the most disappointing games I have ever played, comming from the standpoint of a gamer. It is one of the poorest quality games out there in terms of bugs, both minor and game breaking, it has the most basic endgame, and pvp has never been, and likely never will be balanced. The graphics are overly taxing for their quality, and lag issues plague a percentage of players constantly. The only good things that I can say about this game from the view of a gamer, is that the free to play system is tastefully done. One does not need to pay a single penny in order to play and enjoy the entire game, but it is worth it if you do wish to pay. You can acquire credits for the real money store by just playing the game, so even though some of the items offter a small advantage, they are obtainable for anyone willing to invest the time (most notably end game ships). The other thing I find great about this game is that it is always adding new content, while not super amazing it is enjoyable for a time, and features some great voice acting talent, who would be familiar to anyone who knows Trek.This game becomes better from the standpoint of a fan of Star Trek, and is very much worth it to play if you are one. Overall I recommend this game to anyone who just wants to have fun with Star Trek, or for a casual gamer who just wants to have fun in general and does not care so much about overall game quality. I do not recommend this for a pure gamer just looking for another game to try, or for a unique gaming experience, because you will not find that here.I do feel it is fair to note that the game has lately increased in quality, while it does not yet change my opinion of it, It might become better in the future.It is free to try, so, why not?

So I probably have a couple weeks worth of actual game play time.I used to like this game and I will always be a Star Trek fan but as much as I wanted this game to suceed it has always fell short.  One it's left many promises unfulfilled even after years and the fans asking again and again doesn't matter.  What made the game good was it's stories which made me feel like I was in a interactive Star Trek episode but they have now all but stopped the featured episodes in favor of these large exploration zones, that would be alright if a player felt like they were accomplishing something but for example the Dyson Sphere your given a general objective clear out the enemies you do that and the enemies just keep respawning beind you in the same place making it feel like you're accomplishing nothing, no sense of progression.  There is no real attachment to your crew or ship, this is one of the unfullfilled promises from the developers, other than the bridge variants the rest the ship is exacty the same no matter what class or size ship you are in, there is nothing really interactive or things to do inside the ship and doors and hallways are disproportationaly large making it feel off.  One of the worst things they implemented was the Doff system which makes the make feel like Facebook's Farmville where the player has to constantly log in every few hours to re-que missions to earn better equimplent and skills.  These Doff missions also require resources which require grinding of a few missions hundreds of times to det top tier, this gets boring real fast.  The game has severly suffered from lack of PVP, it's in there just there is no real point to it and it's not really fun with no real rewards to playing it.  One of the worst is Cryptic won't let you post any negative feedback on their forums about game improvement or critiques doing so will get the person a warning or banned.  There's a lot more but like I said I really wanted the game to succeed but it's just not going to happen.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Now there are a multitude of problems that rear its head with Star Trek Online: Glitches Galore, Not much in game benefits for being part of a fleet, Starfleet feels really obsolete when you unlock the ability to become part of the KDF and Romulan Empire and the pretty much very similar story missions even if you are part of a different faction. This game screams "Generic MMO" and has done for its 5 year life cycle. There is one thing though that no other Star Trek licensed or really any Licensed Sci-Fi games have ever done, Made you feel like the Captain of your very own ship and your very own crew that you build yourself through hours of work. For so long i have craved a game that could make me feel like i was part of such a universe like Star Trek's and that i could create my own story and be that Starfleet/KDF/Romulan Captain. If i am quite honest if you are someone looking for an MMO and do not have the faintest idea of Star Trek's lore or have no interest in Sci-Fi then turn away as this will be frustrating and excruciating to the core. But for those who want "To boldly go where no man has gone before" and are self declared members of Starfleet then this game will provide hours upon hours of entertainment, even with the games numerous issues. I should know, I have played the blasted game for almost 195 Hours...

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												I've played this game for 700 hours, and have played this game to win. I've played this game to max out my level, achieve the highest score, get the most out of my characters. Before I explain why I dont like this game,I would recommend this game if you are looking to have a fun time, if you are a casual gamer and a star trek nerd, you should definately give this game a shot. You can play through the campaign and have fun with your friends easily without spending a dime. Anything beyond that, I am not so sure, unless you like grinding your organs to mush. So, if you are in it for fun, and not to win it, then absolutely go on and download this game, skip the rest of what I have to say. Now, if the above does not apply to you, I would not recommend this game if you are looking to do what I did in this game, play to win. Before I start my review of the game as a whole, which might turn into a rant, let me say one major turnoff to all non-casual gamers, and that is that this game is SUPER DUPER POOPER SCOOPER Pay 2 Win, it's really pay 2 win, and every update that the devs stick into the disgrace of a game that it is right now, make it more and more pay 2 win.Originally created in a sort of rock paper scissors manner where you needed different classes of ships and types of captains to win in pvp or pve, (which mainly become the game after the storyline, and becomes a repetitive grind anyhow), the developers are slowly getting rid of this concept. It is common knowledge among all veteran players of this game that all that matters if you really want to win, is DPS. The usefulness of players that run ships like cruisers and science ships is so miniscule compared to those of escorts (the tactical officers main ship), and high dps cruisers, a more recent addition, (disgusting imo), that at high levels, after long hours of grinding, you will find yourself obsolete as anything but an escort player or tactical officer. This problem is so large that you will find that when you enter PvP especially, that players will exploit the broken game mechanics enormously, pairing different equipments, bonuses, and abilities, (there are so damn many), in ways that they are not intended, but allowed by the developers, that they are impossible to beat. The exploitation of everything at high ranks, the balancing of statistics to get the most out of escorts and such, really retracts from the star trek atmosphere. There are so many flaws I can go on and on about in the game, and before I run out of breath talking about this one flaw, exploitation, ill just lay them all out for you:1. Players exploit the game at high levels2. The game is unbalanced for different playstyles at higher levels3. Most players are at max level so you cant do anything in pvp 4. After you finish a set of missions, you will find yourself grinding the same PvE events for countless hours for just a few pieces of borg tech for example, unless you deem yourself a wallet warrior. 5. The in-game economy is very limited and boring.6. The actual storyline is repetitive and sparse.7. Broken game mechanics brings little variety to ships (if they want to win and be useful)8. They are always adding new ways to spend money or grind your organs to mush, they add plenty of new ships, plenty of new equipment, and new missions to get equipment, they hardly work on REALLY fixing the game and polishing it's mechanics. Instead of revisiting problems, they will simply expand. For example, if cruisers are underpowered because tanking and drawing fire is useless in PvE, they simply increase the damage of cruisers) 9. Besides the main storyline, side missions or personal missions are just as boring and typical, almost 100% of them are just rinse and repeat. Go shoot some ships, shoot some people on the ground, and run around pressing F to do some scan sci-fi stuff.10. Did I mention scans and the F key? Yes, everything besides shooting♥♥♥♥♥♥up, (which is easy because your character and ship locks onto everything automatically, making every enemy encounter just repeated buttons to press over and over, even with autofire on you are simply using your simple and boring abilities over and over to kill your enemy, waiting for abilities to recharge, rinse and repeat, rinse and repeat, grind GRIND GRIND!!!!Sorry, went on a bit of a tangent. Anyway back to the F key. Anything besides shooting♥♥♥♥♥♥up is basically going around, pressing the F key, whether you are healing wounded patients or scanning asteroids, you simply press the F key and wait for the bar to reach 100% and yay thats all. This isn't completely true, there are a few things in the campaign and side missions and stuff in the game that require a bit of skill, but 90% of these tasks have the same mechanics, and the way they are set up (easy as hell and boring to tears), you can probably set up a couple of macros to solve them anyway if you really cared. There are only a few instances in the newer campaigns that aren't the same damn easy puzzle, repeated over and over. The only useful mini-game is the one that you use to go dilithium mining, and that one is... Ok. :)Back on course, I think the #1 problem is the broken mechanics at higher levels:You will encounter players using dyson ships (completely STO-unique ships), firing romulan weapons (disruptors), using only beam weapons, (because multi-weapon ships are useless besides the occasional special weapon, and torpedoes are largely useless too thank you game mechanics), using borg ship modules, while using tholian engines and shields. Now this above issue isn't just an isolated thing, like you will see one in a handful of people doing this. Absolutely not, unless you are a low level player that doesn't know what he is doing, when you achieve higher ranks of Admiral, which everyone does pretty quickly, you will find that everyone is forced to do completely uncharacteristic things. You will find starfleet ships using antiproton weapons, and only antiproton cannons, or only antiproton beams, because adding a torpedo to a weapons slot would be useless, as torpedoes are quite useless without wasting plenty of skill points on them anyway and you need those skill points for beam weapons becuase torpedoes do nothing against enemy shields. (I could go farther but that would probably bore you)The worst thing that ever happened to this game was Perfect World Entertainment acquiring it from the original creators, Cryptic Studios. From the stories told by my clan mates, who have played this game from the creation, the game was a lot better, focused a lot less on giveusmoneygiveusmoneygiveusmoneygiveusmoney with PWE.I quit it a bit ago after getting fed up with all of the♥♥♥♥♥♥updates that were just excuses for PWE to make more money.

content:
Posted: March 6
												I've played over 200 hours of this game. There is SO MUCH to it. From the moment you create your captain you're at the centrre of a canon storyline, and the game doesn't fail to deliver. EVERY star trek fan should want to sit in a captain's chair though, and doesn't need me to convince them. There is a little something for everyone though. It may sound like a silly aspect to judge, but the single player value to this MMO is insane, which is rare. Weather you party up, pvp, pve, RP, farm, grind or seriously roam around to take the sights it's easy to find something to do. Not just for star trek fans, but as a trekkie obviously worth checking out. Pay to play aspects coupled with ruthless marketing take away from the enjoyment, though everthing purchasable with money is possible to farm or grind for - albeit very tediously. My advice, spend your time having fun with the game until you unlock the end game ships, save up enough game currency to buy keys for lockboxes in auctions and try your luck for high tier ships that way. I ended up purchasing a t6 ship as a reward for hitting the level cap with no regrets. Best:High level of customization and choice 3rd person gameplay while on planet is good, if a little generic. But space battle mechanics are AWESOME. Best space battles in an online game by far imo. Story and lore written in star trek canon, lots of interesting locations, characters and situations trekkies will recognise, but it's not necessary to be familliar with literally any of it in order to enjoyMostly friendly communityGreat graphics, music, voice work, UI, controls, tutorials and a very large, interesting world to exploreDifficult gameplay - not just a matter of spamming a rotation of class abilities-there are tactics involved.Worst:Dev support has left much to be desired, although just for things like gameplay bugs. Community support and store support are dependable. Frequent updates and patching - means more down time, more bugs. Unfortunately most of the updates are made to the store and are designed to make players want to spend money. This would not bother me if previous updates were more stable before attention was made to updating again. A bit buggy. Shouldn't have to explain this. Nothing that breaks the game, but I've had to restart missions enough times that I should probably mention it. Freemium. Hate this. I know it's the future but it takes away from the enjoyment for everyone except the people it exploits. If you don't let this get to you, and indeed it is not SO bad compared to other freemium games, the purchasable items are excellent and there is a large attention to detail and value. Before you purchase anything I reccommend unlocking the lvl 60 ships or higher first. Overall the game is not perfect, may have been better as a subscription game, kinda lost its soul a little bit because of in game purchasing - but the developers and community have managed to keep the game very fun despite the small hangups. The engine and mechanics in this game alone are worth checking out. For the record, this is the only MMO that I've held even remote interest in for more than 6 months. Long story short: It's free, fun as hell, and the main problem is that without spending insane amounts of time mining or spending real money you really can't compare to the players that do. If anyone who plays it and doesn't enjoy it wants their $0.00 back I'll happily refund.

												I would recommend this game to those who enjoy space battle games, MMOs, or specifically Star Trek! The game contains a lot of elements I enjoy, lacks in a few areas, but mostly is a great game! I tend to take my time, with my own method of how I play the game, making logs for every mission I do. Like an actual Starfleet Officer would do, as far as I know. The whole Star Trek franchise is my 3rd favorite (set of) show(s). The games story throws me off, the Federation allied or has a peace treaty with both the Klingons and the Romulans, I don't know why they are considered enemies. Especially when the 3 sides that you can be on, don't really fight one another. I haven't gotten much into the campaign yet to really know and understand the story, but as far as I can tell, I just enjoy being able to be a Starfleet Officer and having my own ship, and of course making my own logs.Issues I have with this game:1. You can't customize your ship fully. You can, somewhat, but I wish there was a more detailed way to modify your ship.2. You can't change your first officers information. This kind of bugged me, I wish I could change my first officers details just as I can change my first officers appearance, but the game doesn't allow it.3. You can't train your officers in like a holodeck program, which I wish you could build your own training programs and have access to a holodeck program. That way you can train your officers and even earn experience for yourself, maybe?4. You have to buy a lot of things with no free way really to earn a few Zen coins every now and then.Other than the issues I have with the game, the game is really fun and enjoyable! Even for a MMO. Although having it a single player game would have been cooler, that way they probably would of payed attention to how you build your ship, or design your character, and all of that rather than focusing on how the PVP system will work. Like with most MMO's, you can't really summarize the story without going through most of the game. So I can't summarize the story for this game.
