content:
Posted: June 17, 2013
												An all around good game in many ways. First off you have three factions, all with at least a few races in each. Both ground and space combat are solid however space combat is easily the better of the two. There is of course the Federation, the Klingons, and the newest faction which are the Romulans.The Romulans have a story of liberation and resistance against a nearly rogue sect of the now shattered Romulan Star Empire. You fly warbirds which at each new rank grant you a new ability only usable on warbirds. All of them can cloak and a later version can even split into two.The downfall of the Romulans in my eye is that they have no great massive ship of their own. I find the Ha'apax Advanced Warbird a bit lacking in that department. And even though you are in fact forced to join either the Federation or Klingons you cannot actually gain access to their T4 and higher ships. So I must recommend a mightier faction, one of glory and honor. The Klingon Empire.The Klingon story is far more diverse and even includes a small portion of the Romulan story, even including the Romulan end mission around lv32. The story ranges from house rivalries and betrayals to the return of Klingon enemies from ancient lore among other interesting developments. The Klingons are a faction with many mighty ships designed for head-on combat that have hull strength only rivaled by ships you'd have to spend $150 opening gambling boxes to get your hands on. And this does not even diminish their offensive capabilities as their greatest ship is a carrier armed just as well as any warship.The Fedration offers little that can compare to the might of the Klingon Empire. Their ships seem to be designed around a doctrine of agility as many of their ships are far smaller but probably just as effective in combat if used properly.There is also a system for crew missions, where you deploy your crew to go do things like sacking a colony, bribery, espionage, fighting in tournaments, trade agreements, asteroid mining for arguably the most valuable currency dilithium, among other tasks. These all net rewards which vary by the rarity of the mission, its difficulty, who's on it, and of course what the mission is in the first place determines the base set of rewards. You can even send one of your crew to be executed for incompetence as a Klingon, which even though its useless is just great to have sitting there as an option.The visuals are good, the game hasn't crashed once for me, the UI is customizable.All in all, a great MMO.

Product received for free
												Very fun game, i love all of the customization options such as customizing your ship's look and color, to changing how your player and officers look. It has a great star trek feel to the story missions also, almost like you are in the show instead of just watching it. Also the gameplay is really fun, from flying your ship, or going on away missions. Another thing i really liked was all of the references to the shows ( TNG, Voyager, DS9, TOS, Enterprise and the movies) not to mention all of the actors who have voiced their characters in the game. (Michael Dorn, Robert Picardo, Tim Russ, Aron Eisenburg, Jeri Ryan, Walter Koenig, Leonard Nimoy, and others as well. Overall, i highly recommend this game for anyone who likes Star Trek or just a good space game. Although knowing the star trek universe really adds a whole new layer to the game.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												I played Cryptic's Star Trek Online from launch and witnessed all the changes including the newest Expansion Delta Rising. It has drastically changed over time, for the most part not positive.First of all, in my opinion, this game has little in common with the spirit of the original Star Trek series and films.It is a standard MMORPG on a generic engine that happens to be in a cartoonish colored version of the Star Trek Universe. You mainly run/fly around click on static dialogs and kill millions of enemies. SpaceAs the game reaches its 5th anniversary, Cryptic's Star Trek Online universe grew to an acceptable size. Unfortunately it is not an unlimited and contigous space. Instead this overall 2D universe is devided into 3D "Sector Blocks" (maps) with unpassable hard borders, so that you are hopping from one block to another beiing shown a loading screen as you are travaling through it.In addition, every map gets instanced, if a certain player limit (i tthink 20-40 players) is reached, so that you never will experience the massiveness of MMORPG.GroundI'll skip the ground part. I think, it does not differ much from every other game of this kind except that heavy "instancing" and "zoning".Revenue ModelIn theory, the Free to Play acccess grants access to the whole content, but you'll be disapointed rapidly. In fact the free access is restricted to storyline, all areas and basic equipment and few basic ships. Everything else has to be either bought or exchanged/upgraded in exchange for diverse in-game currencies. It is possible to earn them, but it is an endless, monotonous, boring and repetitive "grinding" and Cryptic did set a limit for a daily income of the main currency called refined dillithium, You are forced to came back and login every day to earn it and even then you will be always short of it. Or simply buy them for real money.Then you have the c-store where you can buy expansion packs, items, most ships and "services" which expand your account with real money or exchanges refined dillithium.Furthermore Cryptic invented a lottery/ casino system for special items and ships packed in boxes with unpublished win chances, but they are told to be very, very small. You can participate with using real money among others and can't be sure to ever win.With the latest Expansion "Delta Rising" the costs for high-rank equipment increased drastically. And you badly need it to successfully participate in the end-game elite content, where practically the only important ability is, to deal the most damage per second (dps) to the enemy.ConclusionSo if you don't want to stuck at easy difficulty in pre-endgame state, the game ends up being either a second job/chore to earn all currencies/materials/marks/... or a serious cash investment for virtual stuff and Cryptic's casino with equivalent nofun-factor.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												Personally I found this game quite enjoyable. I am a big fan of Star Trek, both then new movies and the tv series. But here are my pros and cons for this game.Pros: 1: Large expansive map with loads of planets and systems to explore.        2: Many ships, weapons, costumes and species to play and experiment with.        3: The ship-to-ship combat is enjoyable and fitting for any play style.Cons: 1: Ground combat is far from perfect. It has its moments but those a few and far apart.          2: Since the game is free-to-play, it will insist on flashing ads in your face at almost every loading screen.          3: The servers can be a bit jumpy and unresponsive at times but after a few seconds they manage to fix themselves.Finally my final verdict: This game is good. Not great but not bad. Its really has its moments if you are a fan the the series. To any Star Trek fans who are considering this game I can heartily recommend it and to any others, why not give it a shot. Its pretty good for a free game.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												I'll recommend the game as a mildly amusing way to burn an afternoon, seeing as how it was free.  Mildly amusing, that is, if you play Klingon.  You get the option to run about smacking Vulcans and Bolians with a bat'telh and then blow away some much heavier Federation ships in need of an attitude adjustment.  Even on Klingon side, after I smoked a Chimera dreadnaught (one of the biggest boats out there) in a B'rel Bird of Prey (the starter ship) I felt very much like I'd seen everything there was to see here.Playing Federation, on the other hand, was just insultingly silly.  Going from the academy to the captain's chair in the space of an afternoon, in the company of your bubbleheaded teenybopper classmates who all seem to think they're going to be captains too sometime soon, just wrecks all suspension of disbelief.  As does taking an old clunker of a training ship out, running into a Borg cube, and NOT getting owned in five seconds.  Sorry, I don't see how I'm supposed to take that seriously as either a Trek fan or a newcomer just looking to blow stuff up in space.A few very notable nice touches, though the memorial to the Star Trek actors and crew who have passed away was both touching and depressing (the list of names is really, really long...).  It was fun for a bit, and can't say I won't go hunting Feds again in the future, but don't wait up for me.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Short review: This game is absolutely worth your time.  The crafting system is simplistic, the build mechanics complex enough to provide lots of diversity, and the ship battles are ultimately quite fun and engaging in ways that few other MMOs can manage.  The game's bugs and shortfalls (ground combat in particular) are more than compensated by the range of content and useful ways to spend your time, and this MMO is among a very select few MMOs which has an in-game system designed to reward you even when you're not playing.  Since it's all free, it's worth your time to try it out.If that's all you needed to see, then you can stop reading here.However, I want to spend the bulk of this review explaining the "negative" reviews you see, because they all stem from the same common attitude that an increasing number of gamers tend to suffer from: an unwillingness to put forth the effort to EARN things.Something you may notice about this game is that many of the top negative reviewers have two things in common:1) They're mostly bashing the studio (not the actual game) for perceived slights and its "pay to win model".2) Despite their supposed hatred of the game, they've sunk hundreds if not thousands of hours into it anyways.It's not as hard to understand how this is possible, if you spend a bit of time playing the game for yourself.  STO is, simply put, a lot of fun to play, and this is something many of these negative reviews either ignore or begrudgingly admit somewhere in the footnotes of their massive rants against the game's payment structure.This is, of course, mostly misplaced rage from people who either don't understand the currency system or lack any semblance of patience (the "gimme" crowd that is all too common to MMOs).The payment system is relatively simplistic: Everything that can be bought for real money uses the "zen" currency (at a rate of $1 per 100 zen).  Some ships and a multitude of other ship devices and items cost dilithium, which is obtained in-game for free at a relatively slow pace.  This game also features a trade system whereby you can trade zen for dilithium and vice versa, meaning that anything you can buy for real money could potentially be bought entirely for free, with enough time and patience.It takes a LOT of dilithium to do this, naturally (usually 150 dil for 1 zen), so you will be doing some grinding for it.  However, the grinding is not that bad by comparison to typical MMO grinding as dilithium can be obtained several ways (dilithium farming can be done through a variety of daily quests across the entire universe, as well as through duty officer missions and PvE queues).  The only real limiting factor is the fact that you can only produce 8k "refined" dilithium per day, per character (and dilithium must be refined in order to exchange it for zen), which generally doesn't prove to be much of a problem for me.If I were to pick at anything, it would be that the Zen-based costs of ships do feel prohibitively high (ranging from 500 to 3k zen, or $5-$30), but this is primarily a consequence of the fact that they are account-wide ship unlocks (meaning any character of yours in that same faction gets access to them), as well as the fact that dilithium can be used to supplement part or all of these costs with enough time and patience.  The people who are whining about Cryptic's "pay to win" model are mostly complaining because these items cannot be obtained for free very easily if you lack the time or patience to put in the work for them.  In my own experience with many MMOs, this one is hardly as "pay-to-win" as they want it to sound.  Cryptic gives you a chance at a unique top-tier ship via the lockbox system if you're willing to spend your dilithium on keys for the lockboxes instead.  And on top of that, they even throw events which allow you to unlock a top-tier ship entirely for free (such as during Q's Winter Wonderland) with enough time put in.So suffice it to say you can do far, far worse than STO if you want to talk "pay to win".  This game by no means fits that bill, not when you can buy anything in the real money store for free with enough hard work.  It's attitudes like those of the "popular" negative votes against this game which help fuel the stereotype of "gamer entitlement" that many often refer to.  Truthfully, this is a great game, and you ought not to let these people fool you into thinking otherwise.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												For years my favorite Star Trek game was Birth of the Federation, but this is the first title to unseat that position. It's also my first MMORPG, a category that I was never interested until I decided to install STO. Boy, am I glad I decided to give this one a try. The fact that it's free to play gets rid of a major obstacle. If you enjoy the rich world created by Gene Roddenberry and built upon by hundreds of other writers and artists, you may love this game. The developers of this game clearly studied the various Trek series and have infused the game with that knowledge. Playing through various missions sometimes feels like getting to watch a new episode of Trek, only this time it's starring yourself!

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Short review: This game is absolutely worth your time.  The crafting system is simplistic, the build mechanics complex enough to provide lots of diversity, and the ship battles are ultimately quite fun and engaging in ways that few other MMOs can manage.  The game's bugs and shortfalls (ground combat in particular) are more than compensated by the range of content and useful ways to spend your time, and this MMO is among a very select few MMOs which has an in-game system designed to reward you even when you're not playing.  Since it's all free, it's worth your time to try it out.If that's all you needed to see, then you can stop reading here.However, I want to spend the bulk of this review explaining the "negative" reviews you see, because they all stem from the same common attitude that an increasing number of gamers tend to suffer from: an unwillingness to put forth the effort to EARN things.Something you may notice about this game is that many of the top negative reviewers have two things in common:1) They're mostly bashing the studio (not the actual game) for perceived slights and its "pay to win model".2) Despite their supposed hatred of the game, they've sunk hundreds if not thousands of hours into it anyways.It's not as hard to understand how this is possible, if you spend a bit of time playing the game for yourself.  STO is, simply put, a lot of fun to play, and this is something many of these negative reviews either ignore or begrudgingly admit somewhere in the footnotes of their massive rants against the game's payment structure.This is, of course, mostly misplaced rage from people who either don't understand the currency system or lack any semblance of patience (the "gimme" crowd that is all too common to MMOs).The payment system is relatively simplistic: Everything that can be bought for real money uses the "zen" currency (at a rate of $1 per 100 zen).  Some ships and a multitude of other ship devices and items cost dilithium, which is obtained in-game for free at a relatively slow pace.  This game also features a trade system whereby you can trade zen for dilithium and vice versa, meaning that anything you can buy for real money could potentially be bought entirely for free, with enough time and patience.It takes a LOT of dilithium to do this, naturally (usually 150 dil for 1 zen), so you will be doing some grinding for it.  However, the grinding is not that bad by comparison to typical MMO grinding as dilithium can be obtained several ways (dilithium farming can be done through a variety of daily quests across the entire universe, as well as through duty officer missions and PvE queues).  The only real limiting factor is the fact that you can only produce 8k "refined" dilithium per day, per character (and dilithium must be refined in order to exchange it for zen), which generally doesn't prove to be much of a problem for me.If I were to pick at anything, it would be that the Zen-based costs of ships do feel prohibitively high (ranging from 500 to 3k zen, or $5-$30), but this is primarily a consequence of the fact that they are account-wide ship unlocks (meaning any character of yours in that same faction gets access to them), as well as the fact that dilithium can be used to supplement part or all of these costs with enough time and patience.  The people who are whining about Cryptic's "pay to win" model are mostly complaining because these items cannot be obtained for free very easily if you lack the time or patience to put in the work for them.  In my own experience with many MMOs, this one is hardly as "pay-to-win" as they want it to sound.  Cryptic gives you a chance at a unique top-tier ship via the lockbox system if you're willing to spend your dilithium on keys for the lockboxes instead.  And on top of that, they even throw events which allow you to unlock a top-tier ship entirely for free (such as during Q's Winter Wonderland) with enough time put in.So suffice it to say you can do far, far worse than STO if you want to talk "pay to win".  This game by no means fits that bill, not when you can buy anything in the real money store for free with enough hard work.  It's attitudes like those of the "popular" negative votes against this game which help fuel the stereotype of "gamer entitlement" that many often refer to.  Truthfully, this is a great game, and you ought not to let these people fool you into thinking otherwise.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Been playin STO for a long long while "Bought it when it first came out" and I have to say that out of all the F2P models I have seen this one is one of the best. You can get whatever you want in the cash shop without spending a dime, you do this by mining and trading on the Dilithium market which is basically a form of currency that you can exchange for Cash Shop Zen. HOWEVER, be prepared to put in the time if you choose to go that route.  Biggest problem I have seen with this game is the players who actually play it. Those that dont put money into the game are constantly ♥♥♥♥♥ing about the "advantage" other players have over them and Earth Spaceport has become a literal soapbox for these people to voice their ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Despite the fact that if these people simply just put some time into the game they could have everything a paid player has access too as well. Putting money into the game is simply a time saving convinence, not a game breaking flaw. As many of these people would lead you to believe. Besides, there is a mission where you take a current generation Ship, slingshot around the sun, go back in time to TOS. And get drink recipes from Scotty... That alone should make you want to play. Graphics I have noticed are getting a bit dated and certain aspects of space combat will take you a moment to learn. But, other than that the game is enjoyable and fun.10/10 Would go back in time to get alcohol recipes from Scotty again.

The problems come from:1) Redundancy. A lot of missions are go to a place and seek out multiple groups of enemies; return when you've killed x number of them2) Ground combat. It's tedious. Additionally, the character movements are very jumpy on ground missionsAnyway, it was fun for a while, but didn't have anything to hold interest. Just more and more of the same grind, essentially.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												Dear Star Trek community, of my currently more than 3 hours of trying to play this piece of♥♥♥♥♥I've spent no time in game. This was at first because I couldn't make a ♥♥♥♥ing user. When I made my user, it wouldn't accept my username in the username/email box, so I always had to use my mail. When it would finally accept both mail and password, I was presented with a loading screen. I've so far spent about 3 ♥♥♥♥ing hours in this loading screen, and have yet to play the ass♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ load of ♥♥♥♥berries that is the game I wanted to help me get into the show.♥♥♥♥ it.10/10 IGN would loading time again.UPDATE:I got it running after about 7 hours and will now review the first hour of in-game gameplay. It bouldly goes where no asspoop has gone before, except maybe that Star Trek game that costs actually human money.I'm reviewing this for it's gameplay, not plot, cuz I skipped all the story things.First there's a surprisingly non-testicular character creator, this concludes my list of pros.I chose to be a starfleet person for reasons of reasons, and was booped into San Francisco anno 2400 or somewhere around ther, I know it's San Francisco because it's shouted at me trough voice-acting and the golden gate is pushed up into my face. My first quest is to go and talk to someone, so is my second one, and third, and fourth, and fifth (after it let me talk to the guy), and sixth. As my seventh quest I have to go and toast cuz I graduated from space-school or something before I get sent to a spaceship that; MAJOR SPOILERS OF SOMETHING NOBODY WOULD PREDICT IN A GAME AT ALL, the ship gets attacked. You then do yada yada for a couple of minutes (one of which was breaching a door I couldn't quite find because the doors don't work at all and you just go through all of them) before I get to control the ship (which the dialogue might explain but I skipped it. At this point I realised that I have about 71 games that are better than this in my steam library (I have 72 in total as of when I'm writing this) that are a quadrillion times better than this pile of words that would have my steam account banned due to profanity.Conclusion:Pros:Character creator.Cons:The other bit.The character creator is worth the money they're asking, it's a bit much for the rest of it tho.Negative 834762859/10 IGN would exit game again.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												Personally I found this game quite enjoyable. I am a big fan of Star Trek, both then new movies and the tv series. But here are my pros and cons for this game.Pros: 1: Large expansive map with loads of planets and systems to explore.        2: Many ships, weapons, costumes and species to play and experiment with.        3: The ship-to-ship combat is enjoyable and fitting for any play style.Cons: 1: Ground combat is far from perfect. It has its moments but those a few and far apart.          2: Since the game is free-to-play, it will insist on flashing ads in your face at almost every loading screen.          3: The servers can be a bit jumpy and unresponsive at times but after a few seconds they manage to fix themselves.Finally my final verdict: This game is good. Not great but not bad. Its really has its moments if you are a fan the the series. To any Star Trek fans who are considering this game I can heartily recommend it and to any others, why not give it a shot. Its pretty good for a free game.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
												Star Trek online is a spectacular game. With that being said there is alot to do in game. The Quests and instances make you feel very immersed into the star trek universe. My only grip with this game as it can get complicated, there is somewhat of a learning curve and it can be overwhelming to some players. Over all this game is well done and it does a good job connecting all elements of every star trek series. Id say if you are a star trek fan you cant go wrong. If you like complicated yet dynamic space exploration games youll like this game as well. Communitys however are a different story, it is hard for me to find americans that I can group up with. Either way its a good game in an over saturated MMO market, so it kind of makes this a diamond in the rough.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												I recently started watching Star Trek Voyager agian and the by product of that experience is the need to fly around and shoot some phasers at things. The reason I say this is cause I want to point out the single greatest thing about this game which is simply you get to fly around and shoot phasers at people. This added with crew compilation options, varying abilities, and a vast universe created a game worth playing. Ship decoration is neither abundant nor limited so there is something for everyone and the ability to make your crew members match uniforms really adds to your own world and a true feeling of what sitting in the captains chair is like. This game isn't without fault but there is no game that can claim to be flawless, perfect, and sparkly. Such things are a myth and any errors or bugs in this game should not effect your opinion in whether to play it or not.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												This game causes a lot of nostalgia and excitement to see what the Star Trek universe can do. But this game is riddled with bugs, glitches, display problems, choppy fps drops, and hilarious lag issues. If cryptic can stop sucking up the players' money for a month or so and genuinely patch the game, this may improve. PvE events are non-existent, the grind is still horrible. The tutorial sticks you with skills and abilities you may not want and doesnt even let you respecialize to your own liking. You have to buy a token which you can obtain without spending actual money, but it'll take weeks of grinding for Dilithium Crystals just to afford it. My overall rating on this bug-ridden distaster is a 2 out of 5. It seems Cryptic has lost its sense of gaming and just dove for the players' wallets. Patches are meant to improve the game, new content is supposed to add new things.. but clearly its just layering on more time wasted grinding away for a ship or loadout you can't do without paying actual money.

												This game was fun for a time.  Then, I tried to get my second ship.  I got a free token for another ship and went to turn it in and both the OK and CANCEL buttons did the same thing...nothing.  My token was gone and no new ship.  So, I played for a few days and built up enough Dilithium to purchase the Cruiser ship (15000).  I went to purchase the ship, my Dilithium disappeared and in the chat window it said I received the Cruiser, but sadly no ship.Granted, I was using a free account, but if free accounts are not allowed a second ship, why does my Ship Slots show 5 available and both my token and Dilithium were depeleted?  What's worse is the bug reporting system wouldn't let me notify the developers of this issue.  Shotty programming guys.  If you would have kept me happy on the free account, I would have became a paying member, but I don't think I want to waste anymore time or ANY money on this product.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												This game is very very fun even if you don't have any idea what Star Trek is. I started when one of my friends was playing and was like "oh that game looks like fun" and i really wasn't that into Star Trek. I now love Star Trek and this game. but enough about that, you probably want to know about the game not my personal experience.Pros:+Fun gameplay+Many different races to play as+Three factions: KDF, Federation, and Romulan+Good story+F2P+Can create fleets with other people+Can ram enemies+Partial voice acting+Pretty good audio+You command your own starship+You have Duty Officers that you can put on assignment to do stuff+Crafting+There are tribblesCons:-There are tribbles-Gameplay can get a little repetative-Hard to make EC (the currency) if you don't know what you're doing-Servers are a little buggy/slow-Ground combat is a little buggy if you use shooter mode-Can be pay 2 win if you don't know what you're doing-A skill is required to ram enemies-You might find yourself becoming a Trekkie-Leonard Nimoy is dead. RIP :(

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Star trek online is a MMO where you are a captain of a (klingon,starfleet,romulan) ship as you progress to make your faction more powerful and to progress your character.Ignore my hours as I played this game three years since I got it on steam,so it probaly is really around 100 or so hours.Now even though i'm a extreme star trek fan I have to be brutally honest as there are some extremely bad things in this game,trust me.So without further delay here is the reviewPros- Game is large with lots of things to do,with atleast 20 hours for each faction storyline,and with all the sidemission and fleet actions it increases far  beyond that-Space battle are amazing,when you get to those points where a group of allied and enemy ships meet it looks so good.With ships scattered everywhere in a tight group with beam lines everywhere with torpedos flying by your ships evere three seconds.And in the higher level ones you also get to see massive ammounts of fighters going by as well.-There is alot of customization options to make your perfect character,as well as there being alot of ships to choose from with alot having different variations to choose from.With the ability to mix and match the different parts of the different variants-You get to see alot of memorable places from the movies and shows,like DS9,Earth,Starfleet academy,vulcan,Qo'nos,Debris of romulus,Wolf 359, etc.-Dabo,enough said here-PVP is fun at the lower levels and you get tons of awesome loot from it!-Alot of races to choose from,and only made 10 are paid for,out of like the 50 species to be.Neutral-Game needs a better interface,even with a maxed out character I get lost in the UI and the several different drop down menus,forgetting where that one button is.-most of the clothes you need to pay for,while I love have payed content so you can have something most people in the game won't have to make your character more unique,having 80% of the clothes you need to pay for is just crazy.-All of the max level ships you have to pay for,with them being 25 dollars a peice.Cons-A.I is MENTALLY ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥,one time I lost my crewmembers because they didn't know how to jump over a pipe.-Game completely favors people that pay money,and I don't mean like a exp boost,I mean like later in the game inless you pay money you get practiclly screwed on the harder missions and in pvp don't bother inless you pay money.-There are some large difficaulty spikes,on one point in a mission,then it goes back to being in the middle between easy and moderate-Animations are pretty bad,but I won't have this impact the score-Loading screens EVERYWHERE!,While it's better with only three loading screens as you travel in sector space,there used to be like 10-15,it's still bad in planets and such.-Game is linear especially since they removed the exploration missions and replaced them with some duty officer assignments,while they were a sorry excuse for exploration they were my favorite thing to do.Overrall the game scores a 7/10,when it first launched it was definately a 5/10,but has growed as a whole and will continue to get better for a while to come.I definately reccomend this game to EVERYONE except people that hate star trek,everyone else it's free so you might as well try it out.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												this used to be a fantastic...amazing..perfect game...i loved the aspect of it..played it since it went free to play....ship combat was amazing....great style fitting most space sims of its time...ground combat needed work but was a fun expeirance...the game was overall a fantastic peace of work....it wasnt without its bugs and glitches...all mmo's have them...sometimes things get released to early.....to name a few problems from the paste..they released a fantastic escort carrier for the federation......annnnnnnd..it couldnt warp out of any system without crashing the game......and then the borg had a super weapon we called invisible death...(they were invisible torpdoes that you cant avoid and shoot down and one shot you..fantastic) but it was still fun..they were fixed..and the game was great..that being said...i can no longer recomend this game..its gone completely wallet happy...paste level 40 if you do not buy a ship for 40 to 60 dollars...you get left behind...you can refine dil in the game to do this..but the cap means you will be at it for months on end..you can improve your weapons!!!.....to higher tiers and more rarity with fantastic improvements.....for dil...which you need to get the ship....you also need....well you need it for everything...the game has quite litterly..and plainly...gone wallet to play....as in paste 40..its pay to play..i can no longer recomend star trek online to anyone.......and this is heart breaking to me...because i have been a star trek fanatic since i was 12.....and i spent so much time..and money on this game..and it shatters my heart seeing its become a buggy game....a glitchy game......based around money.....please...do not waste your time...

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												I’ve never really been that into MMO’s, after having a dabble in WOW, I find them so time consuming, and not to mention addictive. However, being a huge Star Trek fan, I had to try STO. I’ve actually spent likely hundreds of hours in this, right back from when it was in beta play. I absolutely love it, the easter eggs, the guest characters are such wonderful features for those who love Star Trek. The stories are all perfectly written and have many brilliant references to previous episodes of Star Trek. The game play itself is great, the space battles and ground assaults give it a good variety of play. Ship customisation is so much fun, although to get some of the best stuff… you really have to do a lot of farming and devote a lot of time to your play. The game encourages a lot of team work and group playing, I never really precipitated in that as much prefer going off and doing my own thing. Overall I would recommend this to any Star Trek fan, hours of fun and stratification! Glorious space battles and phaser fights with an exciting sound track! What more could you ask for?!

number of helpful: 9 of 18 people (50%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												Possibly the worst MMO experience ever. Missions can take upwards of an hour - and regularly bug out - assuming you've taken so long you're AFK - and causing NPCs to start regenning health faster than humanly possible.If the Borg were to encounter STO - they wouldn't even attempt to assimilate it - probably deciding to exterminate instead. The Ferengi wouldn't even consider it worth an ounce of gold pressed latinum, and the Klingons would find it a poor simulation.The STO experience is an exercise in frustration and tedium. You'll see familiar faces, some incredible voice acting, and Korean levels of grinding. Everything worth anything costs insurmountable amounts of credits due to inflation from the Microtransactions.The entire game is built around the 1% of hard core players who somehow manages to stay far enough ahead of the curve to be gods among men - living embodiments of Q - who swat NPCs with ease - and leaving the casual player or trekkie in the dust, struggling to complete the simplest of missions.The game has not progressed in any meaningful way, or improved even remotely since the beta - bugs continue to plague  the game, that were reported in those early days. Instead they've elected to paywall or outright remove features and content to make it easier to manage.If you're thinking of picking up this game, don't - you'll have a moment of excitement to be experiencing a Star Trek game, followed by a slowly growing frustration that this isn't a trip through the holodeck, but instead a Tal'shiar torture device being experienced in the coldest corner of rura penthe while a gorn does unspeakable things.1/8472

the game is full with never fixed bugs, boring cutscenes you cant escape, more boring pvp and pve missions, bad comic-like graphics, every 20 minutes you get a game crash, the network code is very slow and you will get a ton of lag and rubberbanding all the time, the login and loading of the game takes ages the first 5 minutes you cant do anything and i have a fast ssd, huge amount of fast ram and fast connection so its not the fault of my system, the game clipping is horrible everything is warping around, the episode mission storys make no sense at all, the support doesnt even exist they will rather harras you instead of help you, everywhere they have added timegates i still wonder why they havent added timegates even for the beamout process. the game devs cant even code at all, they are all copy and paste coders cryptic has hired some cheap coders of a third world country and they just c&p code from neverwinter another pwe game. now they have added a new and very, very, very expensive crafting system and it takes you almost 7 years to reach the endlevel in crafting and if you want to speed up crafting to reach level 20 asap you would need to buy enough dilithium for 8500 dollars!!!, but you cant craft gear with the mods you want, instead its more like a lottery crafting with random mods, its useless in this stadium. so forget it, you cant equip your toons with your own crafted gear. after that they have added a new very, very, very expensive upgrade system, this is the most expensive and overpriced system i have ever seen or heard of. you can easily burn 300 dollars away just to upgrade one shipgear loadout(6-8 weapons, 1 deflector, 1 engine, 1 shield, 1 warpcore) and it takes ages to go through all the little upgrade steps(for 1 shield i have needed over an hour to upgrade) and you have to click like a trillion times and you need tons over tons of upgrade commodities(you cant even get more some of the needed commodities anywhere in the game, they are very, very, very rare and therefore very, very, very expensive). the upgrade system is the total scam. and again this new upgrade system doesnt give you the needed mods you want, its again another lottery-like upgrade system. just to have 8 identical beams with the same mods you would need atleast 8 beams x 8 different mods - 8 = 56 trys with the upgrade system, just to get 8 identical beams with the same identical mods like crtdx4 LOL!!! and this whole process will cost you hundreds of dollars in real life money. now imagine you have to upgrade the warpcore, engine, deflector, shield of your ship and now even imagine you have 50 ships all with different gear. this will cost you thousands of dollar just to upgrade all your old stuff that you have already aquired and paid with real money. they let you pay again and again and again your stuff that you have already bought. sto is not worth the insane high costs, its maybe worth 10 bucks per month at all. you could fill a 1tb drive full with games for the money sto wants from you. i had a little trick i have used to avoid the insane high costs in form of real money. i had in the end 27 chars and 20 alts all level 50 that i have used to farm ec, dilithium, commodities, contraband and i was a heavy multibox user. because of this little trick i could aquire everything in the game, i had everything and all ships you could get. this means i have started sometimes up to 10 game clients and i was logged in with 10 different accounts at once. i did cycle though all 47 chars to get all the doffjobs done on all of my chars. i mainly used the refugee, prisoner, officer doff exchange assignments to get more very rare and rare doffs and sell them on the exchange. all i did was switch between the game windows and do doff assignments for doffs, contraband and commodities or i did path to 2409 or did mine dilithium with my 47 chars or did the cristalline entity event and idled with 10 chars at the startpoint lol. sometimes i have played more than 18 hours per weekend day! i made trillions of ec and millions of dilithium(trade 5 contraband for 2000 dil ore every 4 hours with my 20 alts chars plus 1 main char). i did not pay a dime for the new greed rising extension, i have farmed over 2,5 million dilithium and traded it for zen and bought the dr pack ingame for 12,5k zen. i was very dissapointed by the delta rising pack, the new t6 ship are ugly beyond imagination, the stats of the ships are horrible, everything is broken in delta rising nothing works. i couldnt even login more due to crashes and server timeout and game freezes every few minutes. sto has no beta testers, we the endgame customers are the alpha and beta testers. i said to myself enough is enough, screw that. i have deinstalled sto and sold my main account. i will never again play a mmo or sto. i bought now battlefield 4 with premium and all unlocks. now i play maybe every 2 or 3 days bf4 for 2 or 3 hours per day. i only play bf4 if i really have the time and nothing else to do. i have also no monthly followup costs like in sto. i bought bf4 once and have never again to pay anything and bf4 is now 99% gameplay and fun and only 1% grinding and for the first time in 3 years i have seen a real working game support, thanks for that. now after my horrible sto experience my whole life has changed to a very good life, i have now more sleep, more energy, more money, more time, more friends, more sun, more of everything, im so glad i stopped playing sto.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												I love Star Trek. I always have, and I'm pretty sure I always will. I loved this game for a long time, too.What I'm not a fan of, is the way things on this have turned recently within STO. The atmosphere of the game is wrong. When I first started playing, it was a happy, very lore-friendly place filed with lots of people trying to get their way into the TV screen we all watched our first episodes on. Recently, the lay of the land has become confusing. To say you have to grind a lot is the understatement of the milenium. EVERYTHING is a grind now, unless you want to pay for it. It has also become increasingly apparent that PWE is searching for money: In-game purchases are fine, but when you give us 3 new ships and 10 new costumes every other week, it gets ridiculous. I think one of the things I have been experiencing serves as a perfect explination. The game only launches on safe mode. In the time that this bug began to now, I count at least 19 new ships that have been added to the game (not including fleet model ships). The new way of grinding is... well, bad. Horrendous. An abomination. A lot of the new grinds require vast sums of dilithium, which is hard to farm for, and is quantity capped at 8000 units a day, which is a penny in the well of what you'll actually need. Now, dilitium is hard to farm for, but guess what PWE sells. Zen. Guess what you can by dilithium for, kiddies. Zen. All in all, this game is very good. I wouldn't have spent so much time on it otherwise, but I'm terrified that this will turn into Guitar Hero. A good game, a great idea, but driven into the ground harder than a Mack truck hitting a freight train because they produced too much new content too fast, and people got sick of it. Also: when you advertise an upgrade to your existing tier 5 ships to make them "tier 5u" ships, make them equal to the tier 6 ships. The imbalance is ridiculous. I have top-tier gear on my odyssey (including your $5 upgrade). It can't keep pace with anything on tier 6, and thats not okay. To Perfect World Entertainment: Fix your mistakes before you turn into another guitar hero rerun.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												I love Star Trek. I always have, and I'm pretty sure I always will. I loved this game for a long time, too.What I'm not a fan of, is the way things on this have turned recently within STO. The atmosphere of the game is wrong. When I first started playing, it was a happy, very lore-friendly place filed with lots of people trying to get their way into the TV screen we all watched our first episodes on. Recently, the lay of the land has become confusing. To say you have to grind a lot is the understatement of the milenium. EVERYTHING is a grind now, unless you want to pay for it. It has also become increasingly apparent that PWE is searching for money: In-game purchases are fine, but when you give us 3 new ships and 10 new costumes every other week, it gets ridiculous. I think one of the things I have been experiencing serves as a perfect explination. The game only launches on safe mode. In the time that this bug began to now, I count at least 19 new ships that have been added to the game (not including fleet model ships). The new way of grinding is... well, bad. Horrendous. An abomination. A lot of the new grinds require vast sums of dilithium, which is hard to farm for, and is quantity capped at 8000 units a day, which is a penny in the well of what you'll actually need. Now, dilitium is hard to farm for, but guess what PWE sells. Zen. Guess what you can by dilithium for, kiddies. Zen. All in all, this game is very good. I wouldn't have spent so much time on it otherwise, but I'm terrified that this will turn into Guitar Hero. A good game, a great idea, but driven into the ground harder than a Mack truck hitting a freight train because they produced too much new content too fast, and people got sick of it. Also: when you advertise an upgrade to your existing tier 5 ships to make them "tier 5u" ships, make them equal to the tier 6 ships. The imbalance is ridiculous. I have top-tier gear on my odyssey (including your $5 upgrade). It can't keep pace with anything on tier 6, and thats not okay. To Perfect World Entertainment: Fix your mistakes before you turn into another guitar hero rerun.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												This game causes a lot of nostalgia and excitement to see what the Star Trek universe can do. But this game is riddled with bugs, glitches, display problems, choppy fps drops, and hilarious lag issues. If cryptic can stop sucking up the players' money for a month or so and genuinely patch the game, this may improve. PvE events are non-existent, the grind is still horrible. The tutorial sticks you with skills and abilities you may not want and doesnt even let you respecialize to your own liking. You have to buy a token which you can obtain without spending actual money, but it'll take weeks of grinding for Dilithium Crystals just to afford it. My overall rating on this bug-ridden distaster is a 2 out of 5. It seems Cryptic has lost its sense of gaming and just dove for the players' wallets. Patches are meant to improve the game, new content is supposed to add new things.. but clearly its just layering on more time wasted grinding away for a ship or loadout you can't do without paying actual money.

content:
Posted: March 11
												If you have a deep love for sci-fi, or Star Trek in general, this might be a good fit for you. Focus of the game is on space and ground combat, with exploration mechanics thrown in. The quest lines are usually nicely done and supplemented by the availability of user made quests and zones. The amount of ships  available is impressive pulling from nearly every race and era of Star Trek, with new ships being added often.The downside is the fairly insistent pokes by the game to cough up cash. While not unexpected, the frequency and manner are a bit too frequent and in your face. Bugs... long standing interface bugs that have literally persisted unfixed for years (suppose that technically makes them "features"). Grind... lots of it. That said, you can attain almost anything in the game if your willing to put in the time.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												Thinking about downloading Star Trek Online? Sweet! You might love it!Pros --* First, this game has a MASSIVE community! Quite friendly too!* Second, this game has a ton of content! Multiple story-arcs!* Third, awesome customization, both for player and starship!* Fourth, you can indeed fly a starship!* Fifth, content is still being released!* Sixth, plenty of ships to collect!Cons --* First, the game can be hard to run for some low-end systems.* Second, after a few weeks, the game can feel quite grindy.* Third, after a few months, you may get bored with the overwhelming content.* Fourth, the game has connectivity issues.Overall --Would I recommend this game? Yes, yes I would. Especially if you are a Star Trek fan!

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												Cluncky on foot but so much free Star Trek based FREE content, even to end game stuff, that you'll easily get your nerd pleasures from it. 


Star Trek Online 
A Screenshot of Star Trek Online
By: Opt_0™




 It's got all the MMO elements in a Star Trek Universe and more than enough PvE and basically single player "questlines" to give anyone the option to play countless hours without worry of only having the option to be phaser-fodder for "pay to win" players in PvP only like so many other "Free to Play" games. 


Star Trek Online 
A Screenshot of Star Trek Online
By: Opt_0™




 If I understand it right, you actually pay for more "Episodes" which I think is like expansion story lines and some cheaper access to other ships which can be used for further standard MMO play. Yet I don't feel I saw any major "beat-all" purchasable items, ships or gear. It's got a lot to offer for a free and if you've got a Taste for SciFi and/or StarTrek then give it a shot. You'll even get a little time travel now and then to cross paths with old friends and some nice Star Ship Battle time to really get that nostalgic feel, 


Star Trek Online 
A Screenshot of Star Trek Online
By: Opt_0™




  or play with more recent itterations of your favorite ships. Even select the details ofyour Officers from uniform details to species and physical features. It can scratch that nerd-itch well in so many ways and all for free.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												This is a great game for any star trek fan. I played it for a solid 3 weeks until I reached admiral level. From then on you are required to buy ships and equipemnet with real money if you want any chance to finish missons. So this means you'll get a good 50 hours gameplay until you have to reach into your pocket for mmo virtual products. So if your a star trek fan of any of the franchise give this a play for a few hours and decide after if you wan to spend money.The ship fights are great. The fan made missions are even better. The arrangement of your bridge crew adds fighting and mission abilites which is great. Complete customisation of your self crew and ship. The only downside I found was that every mission had you kill emeny ships. Its not very federation if your killing everything. The fan missions have a bit more of a true federation feel to them than the main ones. There is alot of fighting for a peaceful exploring space federation. Also its always updateing. If you dont update for a week itll be a good 10 min update waiting when you log in.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												When reading this review, please bear in mind that I am reviewing the Agents of Yesterday DLC, not the full game.Star Trek Online: Agents of Yesterday is a brand-new DLC for Star Trek Online. It consists of 6 missions if you choose to create a character from the Starfleet of the 23rd century, and also about 4 other missions towards the middle of the game whereby you become a Temporal Agent.The storyline takes you to various different locations and various timelines, most notably: the JJ Abrams Timeline (or the Kelvinverse) where the U.S.S Kelvin was destroyed in battle (presumably). In this timeline, you assist the U.S.S Yorktown against Na'Kuhl Raiders who are trying to destroy the timeline hence creating a weapon against the Federation. There are several ships added in his DLC, all of which, however, cost REAL MONEY. I have to say, however, that they are very unique and powerful although I am surprised at the lack of a Kelvin Timeline Constitution Class (T6). The DLC itself feels and looks very much like the TOS sounds and graphics I wanted but does not give me the option to change to the 2410 style later on when the TOS effects seemed to get slightly annoying, Other than this, it felt almost empty as the storyline ended abruptly. I feel that more could have been added to improve e experience.

I have also boosted the default max graphic settings in the game with 8x supersample and that reduced most of the jaggies I got on normal maxed settings. Still, it's not a great looking game, but it does look acceptable now.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Star Trek Online the perfect MMORPG. It is Free to Play, but not Pay to Win. You may progress through the game faster, and get some exclusive items (mainly customization items) and features with a paid subscription, but the free version is still perfectly enjoyable. The high-end ships and items are very expensive, but you do not have to pay with real-world currency just to purchase them. All you need to do is grind... a lot. I have almost one million energy credits, and that's all from playing casually, no gridning involved. You pick up items from fallen enemies, and if you pick up all of the loot critters and sell the stuff you don't need, you'll be rich in no time. The more valuable currencies are a bit harder to come by, but again, they are obtainable by simply playing the game!The game has a lot bugs, but almost all of them can be fixed with a console command, and I have only come accross one game-breaking bug. I feel like I should mention that I have put in alot of hours into this game. Like, hundreds (the 7.8 hours on record is only on Steam, I usually play with it's standalone launcher.)And don't even get me started on the fan service! It's simply wonderful! Actors from the television series reprise their roles to voice their characters' in-game counterparts.Whether you're a Trekkie, or just enjoy MMO's, definitely give this game a go.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												This game is such a mixed experience for me. On the one hand I want to hate the terrible land combat and the quests inability to engage me (though that is probably a bit more of my fault than the game's) but on the other hand the space combat is one of my favorites I've encountered in a game and I love the thrilling feeling I get when the game allows me to upgrade my ship to the next really cool looking stage. Gameplay wise the game has two parts, as I mentioned above, land and space combat. These two balance out in one being boringly bland and generic, and the other being really fun and feeling appropriate to the universe. The space combat is the better part, feeling like a sort of naval combat except in space. You have to line your ship up in the appropriate positions to fire ceratain weapons and it feels more like the sub-esque combat of the orginal Star Trek series, and is nice change of pace. The leveling is kept fairly well paced throughout the game as I remember only having to grind for levels a couple of times during my playthrough. Also another good point is that most of the real money currency is used for cosmetics (like costumes based on the original shows' designs). However, as stated before, the land combat is incredibly generic, it's very similar to the hotkey buttons that I complained about in Lord of the Rings Online, this combat system can be fun if done right, such as Aura Kingdom's mix of being able to use two class weapons and rediculously flashy animations, otherwise though it's very boring. Unfortunately, Star Trek Online falls into the boring category of hotkey combat. Ultimately the enjoyable space combat and the charm of the Star Trek universe keeps me enjoying the game however. If you're a fan of Star Trek, space combat, or naval style ship combat, you will definately enjoy this game. If not, I'd still recommend giving it a try, there are worse games to spend a few minutes on.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												Engagins and entertaining to play for those who are a fan of Star Trek (and possibly those who are not, although STO's charm will be lost on those who don't enjoy Star Trek).The gameplay is enjoyable but can become repetitive the more you play, but such is the norm with MMOs, and can become a grind when confronted with the higher level end-game content, because missions have to be replayed to build experience points to advance to the highest ranks.The game follows Star Trek lore faithfully and recreates the vessels of Star Trek very well with a high degree of accuracy, which can be a limiting factor as the developers will have to start creating their own designs if they wish to add more vessels when they add the existing ones thus degrading the fan appeal of the game itself.STO has been focussing more on Fleet missions and PvE events lately where large groups of players are necessary to complete a mission, which sadly takes away from the single-player enjoyability of the game that is present in the campaign missions.All in all I would recommend STO to anyone who enjoys Star Trek.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												Steam really needs to have a 'meh' button.This MMO is not by any means bad. I mean it's an MMO so what do you honestly expect. The story is reasonably strong and does have some grounding in the Star Trek cannon but they seem to use it as a spring board which is a good thing in my opinion. I'm not too sure about the story as about half way though I got bored and started skipping through the story. I kind of picture my captain giving 'get to the bloody point' hand gestures while some Admrial gives me a new mission and the story becomes go here, do this and get these as a reward.The space combat is what people really play the game for. It is quite fun although does get annoying if you go up against another ship which is roughly the same level as you and taking down it's shields is like shooting spit balls at it. The ground combat is sort of meh. I don't know if I set my character up correctly but I seem to die very quickly and enemies can tank damage like nothing else.STO does have a few other things to extend the life of it and ones of these is a reputation system when several factions will give you nice little traits once you get enough reputation points with them which you get through completing assignments by using reputation marks which are rewards for PvE events. These do turn into grinds but most of the traits are useful and you can get some fantastic ship and ground upgrades.They also put on winter and summer events which are quite nice and do add to the life albeit not much. One system I do like is the Zen coins, you can either buy them for real money or use Dilithium (in game rewards) and trade it in the games version of the stock exchange. This takes forever to get any usable ammounts of Zen but it does save you real money and you can buy some pretty fancy ships if you have patience.I'll be honest I play this game till I finish the event or get to teir 5 of the current faction reputation and that is it, I find little incentive or want to play more and while there PvP, little pointless side missions and the Foundry where you can make your own story missions they just don't grab my attention. Hardcore MMO players might disagree but for me this game is a quick distraction and a bit of a habbit.Check out my youtbe channel for lets plays and commentary every Monday and Fridayhttp://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2l1zwMcpJm_hJq4owO3nHg

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												I used to love this game - there was PvP, there was procedural content (albeit more limited than even older MMOs like Anarchy Online), there were lots of canon starships at endgame - it was almost a Trekkies dream (aside from the lack of non-violent mission resolutions, which will turn off hardcore Roddenberry-ites).Then free to play happened.  The game was monetized, at the time, in an acceptable way.  As time has progressed, however, there have been paywall timegates and $60 ingame purchases labelled as "micro-transactions" by the publisher.  There has been a complete death of PvP, and the powercreep, which although unavoidable in classic-style MMOs, has accelerated to the point that nearly every update makes the game even more faceroll easy coupled with more lag as the server tries to sync hundreds if not thousands of more effects than it was ever designed to handle.The graphics engine, although once quite shiny and almost speedy, has, with the addition of many new effects, become a lagfest, even bringing SLI Titan Xs to single digits on occasions.  The default DX11 mode is more than likely to crash first-time players, unless you set the game to safe mode and change the render device.  The sound system is frequently broken and glitchy.  The voiceovers, while becoming more and more plentiful, are both poorly directed and poorly acted, not to mention that if you are a Trekkie who doesn't happen to be a fan of Voyager, there are very few characters that you will care about.  The only saving grace was the Leonard Nimoy VOs that you would here upon entering a new sector for the first time - with the combining of the space map into a single zone, I have no idea if these are even still present.If you are thinking of coming back, having played before the Delta Rising expansion - don't bother.  In the most asinine level cap increase I have ever seen, all of your gear is obsolete as "endgame" and has become placeholders for upgraded and crafted gear, both of which are highly RNG based and either require a massive timesink or spending into a paywall.I still do play - but it has no attraction as a game I care about - it fills the same role for me as a game like Ziggurat - if I have 30 minutes to waste but I don't want to commit to a real game, I jump into STO and run a few STFs (raids), or would if the lag in some of the instances weren't absolutely outrageous.Don't get me wrong, there is still some fun to be had, especially if you are a Trek fan.  I just don't think it's worth the time to download, or the temptation to spend real life cash on.

There was the Iconian war.A complete waste of time on behalf of the developing team;A complete and utter piece of bullsh*t on my behalf.Iconians went extinct almost 1 million years before the events of Star Trek DS9, so why does this crummy game bring them back?Profit, I presume...Another thing... Making up new starships? Thats a new low. You can't MAKE up a star ship! It's like changing your second name before being married! Fools!Which brings me onto my next point, why make such a goodd game with huge potential into a 'clash of clans' type of 'pay to play' game? It looked so cool, but it turns out, the full version is £150 or something! What a waste! Its irritating seeing all of those amazing Jem'hadar battleships (which are not made up, thanks STO!) and then look back at my scout ship and say "Wow..."To conclude, if you have money, you will enjoy this game, if you don't, delete that piece of sh*t off of your PC now!

												Left the launcher open overnight to patch the game so I ended up with 16 hours playtime without having ever gone into the game. Spent an hour trying to create a character. Thought my game had glitched for another hour because it didnt tell me I was actually still in a mission, and had to speak to 1 dude for 1 dialogue box to end it. Friend set up a fleet with memes as ranks and then set up another friend called "Baedolf Anschluss" as Fuhrer, but had to pay 2 random dudes 2 million energy points or something so we had enough people to actually set up the fleet. Went to a tailor and realised that not only could I change my own uniform, but my character and also my crew and their uniform. Spent an hour doing that and made some lizard look like deadpool and edited everyone else. Went onto Baedolf's ship and... unmentionable things happened. Then a friend and I spent 4 hours running around my ship asking people for threesomes and criticising them for not wearing the Fleet's uniform. We started giving things random Star Trek names such as "temporal quantum synthesizer". Abused our power to no effect. Pasted the chat into Discord and spent 3 hours with other friends laughing at it and contiuing the role playing. Still haven't played any mission other than the tutorial.100% worth every hour, even if it wasn't free.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												Like many other here, I'm not really sure what to say about this game. I myself have been playing it on and off since F2P and keep going in the cycle of:1. Gets really into it and plays a lot2. gets♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off about all the negative stuff and "quits"3. 3-4 months later get curious and start playing it againRepeatIn a way, this game is kind of like crack: you keep coming back to it even though you know it's bad. I think that I've finally broken my addication after almost 4 years though...For people just starting out, I most definetly do not recommend getting this game. The sheer amount of "stuff" to go through to get "caught up" is mind boggling; the game will probably be dead by the time you get "caught up" if you're just starting out now. Speaking of "catching up", that's exactly what this game has always felt like for me, especially as someone who can't just go shell out $30 for the latest ship, or $150 for the latest bundle/pack, or a couple dozen $$$ to buy keys to sell on the exchange to make energy credits to buy stuff that only the rich players ever seem to have to keep your ship up to date with what has become nothing more than a DPS race that worse all the time. When I first started playing this game, I got the sensation that it was a lot like Burger King: have it your way. Ther ewere so many different combinations and builds and setups that you could do and the 3 classes actually had roles and purpose in group play. My main character is an Engineer, as I always enjoyed popping turrets, mines, shield generators and being able to take one hell of a beating and tank like nobody else could. Now, it's just a DPS race in PvE (don;t even get me started on PvP, or anyone for that matter...) where it's all about how much pow you can put in and obviously the tactical class is now the only relevent one. The only builds people do are the ones that get them the most DPS, there is no longer and creativity, it's all just "Aux to bat" and "beam boat" escorts and such. What does it matter that you can take more damage when Borg cubes in STF's will hit you for 800k damage with their invisible torpedos? Or when tactical people can hit a button and make their weapons do 200% more damage than yours so they destroy everything fast, do the most damage, and as a result, get all the best loot. Loot. Any and all of the good loot is trapped in the "upper class". You can only get it if you have other high-value items to trade/sell, but first you need high-value items to trade/ sell that you can only get if you have, that's right. To "break in", you're going to need $$$, and that is the curx of the problem of this game (besides the bugs): Play to win. This game is probably by far the worst paramount example of it ever. It's a choice of either pay pr grind, especially with reputations, but at least that gives everyone a somewhat fairer chance to obtain half-decent gear. Upgrading your gear seemed like a good idea at the time, but like with many things in this game, it was implemented poorly, kind of like Obamacare. That brings me to the second big disappointment of this game: great ideas, poor implementation. If every new feature/release stopped being more about cash grab than it was about new content, then maybe this game could be more enjoyable. You know, what games are supposed to be like, instead of feeling like it's your second (or third) job. And GOd forbid you can't "keep up" and make a good dent in the previous grind before the next one comes out.Coming back to the concept of classes, which in my opinion are sadly obsolete, there was a time when each had a role to play and you needed a balance to successfully finish a mission. Now, there is very little true quality group play, unless you're in a fleet on teamspeak or some other voice chat like I was. There is very little strategy, planning, communication, teamwork, the list goes on. There's trolls galore in matches, or more often "noobs" that people just♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off at and then leave leaving you and the noob alone unable to finish the mission so you have to leave and take a 1 hour penalty all because people are too impatient and too rude and can't be bothered to communicate and show some of the newer players the ropes. The same goes for chat. On ESD or any other major hub, youask a question, and nobody answers or people just start flaming you for their enjoyment. The forums are practically worthless too, just a feeding ground for those with nothing better to do than rant about how bad Cryptic is rather than actually be constructive. It's like the old saying of giving a man a fish vs teaching him how to fish. Right now, people are just slapping people with the metaphorical fish. And that is the third and final sad face for me about this game: the lack of group play/teamwork/cooperation.I guess the real reason I kept coming back to this game was the hope that the next thing would make the game alright. As some others have said, "the miracle that was never going to happen". That, or because sometimes teaming up with the people from my fleet on the voice chat and doing runs could be a lot of fun and funny too. Finding a quality fleet can really make a huge difference. I was in the Phoenix Vanguard, and although I've been kicked since I haven't played this game in over 6 months, the people in that fleet are quality people who might be enough to get you to stay around despite all the bad this game has.People really seem to enjoy flaming Cryptic, but like current events, they do so without knowing all the facts. Here are some facts:STO was originally developed by Perpetual Entertainment from 2004 to 2008 till they went bankrupt. Even when the liscense went to Cryptic, they had to start from scratch with the code. They started in 2008 and finished in 2010. That is unprecedented to say the least to create not just a game, but an MMORPG in that amount of time. (Just for comparison, one of my favorite games Space Engineers has been in Alpha for over 2 years) Granted, it was buggy as hell and they immediately patch the heck out of it initially once it launched they just had to get it out the door. Since then, Cryptic went from Atari to "Perfect" World (get my drift) and the originaly people who were on the team have since been replaced more than once. The new people don't know how to fix the existing bugs cuase the code is proabaly such a mess it's near inmpossible. (as a side note, how many games do you know of that support 3 different versions of DirectX) But, as they have shown, they can create very good new content, especially once you get to the New Romulus story arc that continues on the Iconians got me hooked and I hope they keep it up. It seems to me that they are slowly trying to re-write the game over with code they do understand and hopefully that will come out on top, but that's not going to happen overnight...All in all, this game has (had?) the potential to be great. Maybe if someone else had made the game/takes over the game it can become what so many of us want it to be. Who knows, I'm going to college for Computer Science - Game Development and maybe someday in the future I'll have my own studio and be able to boldly go where no man has gone before and create the REAL Star Trek Online...Kirk out.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Update: 7 February 2016;It's a fun game to play for a while, especially for fans of the series. There are plenty of different ships, including the main ships from each series;James T. Kirk's Constitution-class Cruiser,Jean-Luc Picard's Galaxy-class Cruiser,Benjamin Sisko's Defiant-class Escort,Kathryn Janeway's Intrepid-class Long-range Science Vessel,Jonathan Archer's NX-class Escort.You can also find some movie-specific ships in the game, such as the Excelsior-class.You could also go for a Klingon or Romulan Republic character, which opens up other ships and options, as well as unique story routes for these characters.Endgame is a lot of PvE/PvP grinding, but what MMO does not have that? STO at least offers a variety of ways in which one can 'grind'. Such as research and development, special missions for duty officers or admiralty ships, and a reputation system with its own special rewards.There is also room for daytrading on the exchange, although item prices seem regulated by a few dozen players who have large stocks of special items laying around on alt-characters and alt-accounts. Not too infrequently I have come across items which are no longer obtainable in the game, bought one or two to see if the price would rise, only to see five more of the same item put up on the marketplace within minutes, as if the sales triggered them to be posted.PvE missions are all doable with items obtainable through in-game currency, but if you are looking to do PvP, it is more of a pay-to-win situation. The more competitive ships require ZEN to buy them or items for them, and while you can trade Dilithium for ZEN, at a cost of 316:1 it's simply not worth it.The community is decent, and the new armada system allows fleets to work together more, so it's definitely worth looking at playing it with some friends.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												The galaxy's premier Starfleet combat simulator with a side of "Everyone loses to a Romulan Tactical officer in a Scimitar" gameplay. Dont bother playing if you're a fan of Klingons, the lead dev is openly opposed to klingons as player characters and only begrudgingly makes new Klingon related content. Oh, especially if you like Klingon Birds of Prey, they've been blacklisted for new releases until at least 2016, per a Cryptic forum Supermod.EDITED IN JUNE 26th 2015: Dev team has become more willing to create quality Klingon-themed content as part of the ongoing war against the Iconians. It makes sense, as we are the greatest warriors in the Beta Quadrant.Still, there arent really a hell of a lot of alternatives. SWG, and even SWGEmu, are all but dead. SW:tOR is a crap fest with on rails space combat. EVE Online takes years to really get anywhere, and months to build any ship you'd actually want. Star Citizen is going to be the next great vaporware of our time. No real alternatives, so enjoy the new pilot ships.

Posted: January 21, 2016
												Do I reccomend this game?Lemme answer that with a question. Is the Pope a Catholic?I absolutely love this game. I mean, the graphics could use a tad bit of an overhaul, but other than that, it is absolutely amazing.Farming for levels to pass through the main storyline? Tch, forget that. Instead, they give you a whole freaking squad to support you in your endeavours, and each mission is specifically designed to level you up, so you need not worry too much about advancing levels. There are special ships, but they're not available straight off the bat, even with purchases, the ships and weapons are restricted by level, as are equipment and such, ensuring an almost always fair game (There are exceptions, but that's just because the other guy has a good weapon combo, not because they're OP.), and in group events, everyone gets a cut of the experience (Some less than others, either because the majority are high levels, or vice versa). You'll be so addicted to the storyline that you'll have a threatening dreanought before you know it!The storyline itself... It's just so addicting, anyone who's watched a Star Trek movie will feel like they're in one. You'll rise among the ranks relatively quickly, and getting through the main campaign is in no way a grind. There's always something new and interesting to it, and by the time you're done, you'll be begging for more. I've never experienced a more exhilirating storyline. If anyone, these guys should be getting all the money. They've made a game that's just in no way a bad game for those who dont wanna pay. So give them your money instead of wasting it on P2W games.

Ground mechanics aren't as good as they could be, but are better than most MMORPGs.3. content:
Posted: July 5, 2013
												It is your mission to explore strange new worlds, seek out new life and new civilizations, while all the current ones you know of are embroiled in an all out galactic war.  Set course for adventure, and reinforce the structural integrity field in your pants, cause we're going to maximum warp.  This is what you wanted out of every star trek game with the exception of a multitude of puzzles you might hope for.  Very action centric, with both ship combat, and away missions.  Join the Federation, satiate your lust for combat, glory, and honor in the Klingon Empire, or join the fight to save the remnants of the Romulan Empire after the cataclysmic events that destroyed their homeworld.  Set roughly 20-30 years after the events of Star Trek 10 : Nemesis, this is for all you purists that can't stand the abominations brought about by JJ Abrams and his crew of hacks.  Set phasers to fun!
