content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												The space combat really has nothing to which it may be compared and is tremendously fun before endgame (when it starts to suffer from feature creep in a big way). Story content is very nostalgic for Trek fans, and while the game is aging and shows it in several ways, the newer content is better constructed with fewer interrupting cut-scenes and more voiced dialogue that plays *while* you play instead of in pop-up dialogue windows or in cut-scenes. Overall, this game is definitely worth checking out.The free-to-play aspects are well done too. You can throw a little money at the game for conveniences and aesthetics until you reach endgame. At that point, you can either spend $20-30 on a T6 ship or spend a large amount of time farming dilithium (a time-gated resource) to exchange with other users for the paid currency to purchase an endgame ship. If you really love the game, then you will have to spend more and more on these things. Having said that, to get to the deep end of the endgame pool with the best ship builds is going to cost some real-world money or deman an epic commitment of time to grind, so there is a point where they start making the game for "whales"; however, this is only for "elite" PvE queues as you can do the "Normal" queues with a free t5 ship and the "Advanced" queues with any t6 ship. So this game can actually be completely F2P and be fun and rewarding. They enticed me to pay a little bit, but not to go full Orca. YMMV.

												I wish steam allowed for a more clear way to define your opinion on a game besides a Black and white "yes" or "no". This would be especially helpful with this title. If you love star trek and are looking for a decent narrative and pretty solid star trek naval combat, this will probably be worth the download. Endgame grinding is rediculous, endgame as a whole is very subpar so dont get your hopes up. Good single player expirence considering its free. Recommended for any true star trek fan.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
												I highly recommend STO to fans of Star Trek. If you aren't a fan of Star Trek, then you may not enjoy this title as much as you would if you are.Pros:1. Star Trek Universe2. You can play the entire game without paying a cent.3. An obscenely huge amount of content available without having to pay.4. Space and Ground game mechanics have matured over the life of the game.Cons:1. Even though there is a huge amount of free content, you will NEVER be able to unlock it all without paying. This is absolutely justified in my opinion as the amount of content that is available without paying is plenty. If you want premium, you gotta pay, get over it. Game developers don't work for free.2. Ground mechanics aren't as good as they could be, but are better than most MMORPGs.3. The same game music for the last 5+ years (come on devs, let's get something new!)If you are a Trek fan, there is plenty to love here.

Lots of fun to be had here.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												Okay, it is Star Trek and anything to do with Star Trek is almost always enough for me, so I am clearly biased. I love it. I love the modifiability of your characters and ships. I love how the developers are trying to keep the minimum requirements as low as possible so poor folk can keep playing using the old computers that were often handed down to us from friends or family members. I love the way it all links together through the ongoing storyline. You can play your way, and you can play for free. It may take a bit longer to make it through the ranks and acquire new ships but you can. I have made it all the way to Vice Admiral and have not had to spend a penny....

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
												I am a HUGE Star Trek fan. I've seen every episode of every Star Trek series at least once (including The Animated Series). Star Trek will likely remain my favorite series from here until the end of time. Everything about the franchise invites exploration, friendship, adventure, action, and ethical responsibility. As an MMORPG this game does a really nice job of instilling those standards onto you, while keeping up with MMORPG standards. Is it completely Star Trek? No, of course not, but it's the best game to instill my dreams of being a Starship captain exploring space on my very own starship. It wouldn't be fun if it was totally Star Trek, and I'm not contesting that. In fact, the MMORPG aspects of that make the game more fun than if I was actually sitting in the Captain's chair making life-or-death decisions."But PsionicPhazon, it sounds like you love the game. Why did you give it a thumbs down?" you might be asking. I will tell you why:I am not allowed to play Star Trek Online because of my region. I live in Taiwan, and since it's affiliated with China they want nothing to do with it for no other reason than PWE doesn't want us to play it. It sucks, too, because I was really getting into it before they banned me a while ago for existing in another country, even though in the past I have played it here. It is for this sole reason that I do not recommend it. Anyone living in Asia is not allowed to play Star Trek Online, and in certain other regions of the world. I can't even log into PWE's ARC website to make a complaint or even activate a code that was given to me by the company (their way of saying Haha ♥♥♥♥ you). For a game set in a world where the heriones of the franchise value togetherness, diplomacy, and peace; they are doing everything they can to do the exact opposite of that. Call me butthurt, but the very thought that this game can't be available all over the world is the antithesis of what Star Trek is about. I will give it a full thumbs up when the region locks are lifted.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Probably the only truly free MMO that you can play all the way through without buying anything.  If you're a Star Trek fan, this is as close to the perfect game as you're going to get.  Obviously the MMO conventions still apply, and you can buy some things if you want (better ships, more storage, etc), but none are required to hit max level and play the story to its current conclusion.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												As a long time Trekkie having seen evey episode and movie made to date I feel comfortable saying this is the truest game to what Star Trek is that ive seen let alone had the privelage to play. I have reccomended this game to all of my friends and even the ones who liked neither MMO's nor Star Trek still enjoyed it. The story is the best most intricately woven storyline of any game even more detailed than some actual Star Trek story arcs. The gamepay particularly space combat is well designed and the ground missions feel exactly like a good MMO should. The game is by no means pay to win (even though i have donated over $200) any content that cannot be directly obtained by free players is either available for free during twice yearly giveaways or can be earned through grinding (minor grinding by mmo standards).I felt that with 1000 hours of STO on steam and another 500 on the second launcher, ARC that it was time to pass on my experience to others.In short: if you like Star Trek even a little bit then try the game and if you like MMO's even a little try the game. Hey, maybe it will convince you to get into the other more. Star Trek is fabulous sci-fi and MMO is the best gerere of gameP.S. For anyone who does want to watch Star Trek i reccomend the following watch order: Star Trek: The Next Generation -> Star Trek: Deep Space Nine -> Star Trek: Voyager -> Star Trek: Enterprise -> Star Trek: The Original Series -> Star Trek movies in order 1-10 followed by the new alternate reality Star Trek movies starring Chris Pine.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												Star Trek online is essentially a single player game with a chat box that will kick you if you are afk for too long. Its NPC opponents are designed to be adjusted to your player level, so that they can be overpowered regardless of the output of your weapons and sheilds, and full enjoyment of the game is unattainable unless you spend money. You will find on the bright side that STO is an exellent opportunity to nerd out and live your life through your avatar counter part given that alot of the purchasable items exist solely for the pupose of customizing and showng off your account, but that's just it! The best part of the game is everything that isn't a mission. Evey mission gives you a level, every 10 levels, you rank up, becoming significantly stronger at the exact same rate as the enemy. the only discernable pupose of this linear increase in point values is to force the periodic upgrading of equipment and to discourage PvP gameplay by enforcing an insurmountable lack of balance.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												I have been with this game since the beginning, day 1 of launch and have been with it through the ups and the downs.  There was a glimmer of hope for this game for a while there but then catastrophy happened and now this game is nothing more than a buffet for the wallet warriors.  About every two weeks they release some new lockbox or some new series of ships and demand prices upwards of 35$ to 100$ + if you want the "bundle".  Days of when ships were around five to ten dollars are long gone.  The game is also plagued with extreme server instability, rubber banding and random disconnects.  Your chat is filled with vile in the form of chinese farmers demanding you pay them irl money for in game currency and theres no stopping them.Anyone who has loved Star Trek and has grown up playing games like Star Trek Starfleet Command or Klingon Acadamy, or even Bridge Commander....Do yourself and your wallet a favor and stay far away from this game.  Its nothing more than a korean grindfest MMO painted over with something that resembles but isnt Star Trek.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
												I am a HUGE Star Trek fan. I've seen every episode of every Star Trek series at least once (including The Animated Series). Star Trek will likely remain my favorite series from here until the end of time. Everything about the franchise invites exploration, friendship, adventure, action, and ethical responsibility. As an MMORPG this game does a really nice job of instilling those standards onto you, while keeping up with MMORPG standards. Is it completely Star Trek? No, of course not, but it's the best game to instill my dreams of being a Starship captain exploring space on my very own starship. It wouldn't be fun if it was totally Star Trek, and I'm not contesting that. In fact, the MMORPG aspects of that make the game more fun than if I was actually sitting in the Captain's chair making life-or-death decisions."But PsionicPhazon, it sounds like you love the game. Why did you give it a thumbs down?" you might be asking. I will tell you why:I am not allowed to play Star Trek Online because of my region. I live in Taiwan, and since it's affiliated with China they want nothing to do with it for no other reason than PWE doesn't want us to play it. It sucks, too, because I was really getting into it before they banned me a while ago for existing in another country, even though in the past I have played it here. It is for this sole reason that I do not recommend it. Anyone living in Asia is not allowed to play Star Trek Online, and in certain other regions of the world. I can't even log into PWE's ARC website to make a complaint or even activate a code that was given to me by the company (their way of saying Haha ♥♥♥♥ you). For a game set in a world where the heriones of the franchise value togetherness, diplomacy, and peace; they are doing everything they can to do the exact opposite of that. Call me butthurt, but the very thought that this game can't be available all over the world is the antithesis of what Star Trek is about. I will give it a full thumbs up when the region locks are lifted.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												Star Trek online is essentially a single player game with a chat box that will kick you if you are afk for too long. Its NPC opponents are designed to be adjusted to your player level, so that they can be overpowered regardless of the output of your weapons and sheilds, and full enjoyment of the game is unattainable unless you spend money. You will find on the bright side that STO is an exellent opportunity to nerd out and live your life through your avatar counter part given that alot of the purchasable items exist solely for the pupose of customizing and showng off your account, but that's just it! The best part of the game is everything that isn't a mission. Evey mission gives you a level, every 10 levels, you rank up, becoming significantly stronger at the exact same rate as the enemy. the only discernable pupose of this linear increase in point values is to force the periodic upgrading of equipment and to discourage PvP gameplay by enforcing an insurmountable lack of balance.

Anyway after 2 months along came the CRASH. OMG i thought and i had to keep force reseting the pc as i couldnt get back to desktop. After 6 months i gave up and put the game in the alcive section amongst a few other titles that are useless to run...So NOW after nearly 6 years and also taken over by perfect world with loads of improvemants so they claim to not only the client but gameplay as well like graphics ect ect you know where im going so i will stop there. i decided ok lets give it another go. Loaded up viea steam now loged in onto my acount and started a fresh charector as i knew through all the changes i would be at a loss so a fresh char would be great to have a fresh begining. And OMG OMG O M G. After a few min of just being in the tutorial my screen was filled with graphicle shap glitches like triangle and all sorts of shade fanomina artifacts it was that bad i couldnt see wtf was going on, so i gave it a little love and made sure directx was all upto date ect ect ect and finaly yes managed to resolve that problem so i thought ok np being an old game and me haveing a new powerfull pc this was expected so a little tweeking solved it. off i when again still in tutorial and after 3 min BOOM!  complete crash, the who thing just froze and i couldnt even get to desktop so a force RESET on pc to reboot. this didnt change after 3 hour trying to play the dam game. this means uninstalling and reinstall 2 times to make sure everything was upto date ect. I finaly gave up. The moral of this story about my experiance with STO is NOTHING and i mean NOTHING has changed since 2010 as far as stability of the game. So with that said i can only say DO NOT WAIST YOUR TIME even playing it. Think of it this way, If after 6 years they cant even sort out the main problems like crashes ect you ant gona get anything resolved even by contacting support for a solution DO NOT WAIST YOUR TIME. I do not recomend this game to anyone. it lags bad, players have random graphicle glitches it crashes all the time and i mean ALL THE TIME.Anyway i thought i would just write a review about this game as i started it from beta and can asure you that the only thing that has changed is the content added and graphics but come on lol what does it matter if you cant enjoy the dam game or even play it. have fun all i wish you all the best

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												Before I begin, I would like to say I really wish there was a third "meh" option.  This game isn't, overrall awful, but it isn't great, or even good.  I would say, it's...decent.  Not great.  Not awful.  Just..decent.  And this is MY OPINION, and this is MY review.  So..please no hate.  I have played at least 200 hours off of Steam on PWE's main browser of Arc, and an extra (as of this) 900+ hours.  With that out of the way, are you sufficiently informed?  Yes?  Let's get down to it, then.NOTE:  THIS IS JUST AFTER THE AGENTS OF YESTERDAY EXPANSION!  NOTE 2: SPOILERS TO TUTORIAL, AND SOME MINOR MISSIONS!1:The StoryOkay, okay, hear me out.  To many people, even some of my friends, the story is the selling point of the game.  If the game were its own thing, and not a Star Trek MMO, then I would accept it.  But, since it is, I will treat it as such.1a.  My first main problem is that the story never has a "pacifist route," or a diplomatic alternative.  And, yes, I know some people like action, but, people like me like making a compromise with my virtual enemy.  Get to the root of what their issue is, and make decisions.  If that doesn't work because of your decisions, then it can escalate to violence.  That’s only my issue with it, and most of my (few) eligible friends to know about it agree.1b. The second problem I have with this is the ladder that you climb.  In STO, with every 10 levels (or in Admiralty’s case, every 5 levels) you get a new rank, until 45, a new ship, maybe a skill or a bridge officer, but not much else.  The only difference in a promotion to Captain and Lt. Commander, is that the Captain ships are more recognizable, as they have been used in the shows.  So, why is this a big deal?  In case you didn’t deduct it from my list of ships, you have a ship at Lt. Commander.  Not only that, you command the ship at Lieutenant, even as a bloody cadet, in the tutorial!  If the Captain’s Chair was something you gained at, I don’t know, Captain, I’d be more accepting of the new ship.  But, it isn’t.  The reason is pretty sloppy, too.  You led one other cadet and yourself to fight some Borg, with the help of a trained Starfleet officer.  You held onto the ship for a few minutes before reinforcements came.  Because of those things, you’re given a ship, but..not the rank?  So, yes, you will probably find people that outrank you but are in lower positions than you, especially early on.  And, because you’re captain, as a Lieutenant, the ENTIRE ship is run by ensigns, so they don’t outrank you.1c.  This game focuses on the wrong thing.  When someone tells you Star Trek, does “war” come up so heavily?  And, while this was brilliantly touched on in Star Trek Into Darkness, Starfleet is, by nature, an exploration organization.  As of the writing of this review, there isn’t exploration in this game.  There was, in the form of going into clusters or nebulae and finding new planets.  This also tied into the Diplomatic Corps., where you might do some missions for them here.  But, no.  Cryptic decided to remove that little feature that even hinted at something other than action.  In summary of what I said, no exploration in this game, and there are way too many fronts against the Federation for the Federation not to fall, let alone the Klingon Empire, that faction should have a civil war story arc.  But, for the action lover, surely there’s opportunity here?  No.  Not really.  The missions feel more like you’re James Bond in a slightly elevated Cold War.  Why do I say this?  There aren’t any real battles you’re fighting in.  Well, to be fair, there are a few battles.  There’s an invasion of a city to topple a falling government, there’s a space battle with ~40 different ships to take down a Klingon house, there’s another space battle with about the same amount of ships above Mars.  But, overall, there isn’t much going on in the supposed war.  In the Federation storyline (I keep mentioning this one, because it’s clear this was intended to be the one you choose) the first story arc is about the Klingon War, but..the most they do is set up a spy network, or try to stop an Undine.  To me, this is a failing point to a Star Trek game.  Maybe this would work in a franchise of its own, but as a Star Trek game, it absolutely fails.  The only thing remotely Star Trek is the Next Gen episode titlescreen UI at the beginning of every mission.1d.  I'm going to be brief here, because this section is too long already.  But, the enemies are dull, and forgettable.  Of course, not ALL are forgettable, but most of them are.  The factions seem the same.  There doesn't really seem to be any motive besides "power hungry," or "I hate the Federation."2: GameplayThere..isn't really much to say here.  It's basically..an MMO.  Nothing special about it.  Again, if it were its own franchise, or its own sci-fi thing, it probably would pass for the story, and maybe the gameplay, but it doesn't fit Star Trek's exploration themes.  Yeah, deep space is dangerous, but there is no real exploration done in the danger of the game, until MUCH, MUCH later in the game, and it has already lost all seriousness, or ties to reality.  Even THEN, not really exploring.  There is an expansion solely based on the Delta Quadrent, and it's the same formula from the rest of the game just in a slightly different environment.  Continuing on what I said in 1d, the enemies seem the same, just slightly stronger as you 'progress' through the game.  There isn't really a strategy against them.  You can literally do the same thing you did against the first enemy and the last enemy.  3: The MissionsI did reference these in the story section, but I thought I should touch on it here.  There are some really great missions in this game, I really have to admit.  But, most of the ones I really, truly enjoy are in the same arc, and it's really too far before the end, and too far after the start for it to be worth stomaching the Klingon Cold War.  The environments for some of these missions are incredible, as well, even if the missions are awful.  There are some really creepy ones, and, in some cases, it really benefits the mission, and in others, it just makes you dread doing the mission.  For the former, there's Mind Games in the Romulan storyline, where you're captured and brainwashed.  For the latter, there's What Lies Beneath, in all three playable storylines.  Overall, there are some diamonds in the rough, but these diamonds really shine.  I really love some of these missions, and I just wish they could've done more with them.  I don't love them because they're the "least bad," but they're the best of the bunch.4: The Expansions.Anybody who has played this game from the early PWE days knows what I'm talking about.  There are a few expansions in the game, most recently the Agents of Yesterday expansion, that really don't help the game in any way.  In some cases, it really hinders on the base game story.  In one expansion, it took one mission from the early game, sprinkled a few more Undine, and made a whole storyline out of a conspiracy that "The Undine did it the whole time!!"  Whenever there's a really superior species, it seems like in the early 25th century instead of just..using their technology to..y'know..invade the weaklings, they feel better just orchestrating some others to fight.There are some updates that do benefit the game, though.  But, the review must end.Overall, the game is okay as a standalone game, but it isn't good as a Star Trek game.  To put my conscience at ease, I shouldn't recommend this game to anyone.  I only play this still to be with friends.

content:

												It's not bad. Seems like a lot of work has been done to improve the quality of the missions lately, and it's made for a much nicer experience. Good visuals, though there are a few scaling issues with the sets and environments. Great character customization. Excellent music and sound effects.Unfortunately it's completely broken on OS X and won't launch, throwing an exception instead of functioning. I'm honestly starting to wonder something very strange. There's a Macintosh version of this, and Steam properly installed the OS X version of the launcher, but ah...... The only version showing in Steam is the Windows version. Did something patently absurd occur, and Steam installed the Mac version of the launcher but then the launcher downloaded the Windows version of the game? I was really hoping not to have to reboot to Windows to play STO, but that doesn't seem to be an option if it's not going to install a functioning game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												I will preface this review by saying that it's a nice way to unwind after a rough day because of the uniquiness of going from space to ground combat and back. So take my own experience with a bit of salt (although not an entire shaker-full).I am really on the fence about recommending this game. I played it through the Arc client for days and days and days. You start up as a cadet and then grind your way through space on repetitive missions until you reach the maximum level. The nice part is that you get a free ship for every major rank you achieve, the unfortunate part is that the stock ships are pretty much worthless. To remedy this, you can purchase a new ship for Zen which is purchased with your hard-earned money, you can spend days and days grinding up dilithium to buy a fancy ship, or you can hope that your fleet (guild) has some in storage that you can pilfer (sometimes these actually sell for a decent amount on the exchange).Then you realize that even with your new ship, you can't even come close to competing with the other players because you need epic equipment, which is mostly an RNG game wherein you end up spending tons of dilitium, energy credits, and time to find out that you created the exact same, worthless ultra-rare [Crtd] [Acc]x2 antiproton array that you just created 500 times previously.Long story short, this game is all about the grind. If you love grinding, grinding, and more grinding: this is the game for you. If you are like me though, you'll play this game until you realize that to compete you'll have to mortgage your house, sell your car, and maybe a kidney- and that might not be enough.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												After 250 hours or so the game just turned into a grind-fest. The story was fun to play through in the beginning, but it gradually devolved to the same types of missions, involving the same types of quests. The regular events were okay, but only if you upgragded your ship to the hilt (which of course requires signficant invest of either real money, or real-time gridning). The strength of this game is the space combat, and I will admit I'm sometimes tempted to fire up the game just to take part in some space battles. There's multiple classes to choose from, and a wide variety of ships to utilize (some free, some paid), and you can also upgrade your ship with a variety of devices (new weapons, shields, engines etc.).But the ground combat - ugh. It looks bad, plays bad, and is buggy too. It really weighs the game down in places, and I found myself dreading beaming down during missions. I hardly played the event ground missions because they were resoundingly terrible, and the ground fetch quests? I cringe just thinking about them.I can't really recommend this game in good faith. Will you have fun with it? Maybe, but it will also frustrate you to no end.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												As of last year during one huge update, all AI coding was released from pathing constraints and many other restrictions put on them. Just facing down one keldon (if you ever happen to find one) on elite difficulty is a tough battle for any engineer in a normal cruiser. AI (npc) ships are or were capable of doing anything a player ship can do, aside from cloaking, pathing used to be enemy ships moving in a straight line only firing back at players in the line of fire arcs, now enemies react follow, even boost and use abilities they never used before. Enemies are not fitted with better equipment, but hopefully one day they will be.Ground npcs are still mostly the same, there were always pathing issues in ground instances where corridors are involved, so making them able to do whatever they want would cause even more chaos. Basically npcs on the ground instances can do things a player can't do, like fit through impossibly tight gaps between a door and blocking shield eventually.The visuals on the game can be adjusted to suit almost every gaming computer on the planet!! those with lower end can turn down shadows and particle settings and turn all other things up to get the most beauty out of the game, those with high end systems can simply turn up everything and see the heavens during a full warzone, good luck with your random crash depending on how it goes ^^i recommend this to anyone looking for npc's that are not completely locked down by code, they have more free will than defiance and firefall npcs put together.please do list any other games apart from champions online that have unlocked AI if anyone replies to this. :)oh and i mention champions online only because npcs in the game have full amazing control of their actions when they are broken.the future is superior

												If you like Star Trek and want to play a F2P game, this is a decent start to enjoy the story line/campaign. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												Star Trek Online. This game is extremely basic, theres not much here other than the Star Trek feel, which soon goes after a few hours of playtime. I have been trying to get into this game over and over with no avail, its too boring. The ship desings and mechanics are sound, They're fun to play for a few hours every now and then, but by god dont get me started on the ground combat. I have never in my life played a game so clunky and weird, the animations are basic at best, some just seem so out of place it adds to the clunky movement and constant animation cancelling. Annnnd thats the game folks, nothing else to mention really, Raids and such are a joke, and no one plays them, you would be in a queue for hours on end looking for 3 people. Im not sure there is even a story here, Much like the TV shows, it's individual missions with the odd big missions with a story, then its completely forgotten till you find another. Voice acting in some parts and none existant in others, you would be best off just turning off the sound and listening to music while doing this grind of a game, actually, dont even pay attention to the missions either, because you soon get lost in what you're doing, even while paying attention.Now, what I did like about the games was the nice little tutorial stories each faction has, it realy feels like you're a member of the Klingon Empire, the Romulan Empire and even the Federation, who of which were the most enjoyable with the whole Borg element. But like I said, all the problems the game has, this feeling soon wears off. It is just a bad game, and the playerbase supports this, the game is pretty dead.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												TL;DR: DONT PLAY THIS UNLESS YOU LOVE STAR TREK AND HAVE A FRIEND TO PLAY IT WITH YOU, 4/10Now, I've played this game a lot. In the begining, it was fun, with the 2 main segments, Ground and Starship, allowing for the game to change what you do, so as to not get bored. But after this initial euphoria, I sadly have to admit, the game is mind-numbingly boring. Every mission has the same basic structure; Warp in, alternate between space and ground combat, then warp out again. It becomes a grind during the mid-game, and dispite attempts to make you solve puzzles or resolve issues, it becomes a mashing "F" contest, as you don't have to do anything other than that 99% of the time. On the rare occasion a genuine puzzle comes along, its solution is either highlighted in a text box, or told to you when you begin. And then the cash-grabbery. I would overlook moderate cash-grabbing in a F2P game; servers are not free, but the preposterous extent of the cash-grabbing in this game is unforgivable. You are capped at 10.000.000 Credits, unless you buy an upgrade. This would be fine, were it not for the fact that the majority of good late-game equipment costs much more than this. The vast majority of ships are locked behind their own paywalls, as are the more iconic outfits, such as the TOS uniforms, just to ring every possible penny out of the playerbase. However, worst of all is that the best, endgame ships are in lockboxes, which you have to buy keys for. But with these ships having an ~0.4% droprate from these crates, to get them you must either waste far too much money, or be very lucky. This guts the endgame, as if you dont pay into the system, you become obselete. Even at endgame the missions are boring and repetitive. Don't play this alone, get a friend who owes you a favour to go through it with you. Its comunity made missions can be fun, but the creator for theses missions is difficult at best. As a Star Trek fan, I have to honestly give it 4/10, as much as it pains me and my 11 days of playtime to do so.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												EDIT: I've been playing now for a month or so and have a much better idea of the game. I will leave in most of my original 'first impressions' review too. NOTE: I have changed my opinion on some areas. Updated bits at the bottom. Essentially, be prepaired to pay real money at the higher levels, and don't buy anyhting less than a T6 ship because it's a waste of money - and in the future expect to pay again, and again as they release increasingly high-level content and your current ship won't be able to do it.---original first impressions-----TL;DR: It's FREE, so give it a go if you're even slightly into Trek. IT's surprisingly good, and the paid for store items are good value for what you get. one of the better PVE MMO's I've ever played.(52 hours played at this point)  I was immediately surprised by how much detail the game makers have gone into in terms of creating a very 'Star Trek' feel to the game, and successfully translating a TV/Film franchise to not only a computer game, but a (relatively) free-roaming MMO.All the Trek bits aside, the game itself plays nicely, the interface on the ground I found a tiny bit clunky, but I adapted fairly quicky and there's certainly a lot of scope for customisation and individual play styles. The ground game reminds me a lot of a party-rpg style game because you have your away team of NPC crew members, all of whom have skills and equipment that you can customise and level up, so it's mostly about creating a 'team' that works well rather than just making one character that can do everything.The space combat is where the game shines in many ways. It's a healthy mix of tactical positioning and phaser-blasting, and the control system is nicely done. Combat is well paced and feels solid, though there are other things to do in space other than shoot stuff.The mission system is robust and fairly varied, with good stories and they feel very much like episodes in a TV series for the most part. There's a lot of repeatable missions and side missions as you'd expect from a MMO. There's a welcome mix of mini-games and small puzzle-solving elements to many of the missions which add some variety.The game is still being actively developed with expansions and content, there seems to be events very frequently that get you bonuses or involve special storylines, the community is active and the players seem on the whole a good bunch of people.My major complaint is that it's too easy (even on the hardest setting). I'm not a power gamer and I wouldn't consider myself to be any sort of expert or anything, but it's basically impossible to fail any mission. There's no way that I've found of losing anything, there's no possiblity of any of your main bridge crew dying, your ship can never be destroyed. If you get 'killed' or blown up on a mission you just repawn (the mission doesn't even reset to the start).The up-sde of this is that it actually adds to the feeling of Trek universe (where there's always a way out even when crew seemingly dies, etc.).So that's it really.-----end original------Latest feeling:Generally, what I said still stands. However there are some important considerations to make. The PVE space game gets less tactical as you get higher up and as usual the DPS-heavy options are infinitely better than any other play-style. Which is sad since at lower levels there's quite a lot of tactics involved and it's viable playing other roles. At lv50+ it's just "activate all the special abilities and keep firing", I spend more time watching the cooldown timers on my hotbar than I do the actual 'ships-in-space' bit. Ironically the ground-game has levelled perfectly and remained consitent throughout.The game ***IS*** Pay-to-win. Up to lv50 you can do fine on the 'free' version, although I did make some (very optional and fun) purchases from the C-store because I wanted to support a game I enjoyed. I purchased a couple of ships and a few other things, spending around £40 or so - for me, the purchase price of a good game. My plan was to make a small (£5-£10)purchase every month or so as I played or les frequent larger ones (the subscription options don't offer much IMO, but there's plenty you can buy).When I hit lv51 I found my ship (which cost me £25+ which I was using since I didn't like the equivalent-in-power free ones) suddenly struggling. It seems to me that to play in a comfortable way after lv50 you really need to pay for a Tier 6 ship - therefore it's pay-to-win since you can't realistically do all the content avaialble without paying.I'm OK with this model, except for one fact. I've already purchased three ships at this point, unfortunately they are all now essentially useless since the content auto-levells with you. One (a Tier 5) did have the option to upgrade "to bring it up to standard at lv50+". Which I did using a paid-for upgrade kit, making it not a T6, but a T5U. We were told that this was as close to a T6 as this ship class could get.7 days later...They have just released the same ship class with a slight stat boost and a new skin as a T6 ship. Unfortunately to use it I have pay full price for it - despite it being 95% identical to a ship I've already puprchased (it's even advertised as being the T6 version of the ship). Because of the nature of the game my existing ship (the T5U) version will be useless and honeslty I'll just delete it from my ship hangar. I would feel much better if they offered an upgrade from T5, or T5U to T6 rather than making me pay full price again. I'm not alone (according to the forums) in feeling slightly cheated/misinformed by this. It seems like this is the plan for new ships, so essentially, just be aware that when you play this game, you'll be expected to pay (between about £7 at lower levels and £35 for highest levels) for ships, and that realistically you need to buy at least one or more at the top levels to play, in addition to any vanity purchases or optional choices you make. Again, not necessarily a critisism of the game or the pay model, but a definite criticism of the communications between the company developing the game and the players regarding real-money-investments. Knowing what I do now, I would not waste my money buying any 'lower' class ship, since they are useless, and I would have just waited until now and spent that money on a T6 instead.

Combat is well paced and feels solid, though there are other things to do in space other than shoot stuff.The mission system is robust and fairly varied, with good stories and they feel very much like episodes in a TV series for the most part. There's a lot of repeatable missions and side missions as you'd expect from a MMO. There's a welcome mix of mini-games and small puzzle-solving elements to many of the missions which add some variety.The game is still being actively developed with expansions and content, there seems to be events very frequently that get you bonuses or involve special storylines, the community is active and the players seem on the whole a good bunch of people.My major complaint is that it's too easy (even on the hardest setting). I'm not a power gamer and I wouldn't consider myself to be any sort of expert or anything, but it's basically impossible to fail any mission. There's no way that I've found of losing anything, there's no possiblity of any of your main bridge crew dying, your ship can never be destroyed. If you get 'killed' or blown up on a mission you just repawn (the mission doesn't even reset to the start).The up-sde of this is that it actually adds to the feeling of Trek universe (where there's always a way out even when crew seemingly dies, etc.).So that's it really.-----end original------Latest feeling:Generally, what I said still stands. However there are some important considerations to make. The PVE space game gets less tactical as you get higher up and as usual the DPS-heavy options are infinitely better than any other play-style. Which is sad since at lower levels there's quite a lot of tactics involved and it's viable playing other roles. At lv50+ it's just "activate all the special abilities and keep firing", I spend more time watching the cooldown timers on my hotbar than I do the actual 'ships-in-space' bit. Ironically the ground-game has levelled perfectly and remained consitent throughout.The game ***IS*** Pay-to-win. Up to lv50 you can do fine on the 'free' version, although I did make some (very optional and fun) purchases from the C-store because I wanted to support a game I enjoyed. I purchased a couple of ships and a few other things, spending around £40 or so - for me, the purchase price of a good game. My plan was to make a small (£5-£10)purchase every month or so as I played or les frequent larger ones (the subscription options don't offer much IMO, but there's plenty you can buy).When I hit lv51 I found my ship (which cost me £25+ which I was using since I didn't like the equivalent-in-power free ones) suddenly struggling. It seems to me that to play in a comfortable way after lv50 you really need to pay for a Tier 6 ship - therefore it's pay-to-win since you can't realistically do all the content avaialble without paying.I'm OK with this model, except for one fact. I've already purchased three ships at this point, unfortunately they are all now essentially useless since the content auto-levells with you. One (a Tier 5) did have the option to upgrade "to bring it up to standard at lv50+". Which I did using a paid-for upgrade kit, making it not a T6, but a T5U. We were told that this was as close to a T6 as this ship class could get.7 days later...They have just released the same ship class with a slight stat boost and a new skin as a T6 ship. Unfortunately to use it I have pay full price for it - despite it being 95% identical to a ship I've already puprchased (it's even advertised as being the T6 version of the ship). Because of the nature of the game my existing ship (the T5U) version will be useless and honeslty I'll just delete it from my ship hangar. I would feel much better if they offered an upgrade from T5, or T5U to T6 rather than making me pay full price again. I'm not alone (according to the forums) in feeling slightly cheated/misinformed by this. It seems like this is the plan for new ships, so essentially, just be aware that when you play this game, you'll be expected to pay (between about £7 at lower levels and £35 for highest levels) for ships, and that realistically you need to buy at least one or more at the top levels to play, in addition to any vanity purchases or optional choices you make. Again, not necessarily a critisism of the game or the pay model, but a definite criticism of the communications between the company developing the game and the players regarding real-money-investments. Knowing what I do now, I would not waste my money buying any 'lower' class ship, since they are useless, and I would have just waited until now and spent that money on a T6 instead.

												I am a lifelong Star Trek fan and have searched for a SciFI MMO exactly like Star Trek Online. I would play the hell out of this game and even spend considerable cash on (as would my brother) it if only I could actually play it. content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												This game is terrible and boring...You want more.I have played a good amount of this game even if my hours don't tell you that, but after the first 20 hours you will have done everything the game has to offer. Which isn't to say i didn't enjoy it, infact I lost myself in the story and look of the game. Even if it was running a mix of settings.The MMO is split into two types of game play. Space battles and Ground battles.The ground battles are rubbish and are, the reason I stopped playing. This is because they killed my frame rate, there were so boring and (the main reason) I couldn't shoot my weapon but my party could shoot there's uuuh.The only solutions I found were re start the account. NOIf you're wondering these are my computers species which are well within the requirements.CPU : Q8200GPU : GTX 650 1GBOS : Windows 10Monitor : 1080p (The resolution didn’t kill my frame rate)Space battles fear much better. Not only because I could fire my weapons and add my own sound effects (pew, pew, pew) to the game's brilliant sound design and soundtrack. But the ships also control really well, unlike brigh commander. Which felt like you were on and ice skating rink (I know that space is meant to be like that).I know that I haven't said anything that would make a terrible game not even an MMO. But eventually the little annoyance give way to boredom and the deleting of the launcher and the 13GBs of game. I would like to get into the story but I get bored before I get to the next mission. Anyway.One to beam up... Go away 2009 Kerk and your 725m USS Enterprise, that is nearly the same size as the USS Enterprise E.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												Star Trek Online. This game is extremely basic, theres not much here other than the Star Trek feel, which soon goes after a few hours of playtime. I have been trying to get into this game over and over with no avail, its too boring. The ship desings and mechanics are sound, They're fun to play for a few hours every now and then, but by god dont get me started on the ground combat. I have never in my life played a game so clunky and weird, the animations are basic at best, some just seem so out of place it adds to the clunky movement and constant animation cancelling. Annnnd thats the game folks, nothing else to mention really, Raids and such are a joke, and no one plays them, you would be in a queue for hours on end looking for 3 people. Im not sure there is even a story here, Much like the TV shows, it's individual missions with the odd big missions with a story, then its completely forgotten till you find another. Voice acting in some parts and none existant in others, you would be best off just turning off the sound and listening to music while doing this grind of a game, actually, dont even pay attention to the missions either, because you soon get lost in what you're doing, even while paying attention.Now, what I did like about the games was the nice little tutorial stories each faction has, it realy feels like you're a member of the Klingon Empire, the Romulan Empire and even the Federation, who of which were the most enjoyable with the whole Borg element. But like I said, all the problems the game has, this feeling soon wears off. It is just a bad game, and the playerbase supports this, the game is pretty dead.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												TL;DR: DONT PLAY THIS UNLESS YOU LOVE STAR TREK AND HAVE A FRIEND TO PLAY IT WITH YOU, 4/10Now, I've played this game a lot. In the begining, it was fun, with the 2 main segments, Ground and Starship, allowing for the game to change what you do, so as to not get bored. But after this initial euphoria, I sadly have to admit, the game is mind-numbingly boring. Every mission has the same basic structure; Warp in, alternate between space and ground combat, then warp out again. It becomes a grind during the mid-game, and dispite attempts to make you solve puzzles or resolve issues, it becomes a mashing "F" contest, as you don't have to do anything other than that 99% of the time. On the rare occasion a genuine puzzle comes along, its solution is either highlighted in a text box, or told to you when you begin. And then the cash-grabbery. I would overlook moderate cash-grabbing in a F2P game; servers are not free, but the preposterous extent of the cash-grabbing in this game is unforgivable. You are capped at 10.000.000 Credits, unless you buy an upgrade. This would be fine, were it not for the fact that the majority of good late-game equipment costs much more than this. The vast majority of ships are locked behind their own paywalls, as are the more iconic outfits, such as the TOS uniforms, just to ring every possible penny out of the playerbase. However, worst of all is that the best, endgame ships are in lockboxes, which you have to buy keys for. But with these ships having an ~0.4% droprate from these crates, to get them you must either waste far too much money, or be very lucky. This guts the endgame, as if you dont pay into the system, you become obselete. Even at endgame the missions are boring and repetitive. Don't play this alone, get a friend who owes you a favour to go through it with you. Its comunity made missions can be fun, but the creator for theses missions is difficult at best. As a Star Trek fan, I have to honestly give it 4/10, as much as it pains me and my 11 days of playtime to do so.

												I was never a big Star Trek fan. To be honest I still have trouble completely understanding. I saw the two latest movies...never got into any of the old shows or movies but I'm slowly becoming a fan. This game downloads fast and is really in depth. Loading time is almost always fast, graphics are great and the community has NEVER been mean. Both characters I made (one I made long ago and quit because I just didn't understand the game much with the lack of a good tutorial) got into a guild really fast; and all the guild members did their best to help. Now that the tutorial is better done I'm enjoying it so much more. Pros: StoryGraphicsCommunityLoadingSpace/ground combatNot P2W (as far as I know so far with all my experience)Name can be remade once for free, ship customization can be mostly done with in game currency as well as character customizationYou can choose to hide your 'show weapons/utility belt' for free (yeah it's a pro because most game devs are shallow and you need to pay for it)Cons:It's one giant server making it unstable at times: crashes/lagsA very annoying random mix of voice acting and just text reading (just stick to one already!)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												After 250 hours or so the game just turned into a grind-fest. The story was fun to play through in the beginning, but it gradually devolved to the same types of missions, involving the same types of quests. The regular events were okay, but only if you upgragded your ship to the hilt (which of course requires signficant invest of either real money, or real-time gridning). The strength of this game is the space combat, and I will admit I'm sometimes tempted to fire up the game just to take part in some space battles. There's multiple classes to choose from, and a wide variety of ships to utilize (some free, some paid), and you can also upgrade your ship with a variety of devices (new weapons, shields, engines etc.).But the ground combat - ugh. It looks bad, plays bad, and is buggy too. It really weighs the game down in places, and I found myself dreading beaming down during missions. I hardly played the event ground missions because they were resoundingly terrible, and the ground fetch quests? I cringe just thinking about them.I can't really recommend this game in good faith. Will you have fun with it? Maybe, but it will also frustrate you to no end.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												Star Trek Online. This game is extremely basic, theres not much here other than the Star Trek feel, which soon goes after a few hours of playtime. I have been trying to get into this game over and over with no avail, its too boring. The ship desings and mechanics are sound, They're fun to play for a few hours every now and then, but by god dont get me started on the ground combat. I have never in my life played a game so clunky and weird, the animations are basic at best, some just seem so out of place it adds to the clunky movement and constant animation cancelling. Annnnd thats the game folks, nothing else to mention really, Raids and such are a joke, and no one plays them, you would be in a queue for hours on end looking for 3 people. Im not sure there is even a story here, Much like the TV shows, it's individual missions with the odd big missions with a story, then its completely forgotten till you find another. Voice acting in some parts and none existant in others, you would be best off just turning off the sound and listening to music while doing this grind of a game, actually, dont even pay attention to the missions either, because you soon get lost in what you're doing, even while paying attention.Now, what I did like about the games was the nice little tutorial stories each faction has, it realy feels like you're a member of the Klingon Empire, the Romulan Empire and even the Federation, who of which were the most enjoyable with the whole Borg element. But like I said, all the problems the game has, this feeling soon wears off. It is just a bad game, and the playerbase supports this, the game is pretty dead.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												TL;DR: DONT PLAY THIS UNLESS YOU LOVE STAR TREK AND HAVE A FRIEND TO PLAY IT WITH YOU, 4/10Now, I've played this game a lot. In the begining, it was fun, with the 2 main segments, Ground and Starship, allowing for the game to change what you do, so as to not get bored. But after this initial euphoria, I sadly have to admit, the game is mind-numbingly boring. Every mission has the same basic structure; Warp in, alternate between space and ground combat, then warp out again. It becomes a grind during the mid-game, and dispite attempts to make you solve puzzles or resolve issues, it becomes a mashing "F" contest, as you don't have to do anything other than that 99% of the time. On the rare occasion a genuine puzzle comes along, its solution is either highlighted in a text box, or told to you when you begin. And then the cash-grabbery. I would overlook moderate cash-grabbing in a F2P game; servers are not free, but the preposterous extent of the cash-grabbing in this game is unforgivable. You are capped at 10.000.000 Credits, unless you buy an upgrade. This would be fine, were it not for the fact that the majority of good late-game equipment costs much more than this. The vast majority of ships are locked behind their own paywalls, as are the more iconic outfits, such as the TOS uniforms, just to ring every possible penny out of the playerbase. However, worst of all is that the best, endgame ships are in lockboxes, which you have to buy keys for. But with these ships having an ~0.4% droprate from these crates, to get them you must either waste far too much money, or be very lucky. This guts the endgame, as if you dont pay into the system, you become obselete. Even at endgame the missions are boring and repetitive. Don't play this alone, get a friend who owes you a favour to go through it with you. Its comunity made missions can be fun, but the creator for theses missions is difficult at best. As a Star Trek fan, I have to honestly give it 4/10, as much as it pains me and my 11 days of playtime to do so.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												Having spent well over 200 hours on Star Trek Online, I can safely say it gives a far better experience than any other games based on the franchise I have played ever has. The game offers two types of combat, ground and space. STO also offers 3 different factions to choose from, the Federation, the Klingon Defence Force, and the Roman Republic (which is a thing in Star Trek Online)/Empire each having their individual storylines and content. Character customisation is excellent, and probably one of the best I’ve seen. However, STO is a combat based MMORPG, losing a sense of exploration; an important aspect of Star Trek. Plus, the more you play, the more the game becomes repetitive. Cryptic (the developers) have done an adequate job with the endgame content.Overall, the game is more than satisfactory.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												Star Trek: Screw the Prime Directive!STO is more for cookie-cutter MMO fans than Star Trek fans. If you don't care about the spirit of the franchise and simply want to blow things up and make yourself as explicitly powerful as possible for DPS, this is your game.If you are coming here out of the desire to have an interactive experience with the world you've grown fond of in the movies and television series, you will feel quickly let-down.This Star Trek universe isn't about exploration or diplomacy, or really any kind of social philosophy. It is about war, power, financial gain, and the biggest ego. Become an Admiral after a very short amount of time and play with dozens of others who are easily and conveniently and admiral as well, owning a collection of ships as if they are trivial collector trading cards, and deal with multiple "reputation systems" and currencies that pander to the ego and primitive reward systems.This simulation was put together by Klingons (frequent war, combat, honor systems), Farengi (multiple currencies and trading), Borg (insistive power in numbers and hardware), and an assortment of other races, none of which included the Federation.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
												I've been playing this game since the game came out, first with Cryptic then Perfect World.  This game is NOT P2W, you get amazing ships just by playing the game, players are helpful and generous.  This game is also Canon!  This is the world that is pre-Abrams.  In other words, Romulus is gone and Spock was sent to the past where JJ Abrams rules with world with pretty starship bridges and lens flares!  CBS is on board wit hthe game and that helps a lot!Make sure you find a fleet (guild) and they'll take good care of you.  You can play as either Star Fleet, Klingon Defense Force or the Romulan Republic.  The Romulans are a pseudo faction, after a while you have to choose to either ally with Star Fleet or the KDF.In the past, when I started playing, the Klingons were at war with Star Fleet. You could not play with them, you couldn't even talk to them.  Now everyone is allied to a degree and it's a lot more fun!There are multiple storylines, all voiced and the ships that come out around the same time all have the same general theme.+ Great Graphics despite it's age+ Customization options that are amazing+ Customizable ships+ Ship to Ship Combat+ Away team ground combat+ No need to spend real money to be competive and have fun+ You can get the Zen (paid for currency) by trading Dilithium+ You can get Dilithium if you have Zen you don't need+ All mission content is voiced+ You can have multiple ships and dry dock even more+ Solo play is very doable, I'm not a group player so I can't say much in that areaI could go all day with positives, I've been playing this game for years for a reason.- Can't have large amounts of EC (Energy Credits, in-game currency) without buying it in the store or having a subscription- *** Personal Opinion *** Ground combat is annoying and more common than ship-to-ship combat- A few latency issues from time to time- You'll want to spend money due to the cool factor of the ships etc.  They all have a gimmick that is pretty cool, but there's a lot of great powers etc available, but the fact that you need Zen (and sometimes a LOT of it) is annoying.- You can process 8,000 dilithium a day, at this exact moment you can get 1 Zen for 311 dilithium... Some store items are 20000 Zen... you can see where this gets annoying.  Fortunately you don't need shop items to have fun.They have seasonal events which can land you some very powerful ships for nothing more than your time and can be a lot of fun.  I've heard some people complain about Q's winter wonderland, (There's a combat against giant gummy sea monsters) however it's Q... he can do anything, so why not Gummy monsters?Anyhow, check it out, it's fun and I hope to see you in game!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
												(this will have PC and XBOX one reveiws: both are mixed)PC: the gameplay mechanics run pretty smooth, however theres a LOT of button pushing/mouse clicking involved so it can get pretty complex to those who are not used to a keyboard and mouse functions of a MMO. camera functions are pretty smooth compared to the xbox one (wich ill get too after the reveiw for PC) were you can let it zoom in or out by scrolling up and down with the mouse wheel. as far as the campaigns go for all 3 factions (romulan, klingon,federation) all 3 run alright without any problems. there is some lag every now and then thru out the game but you sometimes dont notice it.Xbox one: just the same with PC; the gameplay mechanics run pretty smooth, but there is less buttons to push and its all sorted into wheels that you can hold down buttons to select (wich can be pretty usefull to some or all). camera is very glitchy and does not have the full set up with it. during or after combat the camera will glitch to were its zoomed far out and away from your character, when that happens you have to hold down a button, then select "adjust camera mode" to reset it back to were you want it. its VERY BROKEN on the klingon characters, it zooms in OVER your character were its not positioned over the shoulder, federation characters dont have any problems with the camera other then it glitching during or after combat(this goes for all factions with the camera glitching)  (not shure with romulan yet, havnt gotten around to see if its as broken as it is on the klingon characters). STO on the xbox one does not have too many dedicated servers like the PC's version, and when ALL the servers are filled up..you can really feel the lag, when that lag hits, the game becomes your worst enemy, from making you go further down a path only to YANK you back into a random location or to the starting point over and over again,not doing damage to anything to dieing quickly or dieing in one hit, or spamming A in frustration to get to the next selection only to make you select MULTIPLE things to were you make wrong choices or makes you fail a mission or do VERY poorly in a event. example of this is the starbase 234 mission were you fight the ships and do enough damage to the starbase to pass, if you are lagging your not doing any damage AT ALL and if you try to get away from them so you can either abandon the mission and do it latter when the lag lifts up or to swap weapons and gear out to help you in your fight....your yanked back to them and they catch up pretty quick due to there not being affected by the lag, YOU are the only one affected by the lag. and sooner or latter you get oneshot or two out of nowere and the timer will say "0:00" or go down in 10 to 30 seconds EACH lagspikewith those bugs/ glitches you whould think the developers whould listen to the XBOX comunity on the game's performance and feedback, but no..the game has been out for two months and they have not lifted a finger to fix those issuesoveral: i highly recomend you stick to the  PC's STO or give it a shot. i cannot stress it enough to stay away from the one's STO unless your ok with the game fighting you over and over when the servers are full

content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												STO is great. It may have it's flaws, but it makes up for that being Free to Play. They do have event ships, so you don't actually have to spend money on getting a T6. they have a exchange "player controlled". The Exchange enables you to get game shop currency, that way you dont have to spend money, just time for the grind. They have a player shop, you can buy and sell items such as outfits, Lock Box ships, gear and keys for said Lock Boxs. There is a lot of grinding in this game, but it's great, it's sure worth the try. The story is a bit rough at first and in patches later on down the road, but it is overall enjoyable.Played it a lot without using Steam.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												First of it's a star trek MMO, and while most people will go nah, i'm not touching it, there are a lot of people that will enjoy itso lets start with the pro's and consPro's Continually updates with more Events and content.Learning curve isn't that steep.It's Free to play.Con'sIt's very senstive to certain anti virus / antispyware combos, and will crash at the drop of a hat.early game is free to play, late game at Vice Admiral / whatever your race equiv is (lvl 50) is not competetive for F2P'ers and you will at some point have to spend some money to buy an end game ship.PVP is merciless and you will get trolled.but despite those points, it's a very soild game and you don't really need to be a Trekker to enjoy it (Although it helps), I have so far clocked in around 2 Ish years and i'm still playing it, unlike WoW which kept sucking my bank account dry with it's PPM schemeIs it the best MMO out there, nopeis it fun, I'd say yes, but i'm sure there are other out there that will disagree with meIf you fancy saving / or destroying the galaxy in a fully customisable starship then this is probably the game for youGraphics 7Audio 8 (has some really recognaisable tunes for the trek series)Gameplay 7 (space combat is better than ground, otherwise this would be higher)Longeviety 9 (takes age to lvl to 50 if your a casual gamer)Overall 8.5

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												The space part is fun as is the ground part, but ground weapons are unbalanced and look dumb. Federation should be using hand phasers, not space gattling laser guns.Cool thing is melee is just as effective as weapons in ground combat, maybe even more effective. You can even kick♥♥♥♥♥unarmed with big roundkicks. It looks ridiculous, but that was still a good dev decision. You can even use a straight up sword. Problem with ground combat is the way the game is layed out in small areas that are mostly randomly generated crap. This game has like 1/4 of the ground combat it needs.The storylines are also pretty crap. Instead of developing one villian they pretty much used every villian the series has ever had, but developed none of them. Too many races as well, espeically the ridiculous looking custom races where you see things like 2 foot green midgets and homer simpson and joker from batman lookalikes.4-5 races for federation and 2-3 for klingons and 2-3 for romulans would of been more than enoughRacials suck as well, although they made it better. Crafting sucks, not worth anything, and only way to get good gear is be part of a good fleet or spend 20 buck+ to buy one from the store.Overall game has potential, but its really dead nowadays and is gonna need a miracle.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2012
												For the price (free!), it is not a bad game. You can create a character for each of the three main political states - Federation, Klingon & Romulan. There are a variety of races to choose from and you get to customize your character (and supporting NPC crew members) for free (first time only). I saw a lot of buxom & statuesque female Vulcans even one bald but for a top knot (very blonde hair) and a tattoo around one eye back going back towards the ear.Some of the game mechanics feel clunky & some cut screnes (shuttlecraft wobbling all over the place as it comes in for a landing on Vulcan) leave something to be desired. And if you want to really get serious in the game and get the good stuff, you will have to buy (as in $) special credits (or earn them which takes a lot of grinding). Missions included space & ground and you can even get involved in fleet actions (versus Klingons, Gorns, Romulans, Borg, etc). For the first MMO I have really played, Crunch had a good time (not playing much these days) and recommends it if you are looking for a casual or serious MMO. He rates it 7.5 out of 10.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												I've played STO since it came out around December 2009. I have to say that I have liked Trek since I was a kid, watching the, at the time, reruns, in the early 1970's and on to the various TOS movies. TNG took some getting used to, but Picard turned out to be a great captain. The only movie I really care for is Star Trek II The Wrath of Khan and then the new JJ Abrams retcons that take us back to Kirk, Spock, and McCoy. In my opinion, it's the Kirk era that is the real meat and potatoes of Trek. All the rest is just too far out into the future...making it all seem like magic instead of technology. Anyways, this is the only current Trek game and so I've been with it up to now in 2015 and probably will until it goes offline. If you really like Star Trek, this game will not disappoint you. It's Free to Play...which means all the cool stuff will cost you real life money.

												Its a great game to play, I've been playing since 2010 and I haven't regretted it at all. Its enjoyable, you really get the star trek feel and tooling around the galaxy in your own starship is pretty cool. Although having said that, every time they release new content or a major update the servers can't cope with the amount of traffic and I find I have to wait about a week before I can play the new stuff, which really irks me to be honest and what drove me to write this.Overall though the good outweighs the bad and I would recommend star trek online to anyone with the patience to wait a while after new stuff is released.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												First off this game will never win any graphics awards as it has a simplistic system because they have a "in game workshop" where you can make your own missions and scenarios in an in built creator.The game itself is very enjoyable as it seriously takes time to have fan service to all movies and series' that make up the cannon universe.The story takes place 32 years after the end of Voyager ad 20 years after the events in the JJ Abrams Star Trek reboot where Spock and Nero get pulled into an alternate timeline after the Romulus system gets destroyed.They link everything together in a compelling storyline that fills in plot holes from the franchise along the way.They have returning actors reprising theircharacters in voice overs for certain "seasons" or sections of the game.The Away team (ground) combat is a little basic compared to other  MMO's but the space combat...oooh the space combat...is some of the most fun I have had in a Sci-Fi game in ages.Seriously on week of playing the game and I bought the Lifetime subscription.There is a in game shop and "crate" system in the game that keeps this free to play game running, but you can quite easily play this game with the free ships you get during seasonal events.It is not a fee to play game as the bought stuff is generally cosmetic or has things just makes things easier. It doesn't break the game.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												I started playint STO shortly after it became F2P. At first it was a great game with a lot of things to discover, but that changed after a couple of weeks/months of play. Every mission is like: travel to this planet or system, defeat the enemies in the orbit of the planet/station or friendly ship, beam down to the planet/station/ship and defeat ~50 enemies in ground combat. Then beam back on board and defeat the reinforcement. Warp to sector space and report to starfleet.Although the story (traveling back in time, meet Kirk, Scotty and various other well known characters) was quiet good, the linear gameplay of just traveling, fighting enemies in space and then on ground was horrible. If I wasn't such a Star Trek Fan, I would have quit playing after 1-2 weeks. The overall gameplay is (from my point of view) horrible and I hate the ground combat. In all series/movies, there are just a few combats with a hand full of enemies. In the game, nearly every mission has a ground combat with about 50 enemies, which is horrible and does not fit into the Star Trek universe.  In space PVE you just need a DPS-ship, so tanking enemies with a cruiser is useless, because enemies will focus on the ship with the highest DPS. Flying a science-ship is also most useless, because they do 2 types of damage (weapon damage and exotic damage). So you can't skill effectefly a high-DPS science-ship.Space PVP does NOT work either. In most cases an enemy ship decloaks behind you, fires all BUFFs and hit you with ~70k DPS, so you are not able to do something against this. So PVP is mainly broken since YEARS.So all about fighting is to get the most DPS out of your ship. Group play is about doing high DPS in a short amount of time. So there is no tactic like - tanking the boss with a cruiser, slowing/knocking him back and apply dots with a science ship. All is about maximising DPS.There is grinding all around. The 5th year anniversary "present" was a mission, where you have to grind for about 3-4 weeks to get a highest tier cruiser. I tried the grinding mission for 4 days. At the second day the mission was broken, so I couldn't end it successfully. At the 3rd day this bug wasn't fixed. On the 4th day I quit and cursed PWE and Cryptic and all the other so called "Developers".Now content is all about getting a Tier 6 ship with REAL MONEY! So NO F2P anymore. You have to grind months of getting a new ship and then just more months for getting adequate equipment.Just a little bit about the story. There is a redone of all episodes from time to time. They just want that you want to replay Star Trek again with new characters, so they can sell you ships/items. The content of the story is sometimes good, but sometimes the conversations and explecitly the jokes are horrible. After you have done all missions, there is almost nothing to do. Star Trek Online is NOT about exploring the universe, other cultures or getting in first contact with other species. It's a poorly space/ground shooter, but the only MMO in Star Trek Theme (until now).

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												I've played this game twice "only" but the two times I did, I spent my entire day on it from morning to late night (actually morning, I admit it... I played 18 hours in a row and since I have a 30hr total, this also means my first time lasted 12 hours, which were also in a row). I was actually afraid to play it again and that this would happen. I was right, it just did. This game and its world and map are simply HUGE (In the beggining it is impressive and you will have to walk away to wait to reach another place while the ship travels, but I have read that once lvl 30 is reached, one can go fastly between all the systems & sectors and cross absolutely everything almost without any waiting time). The graphics performance is pretty nice & smooth and I play with all settings on maximum (antialising too). Maybe they could develop updates to make it even more "HD" with more textures?. The scenes in the space or inside detailed rooms are stunning and so inspiring. It is such an open world, with typical but also many unexpected missions (which makes it seem more realistic, as if it was indeed a different and existing world). When I was put to install statelites and scan a planet for it to be the new home of certain peoples, I was just fascinated and couldn't be happier about it. Specially, after I went into the planet to do scanning and some little alien creatures ran to me, stared at me and kind of sniffed me. After I analized them they'd run away with their fluffy weird little bodies, aw. It kind of made me think of SPORE (And SPORE was always pretty special to me because it always made me think of a book I got for my 9yo birthday, it was a book that changed my life, opened my mind & exploited my imagination (title: "Ami : Child of the Stars")), but without the cartoon-like designs and the 6yo entire game style. The space battles remind me a bit of the galactic conquest space battles from Star Wars : Battlefront II, but here controls are a bit more complex and ship movement & velocity are just a little bit more awkawrd (Half the game I used R for turbo speed (ON/OFF) and now it works only for turning it ON, so I have to click Q like nuts just to dicrease the velocity fastly to zero again), but is simply a different battle style. I would say it is some kind of mix between that and the modern M.M.O. games. It is not such a "social" game as other famous M.M.O. games I've played where is easy to "make friends" on the first or second day already, here most of people is completely into their own, which is perfectly fine to me (I actually got a fleet invitation but I declined because I was too focused on my own mission and its story line). I would say the ZEN currency and money-greed of all these new games are really tiring though. To get ZEN currency, you have to buy it, directly from your steam wallet. I would rather pay to have this game, than have all that c.r.a.p. incrusted in all windows related to your character and fleet. I'd pay once, in order to have freaking peace forever. Or easier, make it possible to transform the currencies again, as I read it was before in some review. Damn money grabbers.I'm going to bed at 5am, and I cant wait to play again!!! People out there, don't waste any more time and try this game out. Cause even if you don't like it, you will at least enjoy flying through the space ;)  I can also say this game has made me reflect about some deep couple of things too, I am sure it will provoke the same in any other reflexive person or just anyone that wonders about life, our universe, time-travel and space-time theories.Too sad I checked for the Steam screenshot shortcut in the middle of my game, otherwise I'd have over 100 screenshots instead of "just" 68 if I started taking them from the beggining of my game :p
